item.title: Morgan Stanley's Michael Grimes, the $10.5m salary and the $56m stock bonus
item.description:
Michael Grimes is back at Morgan Stanley. The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/7d960fcc-c80f-4c12-8b8e-1fd41fc7a444>reported today that Grimes has returned from his long year in the Trump Administration.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Instead of simply being a managing director (MD) and co-head of technology investment banking at Morgan Stanley as he was before, Grimes will now be the bank's group chair of investment banking. In this new role, Morgan Stanley says Grimes will apply his expertise to "the full banking and [institutional securities group] franchise, particularly as technology transforms productivity and impacts global industrial policy."
Now that Grimes is back in the room, it's worth remembering that he was never a standard investment banker anyway. In the public financial disclosure report <https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25969697-grimes-michael-d-278e278t-2025/> that Grimes filed when he joined the government in 2025, he revealed a $10.5m Morgan Stanley salary and $56m of Morgan Stanley bonuses that had been deferred during the previous three years. By comparison, H1B Visa filings suggest the average salary for an MD at Morgan Stanley is closer to $400k.
As we reported last April, </news/michael-grimes-banker> Grimes received other special dispensations during his 30 year career with the bank. He was, for example, permitted to avoid Morgan Stanley's management committees and firmwide strategy sessions, and encouraged to simply originate deals. He did this successfully, working on the IPOs of Facebook and Airbnb and cultivating a strong relationship with Elon Musk.
Musk is coincidentally considering a $1.5 trillion IPO for SpaceX this summer, and the FT notes that Grimes' return leaves Morgan Stanley well-placed to win a leading role. If so, Grimes' next bonus at Morgan Stanley could be far higher than his last one.
Grimes doesn't really need the money. As is always the case when bankers leave for government roles, Grimes benefited from the accelerated vesting </news/jamie-dimon-donald-trump> of his $56m of Morgan Stanley stock, which became accessible all at once instead of in three year tranches when he left for Trump. He will also have avoided capital gains tax if his deferred stock were reinvested in US treasuries or diversified funds.
Grimes wasn't really suited to government jobs. When he worked on a purge of the Chips Program Office last year, government employees complained </news/michael-grimes> of his manner and said it wasn't a "psychologically healthy place to work." Back at Morgan Stanley, Grimes can now be as brusque as he likes, so long as he delivers the SpaceX IPO.

item.title: How to get a job at Balyasny, the hedge fund hiring interns and portfolio managers
item.description:
Balyasny Asset Management </news/london-pay-balyasny> (BAM) had a good year in 2025. The hedge fund </news/all-the-jobs-in-hedge-funds> posted 16.7% returns, more than the likes of Millennium </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-hedge-fund-millennium> and Citadel, </news/2022/10/how-to-get-a-job-at-citadel>and it's looking to grow further in 2026. Speaking on the Generating Alpha podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O1M8y4QybU8> over the weekend, founder Dimitry Balyasny </news/dmitry-balyasny-hedge-fund> revealed what it takes to belong at BAM.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
What intern and graduate opportunities are there at Balyasny?
Balyasny said that the fund hired ~100 interns last year (more than previously projected </news/balyasny-internship>), and that next year's intake is "probably going to be 130-140 globally." The fund has a pretty good retention rate, hiring 65% of its interns </news/internship-investment-bank> full-time according to Balyasny, but what does it take to be chosen in the first place?
Balyasny said these interns </news/hedge-funds-with-graduate-training-programmes> "come in from all the top schools, investment clubs and math programs," and work across various departments including tech, risk </news/risk-job-investment-bank> and trading. 'Top schools </news/2016/08/the-top-20-universities-for-getting-a-hedge-fund-job>' presumably include the likes of Princeton, NYU and MIT, where Balyasny himself previously traveled </news/2023/12/balyasny-campus-recruitment> to talk to students.
If you join BAM full-time via its analyst program, Balyasny said that your relationship with your portfolio manager </news/2023/09/portfolio-manager-job-hedge-fund> (PM) becomes similar to that of a padawan and a Jedi master from Star Wars: “You’ve got to like and respect your Jedi and think that’s somebody you could learn a lot from," he said.
What do investment analysts and portfolio managers do at Balyasny?
There's a lot of similarities between the PMs and investment analysts </news/what-is-a-hedge-fund-analyst-a-day-in-the-life-of-an-equities-analyst-at-citadel> that BAM is hiring. Balyasny said that both analysts and PMs need to provide a "consistent flow" of "unique, varying ideas" about things that a lot of people are also looking at.
Alongside creativity, Balyasny said candidates need "investment discipline." A smart but ill-disciplined analyst, for example, "might fall in love with one idea. They have a hard time running models on 100 different companies."
The big difference between analysts and PMs is "risk tolerance." Balyasny said that PMs "need the ability to juggle lots of different balls." He said that "risk is tough to coach," and that most people have an "innate" level of risk that can be influenced, but not substantially changed.
What is the right risk profile? Speaking at the LSE Alternate Investments Conference in 2024 </news/dmitry-balyasny-hedge-fund>, Balyasny said it means "enough confidence to take meaningful risk and tolerate the volatility and tolerate drawdowns and not drive yourself crazy."
If this isn't you, maybe you could be analyst instead. He said on the podcast that "a great thing about being an analyst is you can go super deep on a particular thing and not worry about anything else." As a PM, meanwhile, "every day there's something blowing up your book."
Who is Balyasny Asset Management Hiring?
BAM has been growing its portfolio manager ranks. Balyasny said on the Generating Alpha podcast that the fund has roughly 200 PMs, up from ~175 in August. </news/where-do-portfolio-managers-work-balyasny>It's not clear where exactly the recent additions were based, but six months ago, the fund had 113 PMs in the US, 39 in EMEA and 24 in Asia.
Balyasny is especially focused on Asia, where revenues were up over 80% last year. Last month, Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-16/balyasny-asia-revenue-jumps-82-to-record-during-expansion-drive> said BAM had 250 staff in the region across 30 investment teams. It has 23 openings in Asia today, including listings for traders, quants and engineers.
Last year, BAM made a number of big name hires, including multiple who were going through drawdown periods. </news/dave-brodsky-balyasny-citadel>Balyasny previously suggested that people are willing to join the fund on lower wages </news/balyasny-pay> than elsewhere because of the strength of the firm's culture. In last week's podcast, he said that top talent are guaranteed high pay </news/hedge-fund-working-hours> at any of the major funds; if a few extra million dollars is "the main thing you’re offering... that’s not really compelling." Despite this, staff in Balyasny's UK entity </news/london-pay-balyasny> had more than double the total compensation per head of most major hedge funds </news/best-paying-hedge-funds> according to their most recent annual accounts via Companies House.
Balyasny said that, when screening candidates, "we look for passion a lot. Is this person super excited to be in this business, in this firm, in this role?” He said that having passion is important to get through those "miserable periods when nothing is working [and] you feel like the biggest idiot in the world."

The hedge fund </news/all-the-jobs-in-hedge-funds> posted 16.7% returns, more than the likes of Millennium </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-hedge-fund-millennium> and Citadel, </news/2022/10/how-to-get-a-job-at-citadel>and it's looking to grow further in 2026. Speaking on the Generating Alpha podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O1M8y4QybU8> over the weekend, founder Dimitry Balyasny </news/dmitry-balyasny-hedge-fund> revealed what it takes to belong at BAM.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
What intern and graduate opportunities are there at Balyasny?
Balyasny said that the fund hired ~100 interns last year (more than previously projected </news/balyasny-internship>), and that next year's intake is "probably going to be 130-140 globally." The fund has a pretty good retention rate, hiring 65% of its interns </news/internship-investment-bank> full-time according to Balyasny, but what does it take to be chosen in the first place?
Balyasny said these interns </news/hedge-funds-with-graduate-training-programmes> "come in from all the top schools, investment clubs and math programs," and work across various departments including tech, risk </news/risk-job-investment-bank> and trading. 'Top schools </news/2016/08/the-top-20-universities-for-getting-a-hedge-fund-job>' presumably include the likes of Princeton, NYU and MIT, where Balyasny himself previously traveled </news/2023/12/balyasny-campus-recruitment> to talk to students.
If you join BAM full-time via its analyst program, Balyasny said that your relationship with your portfolio manager </news/2023/09/portfolio-manager-job-hedge-fund> (PM) becomes similar to that of a padawan and a Jedi master from Star Wars: “You’ve got to like and respect your Jedi and think that’s somebody you could learn a lot from," he said.
What do investment analysts and portfolio managers do at Balyasny?
There's a lot of similarities between the PMs and investment analysts </news/what-is-a-hedge-fund-analyst-a-day-in-the-life-of-an-equities-analyst-at-citadel> that BAM is hiring. Balyasny said that both analysts and PMs need to provide a "consistent flow" of "unique, varying ideas" about things that a lot of people are also looking at.
Alongside creativity, Balyasny said candidates need "investment discipline." A smart but ill-disciplined analyst, for example, "might fall in love with one idea. They have a hard time running models on 100 different companies."
The big difference between analysts and PMs is "risk tolerance." Balyasny said that PMs "need the ability to juggle lots of different balls." He said that "risk is tough to coach," and that most people have an "innate" level of risk that can be influenced, but not substantially changed.
What is the right risk profile? Speaking at the LSE Alternate Investments Conference in 2024 </news/dmitry-balyasny-hedge-fund>, Balyasny said it means "enough confidence to take meaningful risk and tolerate the volatility and tolerate drawdowns and not drive yourself crazy."
If this isn't you, maybe you could be analyst instead. He said on the podcast that "a great thing about being an analyst is you can go super deep on a particular thing and not worry about anything else." As a PM, meanwhile, "every day there's something blowing up your book."
Who is Balyasny Asset Management Hiring?
BAM has been growing its portfolio manager ranks. Balyasny said on the Generating Alpha podcast that the fund has roughly 200 PMs, up from ~175 in August. </news/where-do-portfolio-managers-work-balyasny>It's not clear where exactly the recent additions were based, but six months ago, the fund had 113 PMs in the US, 39 in EMEA and 24 in Asia.
Balyasny is especially focused on Asia, where revenues were up over 80% last year. Last month, Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-16/balyasny-asia-revenue-jumps-82-to-record-during-expansion-drive> said BAM had 250 staff in the region across 30 investment teams. It has 23 openings in Asia today, including listings for traders, quants and engineers.
Last year, BAM made a number of big name hires, including multiple who were going through drawdown periods. </news/dave-brodsky-balyasny-citadel>Balyasny previously suggested that people are willing to join the fund on lower wages </news/balyasny-pay> than elsewhere because of the strength of the firm's culture. In last week's podcast, he said that top talent are guaranteed high pay </news/hedge-fund-working-hours> at any of the major funds; if a few extra million dollars is "the main thing you’re offering... that’s not really compelling." Despite this, staff in Balyasny's UK entity </news/london-pay-balyasny> had more than double the total compensation per head of most major hedge funds </news/best-paying-hedge-funds> according to their most recent annual accounts via Companies House.
Balyasny said that, when screening candidates, "we look for passion a lot. Is this person super excited to be in this business, in this firm, in this role?” He said that having passion is important to get through those "miserable periods when nothing is working [and] you feel like the biggest idiot in the world."

item.title: The wisdom of Hamza Lemssouguer, 35-year-old trading genius
item.description:
Hamza Lemssouguer breeds parrots </news/hamza-lemssouguer>. That’s not typical of a credit trader </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank>, but neither is market performance – or the depth of his wisdom at such a young age.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
It probably helps that Lemssouguer, just 35 years old, has been in charge of his own hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> since 2022. Lemssouguer's credit fund Arini (named after the parrots he breeds) Capital, which has gone from strength to strength. It now has $15bn in assets under management and has launched a recent partnership with Lazard <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-09-10/hedge-funds-hamza-lemssouguer-s-arini-is-dominating-europe-s-distressed-market>, the boutique investment bank </news/boutique-investment-banks>.
Speaking to students at the LSE’s Alternative Investments Conference earlier today, Lemssouguer admitted that not every day in his career was a win – and neither was that important.
“We don't create anything that is that revolutionary in our job,” Lemssouguer told students. “It's about discipline. It's about waking up every day, doing the same things and then keeping it and improving it. And also accepting that feedback, because ultimately you will be told that you make stupid decisions.”
A lot of bad decisions get made, inevitably. It’s part of the job. And by the time that Lemssouguer checks his phone in the morning, “I probably check that I made five stupid decisions last week, and what's important is to adjust and then move on and continue, not forget about them. You have to adjust, but move on.”
Being able to do that is what makes him a grand slam winner, or whatever the equivalent is in finance. “As Roger Federer said, he only won 54% of the points. He’s possibly the best champion in tennis we've ever seen. It's not about winning every point, it's about winning in general. And part of that winning in general is taking on the losses and adjusting your process,” Lemssouguer explained.
In turn, losses have to be managed in and of themselves. “Losses cannot be terminal. So how can you make sure that losses are not terminal? The initial analysis that you do before investing. Before we invest, and I think before you invest in anything, is think what if this all goes wrong.”
That kind of pessimism is key to working in credit in general. In fact, it differentiates them. Deciding between a career in equities or credit is all about deciding whether “are you – not personally, but professionally – an optimist person or pessimistic person?”, according to Lemssouguer.
Not that you have to be depressed to work in credit – “You can be optimistic in life and pessimistic at work,” Lemssouguer says – but if “you’re an optimistic person in general, and you like to see the dreams and ideas in the upside, credit is probably not the best [for you]. Because credit is really just about getting your money back, and if you dream too much you can get burned. In equities, you need the dream – you cannot be too pessimistic, or you say no to Amazon in the 90’s.”

item.title: Experienced compliance professionals are in despair: "Shocking pay cuts"
item.description:
If you occupy a compliance </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-compliance>role in the financial services industry and are hopeful that 2026 will be an improvement on 2024 </news/how-compliance-became-the-worst-place-to-work-in-banking>or 2025, </news/i-am-a-chief-compliance-officer-i-fantasize-about-resigning> then good luck. Many compliance professionals do not seem positive </news/compliance-jobs-finance-trap> about the year ahead.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
We spoke to five senior compliance professionals for this article. Their verdicts, imparted anonymously, were the same: the compliance profession is being starved of investment, and it's being felt in compliance jobs and pay.
"The business is in control," said one long term compliance professional. "Senior managers from the business don't allocate budget to compliance, which is always seen as a cost. It's the first place to be squeezed and we are always under a lot of pressure. You must always be right - if you're wrong you're fired!"
Following years of squeeze, the market is now awash with senior compliance professionals touting their wares. They are finding in the process that it is a buyer's market.
"I am shocked at how salaries across compliance have dramatically dropped," reflected one executive director who left his job after a decade late last year. "Roles that used to pay six figures, now pay £90k, for double the responsibility."
Another compliance said roles that once paid £100k are now paying £80k and that compliance has been particularly hard hit by cost cutting. "Most firms are offshoring their compliance processes and using AI solutions for monitoring, so there's a lot less demand for people," he added.
The laments come as Goldman Sachs is reportedly <https://www.cnbc.com/amp/2026/02/06/anthropic-goldman-sachs-ai-model-accounting.html?utm_source=www.shortsqueez.co&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=bonus-season-is-back&_bhlid=4e8afcf42e95f2c1874a17b59c272cde916b8f0a> using Claude to automate its compliance and accounting roles. They also come as the Trump presidency has adopted a more lenient regulatory tone and as Chancellor Rachel Reeves has promised <https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/rachel-reeves-mansion-house-2025-speech>to cut capital requirements and red tape in the UK. "The regulatory environment over the last five years put costs and burdens on the firm that we now won't have going forward," said Goldman Sachs' CEO David Solomon in January.
Solomon was referring primarily to capital requirements, but regulatory headcount is falling too. Citi said <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-14/citi-ceo-warns-of-more-job-cuts-calls-time-on-old-bad-habits>in January that it was 80% of the way through its program to remedy is regulatory failings following its 2020 consent order. <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/citigroup-aims-complete-work-consent-orders-this-year-sources-say-2026-02-06/> Citi has spent $260m </news/citi-hired-an-md-to-fix-its-compliance-issues-as-another-md-returned-to-bof-a>+ to solve its regulatory data issues alone and hired both risk and compliance </news/citi-is-still-out-there-hiring-m-ds-to-work-on-its-consent-order> staff and hundreds of data professionals </news/citi-data-hiring> and thousands of technologists <https://www.businessinsider.com/citi-hiring-4000-technologists-to-institutional-clients-group-strategy-2022-6> to controls in its investment bank. When the remedial program is finished later this year, Citi CEO Jane Fraser suggested some of those staff will be let go again.
Compliance professionals who are struggling to stay afloat said their profession needs reframing. "I have always faced off to the business," said one. "My mantra is "I help your business make money and avoid regulatory scrutiny and fines" - I make money and reduce risk (saving money)."
Another said he's looking at contract roles instead. "When you look at the personal liability involved in senior compliance roles and you compare that to the pay, it's not worth it," he said, referring to UK regulations making senior compliance personally liable for regulatory failings. "It's much safer to be a contractor now."

item.title: Investment banks may hire record graduates in 2026. Getting a job will be harder than ever
item.description:
For all the talk of AI reducing demand for juniors </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds> in investment banks </news/what-is-an-investment-bank>, a new report suggests that 2026 could be a fine year for graduate hiring.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
The latest Graduate Market in 2026 report from research firm High Fliers says investment banks in the UK are planning to recruit 2,365 graduates next year, up from the 2,069 graduates they actually hired in 2025.
If all goes to plan, this could make 2026 one of the best years for graduate hiring for a while. In the nadir of 2021 </news/2021/02/big-four-graduate-applications>, investment banks were only targeting 1,640 hires in the UK. This year, their aspirations are 26% above that.
Unfortunately, none of this means that jobs in banking will be any easier to come by. Martin Birchall, managing director of High Fliers, notes that the increase in graduate hiring by UK banks has coincided with a decrease in graduate hiring elsewhere.
"The biggest drop over the last three years has been at the accounting and professional service firms. </news/working-for-the-big-four-pwc-deloitte-ey-kpmg> Over three years they are down by about a third relative to where they were in 2022 and 2023," says Birchall.
The average student now makes 22 job applications but only 25% of them get jobs before leaving university, says Birchall. This means that each cohort of new graduates is up against the unsuccessful graduates from previous years. "You now have three cohorts competing for the same jobs," Birchall observes.
Faced with such harsh conditions, Birchall says students are applying for jobs across the board. "Students aren't thinking what is my ideal career I'll just apply for that," he says. AI is turbocharging mass applications. This is seemingly why banks are registering record high applications and record low acceptance rates </news/graduate-applications-to-banking-jobs> globally.
Birchall says banks' appetite for more graduate hires in 2026 is down to a strong year last year and to wariness about "gaps in talent 3-5 years down the line."
So far, he says there's been no sign that AI is reducing demand for graduates anywhere, citing instead a general malaise. If AI does impact graduate hiring, he's hopeful it won't be dramatic. "When accounting firms offshored jobs in 2010, everyone said it was the end of graduate programmes but they actually used offshoring to turbo charge growth," says Birchall, optimistically.

item.title: Indian HFT firm taps Hudson River Trading's ex-head of Europe to lead new London office
item.description:
Western prop trading firms </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> have been bolstering their Indian presence </news/as-jane-street-and-other-prop-trading-firms-expand-in-asia-these-are-the-new-faces-and-new-teams#:~:text=India%3A%20Everyone%20is%20hiring!%C2%A0> recently, but now an Indian firm is doing the inverse. It just tapped the former European head of a leading US trading </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank> firm to run a new London office.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Graviton Research has hired Ian Jack as its head of Europe, based in London. Jack previously spent six and a half years at Hudson River Trading, where he was CEO of its UK entity, 'Hudson River Trading Europe Ltd </news/hudson-river-trading-pay-uk-high-frequency-trading>.' He left in early 2023, and spent the last two years as a consultant before arriving at Graviton last month.
A company spokesperson told eFinancialCareers that the firm "recently established a UK affiliate, which will act as a talent hub for European research and development," and that Jack will be leading it. Graviton will be hiring in both the UK and contintental Europe. The firm's site currently only lists three offices; two Indian offices in Gurgaon and GIFT City, as well as an one in Singapore.
Jack isn't the only hire in London, though. Heejin Yoon also joined last month to work on business development after a four-year stint at another electronic trading firm, Maven Securities. </news/maven-securities-hiring>
Graviton was founded by Nishil and Ankit Gupta, both IIT graduates. The former was previously a portfolio management VP at Millennium spinoff WorldQuant while the latter was previously an intern at Deutsche Bank. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-11-25/high-frequency-firms-see-india-profits-surge-despite-regulatory-curbs> reported in November that Graviton's profits for 2025 rose 17% to 11.8n rupees ($130m), making it the top performing India-native HFT.

item.title: Morning Coffee: Goldman Sachs stands by its "feminist" on $23m. Bank CEO lies in until 5am following cancer diagnosis
item.description:
When Goldman Sachs hired Kathryn Ruemmler in 2020, it ran some checks on her past. A spokesman told Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-03/goldman-defense-of-lawyer-s-epstein-ties-provokes-unease-at-bank>that the firm did its own due diligence and "was satisfied." Six years later, Goldman insists it's satisfied still. But Ruemmler - who earned $22.5m working for the firm in 2024 is testing the definition of contentment.
Ruemmler is one Goldman Sachs most senior women. She joined the firm as head of regulatory affairs and has thrived. These days, she's a member of Goldman Sachs' management committee. She is chief legal officer and general counsel. She's head of Goldman's firmwide conduct committee, which ensures the integrity of its personnel. She is chair of the reputational risk committee, which protects Goldman's reputation.
Ruemmler is also a close advisor to Goldman Sachs' CEO David Solomon. Solomon thinks Ruemmler is great. He said recently: “Kathy is an excellent general counsel and we benefit from her advice every day.”
And yet, emails Ruemmler exchanged with Jeffrey Epstein in her pre-Goldman Sachs days are raising eyebrows about who she has dispensed her advice to. The Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/us-news/law/when-the-fbi-arrested-epstein-he-called-kathryn-ruemmler-39f7bf73?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqexN5DyXKKiV_YljQBFjJeph2QS6at-WVIWa1-9l8JmvQTP11mO_9gwnJA3d0k%3D&gaa_ts=6988a5ac&gaa_sig=DSsBBWuyBrHcT6sx_-eaRArRK8U2ZtRhh_Umu5MDUasnnbTUQ-2WDFAcxy61FTUPPKsiZiwFZn5gXTfAbPTjiA%3D%3D> notes that Epstein called Ruemmler when he was arrested in 2018. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-03/goldman-defense-of-lawyer-s-epstein-ties-provokes-unease-at-bank> notes that a version of Epstein's 2019 will listed her as a back-up trustee. The New York Post <https://nypost.com/2026/02/06/business/jeffrey-epstein-suggested-top-lawyer-kathryn-ruemmler-advocate-for-him-to-melinda-gates-give-her-the-other-side/> observes that Epstein - in offering to despatch Ruemmler to talk to Bill Gates' wife, called her "an arch feminist who is my great defender." [Gates spokesman said the reference is "absurd" and "completely false."]
Ruemmler strenuously denies any wrongdoing relating to Epstein. The WSJ notes that she never represented him. Ruemmler's spokesperson says she was never Epstein's defender and had no control over how Epstein categorised her. Epstein simply "informally reached out" to Ruemmler for advice, "just as he did with numerous other prominent lawyers throughout the country.” Epstein was a “monster,” said Ruemmler in a statement to Bloomberg last Tuesday; she regrets ever knowing him. She had "no knowledge of any ongoing criminal conduct on his part.”
Ruemmler's emails to Jeffrey have also emerged in the Department of Justice files <https://www.justice.gov/epstein>. In 2015 she told Epstein's assistant, "I adore him” and offered advice on Epstein's plea agreement, noting that, minors "could not legally consent to engaging in prostitution.” In 2017 she called him "sweetie". In 2016, the FT <https://www.ft.com/content/a07bb45d-512f-4694-9ce1-355b78131937> notes that Ruemmler and Epstein discussed her getting a job at Citadel and that Ruemmler appeared to jest that Epstein might “trade one of your Russians for my comp.” She didn't end up joining the hedge fund. “You know me well,” she wrote to Epstein in 2019, in emails where she said <https://www.wsj.com/us-news/law/when-the-fbi-arrested-epstein-he-called-kathryn-ruemmler-39f7bf73?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqexN5DyXKKiV_YljQBFjJeph2QS6at-WVIWa1-9l8JmvQTP11mO_9gwnJA3d0k%3D&gaa_ts=6988a5ac&gaa_sig=DSsBBWuyBrHcT6sx_-eaRArRK8U2ZtRhh_Umu5MDUasnnbTUQ-2WDFAcxy61FTUPPKsiZiwFZn5gXTfAbPTjiA%3D%3D> she was meeting John Rogers, who was instrumental in hiring her at Goldman Sachs.
Most controversially, though, Ruemmler received gifts from Epstein. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-03/goldman-defense-of-lawyer-s-epstein-ties-provokes-unease-at-bank> notes that these included a $9,400 Hermès bag, a $4,200 Fendi fur-trimmed plaid wool coat and a $1,700 Fendi bag. Bloomberg cites emails suggesting that Epstein's office asked Ruemmler whether she wanted a new band for her Apple Watch and she chose a Hermès one. She chose a date for tickets to the book of Mormon when Epstein offered to buy them.
A Goldman spokesperson told Bloomberg Epstein often gave unsolicited gifts to his contacts. Ruemmler's spokesperson told Bloomberg, “Ms. Ruemmler didn’t ask for anything and didn’t want anything.”
Like Epstein, Ruemmler didn't come from the upper middle classes. A profile of her <https://www.law.upenn.edu/live/news/8522-emerging-women-leaders-at-penn-law-nice-people> from 2018, says she arrived on her first day of law school without ever having a met a lawyer. Success comes from 'working hard, doing good work, and being a good person,' Ruemmler told students at Penn Carey Law School. "Don't be a jerk."
Eight years later, Ruemmler feels unfairly targeted as a result of her appearance in the Epstein files. “It is despicable to single out and attack a highly respected female professional simply because of her benign interactions with Jeffrey Epstein,” her spokesperson told the FT. <https://www.ft.com/content/a07bb45d-512f-4694-9ce1-355b78131937>
Goldman Sachs staff seem more confused by the matter, though. Speaking to Bloomberg, some executives at the firm oserved that they would be fired for accepting gifts worth only a fraction of those Epstein gave Ruemmler before she joined. Their confusion is amplified by the fact that Ruemmler now oversees Goldman's compliance policies governing the receipt of such presents.
Goldman Sachs declined to comment. Ruemmler didn't respond to a request to comment.
Separately, the Times <https://www.thetimes.com/business/companies-markets/article/barclays-boss-ai-bot-cancer-venkat-qq6pnqldv> has been speaking to Coimbatore Sundararajan Venkatakrishnan (Venkat), the CEO of Barclays.

item.title: Private credit pay is not what it used to be
item.description:
Private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity> had a good run, and people made a lot of money. Then things went sour – and private credit </news/2022/12/private-credit-jobs> had a good run. Now, with Q4 and 2025 results out this week for some of the world’s biggest private credit lenders, it seems that professionals hell-bent on private capital (or carried interest </news/what-is-carried-interest>) will need to find new employers. Again.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*1flq0xv*_gcl_au*MzI2ODY3NDA4LjE3Njk0MTgyODM.*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NzAzODgyNjUkbzQ2MiRnMCR0MTc3MDM4ODI2NSRqNjAkbDAkaDkwMDk1OTgzMQ..>✍️
Ares, which published its results yesterday, was the biggest of the three firms to declare, with over $622bn in assets under management (AuM), of which $407bn was allocated to private credit. Times do not seem to be good for its employees. The firm’s compensation bill decreased by 32% from $2.6bn to $1.7bn.
Blue Owl Capital was the second biggest private credit firm to announce its results this week, with over $307bn in AuM, of which $158bn, or 51%, allocated to private credit. Its wage also fell, by 22%, from $1.3bn to $1.0bn.
Neither Ares nor Blue Owl disclosed how many people they employ.
Carlyle also announced results today. Although traditionally a private equity firm, its private credit offering is now a bigger slice of AuM: of the $477bn total assets, $211bn (around 44%) were in private credit, compared to $164bn (around 34%) in private equity. Interestingly, between 2024 and 2025, Carlyle’s private equity AuM were flat, while private credit AuM were up by 10%. Despite that, Carlyle's overall compensation bill was down by 18%.
For both Blue Owl and Ares, the largest increases in AuM between 2024 and 2025 were not in private equity or credit. Instead, it was their "real assets” allocation that rose by 63% and 85% respectively, a description that includes real estate and infrastructure </news/2022/07/how-to-get-a-job-in-an-infrastructure-fund>, including digital infrastructure such as data centers.
The falling compensation bills come admidst the "SaaSpocalypse.” This has been promoted by fear that AI could massively harm software companies which received loans on the basis of huge, pre-AI valuations that might not exist in today’s world of ChatGPT/Gemini/Claude/Grok.
Shares in Blue Owl and Ares have fallen by 9% and 13% since Monday morning respectively as a result. That can't be nice for employees who have also been given deferred stock.

item.title: "I have worked for the FCA. The work ethic there is appalling"
item.description:
So, people at the FCA [UK Financial Conduct Authority] are complaining </news/the-fca-had-another-awkward-townhall-about-returning-to-the-office>about returning to the office. I've worked for the FCA and I'm afraid that I have no sympathy at all.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
During my career I have never worked anywhere where people are as work-shy and wasteful as they are at the FCA. The behaviour there is appalling. There is absolutely no accountability and people spend much of their time trying to get away with the least amount of work possible.
This means that jobs that should have taken six months can be strung out for two years or more. People choose to work at the FCA for an easy life and working from home has only made this worse. I had colleagues who would logon for an hour or two in the morning before doing for the rest of the day. People would leave calls to play sports or collect their children from school. The work ethic is awful.
This is why FCA staff absolutely need to be back in the office. Management are 100% right to ask them to go back in more often. They're not even asking for them to return every day, but only for 50% of the time and only from September. The complaints are laughable.
I have no sympathy with my former colleagues whatsoever. Initially I felt sorry that their bonuses have been removed. However, they effectively had a pay rise when they worked from home by saving money on season tickets. If they're struggling now it's because they overspent! Very few of them even work eight hours a day!
Nicole Lee is a pseudonym

item.title: Boutique bank Perella Weinberg slashed average pay by $350k+
item.description:
Reporting season for America’s boutique investment banks </news/boutique-investment-banks> is in full swing. While PJT Partners did well </news/pjt-q4-2025> and kept pay steady, Perella Weinberg Partners had the opposite problem – it did badly, and pay consequently collapsed.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
The problem started with the topline figures. Record high revenues in 2024 </news/perella-weinberg-partners-pay> declined by 14% in 2025, and dipped below even the first year of revenue post-IPO in 2021. In fact, if 2022 and 2023 wasn’t so bad for the market as a whole, it would have been PWP’s worst year ever as a public company.
Consequently, pay at the firm cratered. PWP doesn’t disclose exact employee numbers, but it had “approximately 700” employees at the end of both 2024 and 2025. Its wage bill, however, declined by 32% between those two years. Average pay, assuming 700 employees, went from $1.1m to $765k, a decrease of some $350k - per person.
The actual decline might be even more significant than that. The firm noted that it added 12 new (expensive) partners and 11 new (also expensive) managing directors </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds> across 2025. It had 66 partners at the start of 2025, and 77 by the end. 31% of partners at the firm had been there for less than 3 years, up from 27%.
PWP might be taking a risk with its declining wage bill. Bloomberg noted <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-05/moelis-evercore-pay-costs-rise-at-least-23-in-talent-battle?taid=6984f859be49b700014b1d65&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter> yesterday that the talent war among boutique banks was pushing up the compensation bill of banks like Evercore and Moelis by 27% and 23%, respectively - even Lazard's </news/lazard-q4-2025> increased by 4%. PWP might be left behind.
Nonetheless, the bank was upbeat about the situation. The poor performance demonstrated “the strength and focus” of PWP apparently, and the firm was positive that its record investment in people would place it well for “broadly favorable conditions for M&A” in 2026. If only we could all be so positive.

item.title: HSBC hired a BCG partner to help grow its investment bank
item.description:

Matt Halford, a partner at Boston Consulting Group (BCG) in London, has reappeared at HSBC where he will be director of strategic revenue development for the corporate and institutional bank.
Writing on LinkedIn, Halford says this new role will entail him "shaping and delivering new solutions in partnership with clients." At BCG he says he was a "core member of the financial institutions practice."
HSBC is keen on hiring ex-consultants and is also keen on BCG, with which it has worked since at least 2017. Previously, HSBC hired McKinsey Partner Chirantan Barua </news/2021/06/hsbc-strategy-jobs> as head of strategy for the whole bank, but he is now CEO of Scottish Widows.
BCG has long specialized in helping banks strip out layers and simplify their operations. Citi, for example, used its services to this end </news/citi-bankers-may-be-interested-in-bcg-s-guide-to-the-best-banking-jobs-to-2027>in 2024. HSBC was also practicising simplification </news/hsbc-job-cuts-delayering-country-managers> before adopting the more ruthless approach </news/hsbc-s-self-proclaimed-ruthless-ceo-is-not-its-most-feared-person>of closing much of its M&A and ECM businesses last year. </news/hscb-closure-europe-us-job-cuts>
Now it seems that Halford might help the bank diversify a bit again.

item.title: Morning Coffee: 35 year-old ex-Morgan Stanley trader's wealthy wife issues. Philosophical ex-UBS trader in Singapore is a sensation
item.description:
If, aged 29, you were to marry a 34 year-old woman whose family had made nearly $1bn in Malaysia after the second world war, and who was in a position to buy a house worth over $20m in London's Primrose Hill, would you continue getting up at 5.30am and going to work as a rates trader at Morgan Stanley or Credit Suisse?
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
In the case of Durham University graduate Ardal Loh-Granger, the answer was no. Having worked his way through a Goldman Sachs </news/how-to-get-a-job-goldman-sachs> internship </news/internship-investment-bank>, three years at Morgan Stanley and two years at Credit Suisse, Loh Granger gave up working in 2018 to oversee renovations of the marital home and support his wife.
That may have been a mistake. While the "enormous" trust fund of his wife Wei-Lyn Loh may have seemed sufficient to sustain Granger into his dotage, he made the error of having an affair. Aged 35, he no longer has access to his wife's money cushion and has received a payout of only £2.4m <https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/ex-goldman-sachs-banker-who-36668882>($3.3m) instead of the £6.5m he was hoping for. Granger's wife had a prenup and the judge ruled that he'd spent the other £4m during the latter stages of his marriage.
£2.4m is enough to live well if you're judicious with your investments. However, Granger, seems used to having staff and receiving £200k cars as gifts It's possible to navigate these relationships while remaining employed - ask ex-Goldman Sachs banker Rishi Sunak </news/2022/10/rishi-sunak-goldman-sachs>. If anyone wants a macro trader with home renovation experience, Granger may soon be back on the market.
Separately, someone who seems less likely to suffer marital infirmity is Minal Bathwal a 44 year-old trader at Brevan Howard in Singapore. Bathwal says the“first true test” of a good trader is ensuring that a spouse can't tell whether you had a good or bad day when you get home from work. “Be passionate about work, not emotional,” is his epithet.
In this way, Bathwal - who's described by Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-06/hedge-fund-trader-minal-bathwal-makes-billions-at-brevan-howard-in-singapore?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260206&utm_campaign=author_19458291> as "philosophical" and manages $5.5bn - has had no down years since 2008.
Meanwhile...
Peter Mandelson asked Jeffrey Epstein for help setting up his advisory firm Global Counsel. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/13d2f9e4-2d8e-49e6-a42f-35febcdc5d1f>
Barclays happened to be using Global Counsel's services. It's stopped that now. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/59f92e57-36a1-4996-8c3b-883b62630800>
Moelis and Evercore say that everyone wants to hire bankers. “The recruiting environment is heated up a lot, and it’s very intense and it’s very competitive. . There is no question that getting people to move is harder than it was two years or three years ago.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-05/moelis-evercore-pay-costs-rise-at-least-23-in-talent-battle?taid=6984f859be49b700014b1d65&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>
Elon Musk is paying bankers up to $100 an hour to train his AI. (Business Insider) <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/xai-is-offering-investment-bankers-100-to-train-its-chatbot-grok-9f9a6a50?mod=homepage>
Employees at Two Sigma were confused when a girlfriend of chairperson John Overdeck gained access to his computer and typed strange things into a shared file. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2026-02-05/how-two-sigma-founder-s-divorce-fight-hangs-over-hedge-fund-s-future>
Ina De is retiring at JPMorgan. There is no mention yet of her joining Citi. (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/jpmorgans-ina-de-retires-from-the-bank-after-nearly-40-years-510bf65b?mod=topic_investment-banking>
Now that it's staying private for longer, Revolut wants to bolster its corporate development team. It's recruiting an investment banker, asset manager or person with venture capital experience to oversee transactions, including potential M&A. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-05/revolut-boosting-team-that-runs-share-sales-without-wall-street?taid=6984922b8e61a70001b53d9f&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>

Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Jeffrey Epstein has derailed Karp. Emails <https://www.ft.com/content/e12add1a-56ab-41b9-8288-f8df81ab57f1> released by the Department of Justice in the Epstein files suggested that Karp and Epstein were friends. Karp asked Epstein to help his son find work with Woody Allen. Karp attended a dinner with Epstein in 2015, which he subsequently described as "truly "once in a lifetime" in every way." And that Karp volunteered to review a letter relating to Epstein's 2008 prosecution agreement. <https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/jul/01/usa> In turn, Epstein emailed Karp promising, “There are many many nights of unique talents. you will be invited often.”
Paul Weiss did not respond to requests to comment for this article. There is no indication that either Karp or Paul Weiss ever represented Jeffrey Epstein. Earlier this week, a spokesperson for the firm told Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/paul-weiss-chair-karp-regrets-epstein-interactions-firm-says-2026-02-03/>that Karp did nothing wrong: “Mr. Karp never witnessed or participated in any misconduct. Mr. Karp attended two group dinners in New York City and had a small number of social interactions by email, all of which he regrets.”
Today, the Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/business/deals/a-revolt-inside-paul-weiss-over-the-epstein-files-took-down-brad-karp-955fdfe6?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqd8UMnXuVQmPZM8DHOQKYeNjNTbLgH0QX5qJvNZNcDNFt9wKfhyE1Pdjd-76wE%3D&gaa_ts=6984e1e2&gaa_sig=46wwvkShzspxdASKkqbRTr0GVjozPKzWFkm8bXU3ngSypgDjAgO53_qQ0pb5qboRYx86C7M3P8owcphxKHWgSg%3D%3D> is reporting that Karp was ousted from the top job at Paul Weiss on Wednesday by a group of partners who met without him and decided the Epstein reports were simply too distracting. Karp was reportedly surprised, but went quietly for the good of the firm he'd helped build over 20 years.
Karp's demotion marks the end of an era on Wall Street, where he was a popular figure working on behalf of banks. In an interview last year, Karp told the Vault <https://www.paulweiss.com/media/wvvfa5bn/vault_a_litigation_trailblazer.pdf>that his clients included Citigroup, TD, UBS, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan, Apollo, Blackstone, and KKR.
Among other things, Karp told the Vault that he worked with clients on "sensitive internal investigations," "complex crises," and "damaging media coverage."
His cases included discrimination and sexual harassment cases. As a junior, Karp worked worked on the infamous Boom Boom Room case, which began in 1997 with allegations about sexual harassment and discrimination in a Smith Barney Branch, and which ended with a $33m gender bias class action settlement by Citi <https://www.reuters.com/article/world/us/citigroup-confirms-33-mln-gender-bias-settlement-idUSN03481416/> in 2008.
Karp reportedly <https://www.superlawyers.com/articles/new-york/the-team-player/>helped Citi sift through 2,000 claims as part of that settlement process. Afterwards, he praised Citi for wanting "do justice by the plaintiffs."
Since then, Citi has used Paul Weiss to work on other allegations against the bank by its staff. In a post on LinkedIn, Ardith Lindsey, </news/citi-equities-insiders-on-the-real-problem-london-management-poor-promotions>the Citi managing director pursuing a sexual assault and harassment case, claims that Paul Weiss attorneys are representing Citi against her. Citi also recently used Paul Weiss's people to interview its women complaining of mistreatment by its allegedly angry wealth head </news/andy-sieg-investigation>. Some of those women subsequently complained that they had not been interviewed after all.
Citi has repeatedly refuted all claims of wrongdoing relating to its head of wealth management and is fighting Lindsey's claim. The bank declined to comment for this article. Karp may still be on hand to help: the WSJ says he will remain at Paul Weiss as a partner and will continue to work for his clients.

item.title: The FCA had another awkward townhall about returning to the office
item.description:
As we reported here </news/fca-back-to-the-office> and here </news/fca-return-to-office>earlier this month, the UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) wants its people to return to the office for at least 50% of the time from September 2026 (60% for executive directors). The FCA's people are, however, used to working from home for 60% of their time and do not want to come back.
Today we understand that senior management at the FCA ran another townhall trying to persuade recalcitrant employees that it has everyone's best interests at heart.
Insiders say that the townhall did not go well and claim that the internal message board was instead deluged with comments like those we have extracted below. The survey referred to is an internal FCA survey on remote work, which we understand unearthed overwhelming employee support for home working.
"In light of the recent hybrid working announcement, which is expected to increase costs for employees, combined with the current low pay offer, are there any plans to provide additional support to staff in managing these increased financial pressures?" "Many staff will not be getting a pay rise in line with inflation, and given office attendance will be rising by 25%, why are staff being rewarded for an excellent year with a real-terms pay cut?" "Can you explain why the maximum level for each pay range (except Directors) has not increased this year? The consequence is that pay ranges have been narrowed, pushing more people to the high end of the range or onto maintained pay."
"What benefits of attending the office at 50% cannot be achieved at 40%?"
"When you mention there being “very mixed views”, are you referring to staff views, given the staff survey found the overwhelming majority wanted to keep office time the same or reduce it?"
"Conceptually, a month has around 20 business days. At 50%, this equates to 10 days per month or 30 days over three months. However, not all months have the same number of business days. If there are 61 business days in a three-month period and someone attends 30 days (49.12%), are they required to attend an extra day to reach 50%?" "Did senior leadership consider graduating required office attendance by grade (for example, lower grades at 40%, managers at 50%, senior leadership at 60%) to reflect commuting costs relative to salary? If so, why was this approach discounted?" "As a data-led organisation, why was the data provided by the CRF report ignored in favour of non-forensic “senior leadership judgement” when making the hybrid working decision?"
The complaints are unlikely to make much difference. A spokesperson for the FCA said she was disappointed that they have been made public . She added that: “We recognise that there is a range of views amongst colleagues on the increase to office attendance and many are understandably concerned about the impact on them. Our leadership team are engaging with colleagues on these concerns, including an hour’s Townhall today."

item.title: UBS has given its 100+ new bankers a gentle target this year
item.description:
UBS has got a lot more bankers than before. It also has more revenues. This year it wants growth again, and it should not be difficult to achieve that.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
When the Swiss bank announced its fourth quarter results this week </news/ubs-will-be-cutting-another-1-1bn-from-employment-costs-this-year>, it reiterated its target of doubling its global banking revenues by the end of 2026 relative to 2022.
UBS aspirations are based on global banking revenues adjusted for 'Purchase Price Allocation', or the fair value of assets that came with Credit Suisse. On this basis, UBS's new bankers need to grow revenues by 16.3% this year if they're to meet the stated target.
This should be feasible and it might even be easy. As the chart above shows, UBS's bankers managed to increase revenues by 35% between 2023 and 2024, despite only managing 10% growth last year. Speaking on the bank's fourth quarter call, CFO Todd Tuckner said last year's feeble performance was the result of weakness in the equity capital markets (ECM) business in the first quarters. This is changing. In the fourth quarter, UBS's ECM revenues were up 68%.
UBS has no shortage of bankers to drive its 2026 growth. Speaking to Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/ubss-marco-valla-eyes-us-growth-senior-hires-and-big-m-a-deals-in-top-six-push-4c240eb3>in December, co-president of the investment bank Marco Valla said the bank hired 25 "senior dealmakers" globally last year, alongside the 100 it acquired earlier from Credit Suisse.
This year, those bankers need to an additional $444m of revenues to hit the target. Split between 125 people that's just $3.5m each. Given that people like Morgan Stanley CEO Ted Pick are "amped" <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-21/morgan-stanley-s-pick-pretty-amped-up-about-the-m-a-landscape> about the year to come, UBS could probably be more ambitious.

item.title: Job fears for cloud engineers in finance: from "150 emails per day" to 20
item.description:
Big Tech firms have been laying off engineers en masse to start 2026, and cloud </news/deutsche-bank-cloud-transformation-costs> staff are up for the axe. AWS staff were affected by Amazon's 16,000 layoffs <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cx2ywzxlxnlo> in January, while there are unconfirmed reports that cloud infrastructure firm Oracle could lay off up to 30,000 people. <https://www.cio.com/article/4125103/oracle-may-slash-up-to-30000-jobs-to-fund-ai-data-center-expansion-as-us-banks-retreat.html> Is the future of banking cloud jobs just as grim?
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Cloud engineers </news/how-to-get-a-technology-job-bank> we've spoken to anonymously have mixed emotions. One former cloud engineer at a top US bank in New York told us there are "fears over job security" among cloud engineers and that job interviews are now few and far between. "There seems to be no traction from submitting applications," he said.
Another Cloud engineer at a US bank said "there has certainly been a downtick" in cloud hiring, but it hasn't disappeared entirely. He gets 20-30 emails per day and a few calls from recruiters, but this is "down from a peak during covid of a call every ~15 minutes and 150 emails per day."
Banks still have plenty of open job listings for cloud engineers. We've analyzed data for 14 major banks to see how many engineers are working directly on cloud infrastructure. There are over 1,300 jobs globally, including over 400 in the US. HSBC, Citi, BofA and JPMorgan each have over 100 cloud engineer listings, but the likes of BNP Paribas and UBS are hiring in much smaller numbers.
Cloud engineers were in vogue </news/2022/06/cloud-engineering-jobs-banking> as banks begun their transformation efforts, dismantling legacy technology and bringing everything together on the cloud. Cloud engineering job security becomes more tentative </news/barclays-tech-overhaul-good-for-uk-technologists-less-so-for-cloud-staff> as these transformations near completion, but maintaining AI </news/bankers-frustrated-with-ai-liken-their-jobs-to-manual-labour> architecture may have given them a lifeline. The second cloud engineer said "we're finding it still takes a lot of time to do work even with latest models at our side... I'm seeing an uptick in emails again."
Top cloud engineers may be more valued in other financial firms, however. The New York engineer said he'd been invited to just one interview at a bank in the past six months, but had received "maybe four invitations to interview with hedge funds." These roles are often more than just cloud engineering, though; Citadel's site reliability engineering (SRE) team work on cloud architecture, Linux systems engineering, incident response and more.

item.title: It doesn't seem that bonuses will be big at BNP Paribas this year
item.description:
It’s Q4 2025 reporting season for Europe’s investment banks. Deutsche Bank </news/deutsche-bank-gently-trimmed-45-people-in-q4-while-hiking-pay> was last week, UBS </news/ubs-will-be-cutting-another-1-1bn-from-employment-costs-this-year> was yesterday, and BNP Paribas <https://invest.bnpparibas/en/results> was this morning. The French bank didn’t do all that well.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Across 2025, its fixed income, currencies, and commodities (FICC) sales & trading </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank> team posted revenue just 8% up on 2024 results. European rivals Deutsche Bank and UBS enjoyed greater growth (FICC up 13% and 31%, respectively). However, it was comparable to American banks Bank of America and Goldman Sachs (up by 8% and 9%, respectively). BNP Paribas seemed nonetheless content with the increase, which it credited “mainly” to “rates and options activities.”
Sadly the French bank's equities & prime services team did even worse. Revenue here was up just 10% in 2025 on 2024, well behind what any of the other major banks have posted. Fortunately, the bank was even happier with the increase, which was “across all segments and regions.”
BNP doesn’t break down investment banking revenue, but it did note that it had a “good increase” in both capital markets </news/capital-markets-jobs-ecm-and-dcm> and advisory, mostly on account of a strong performance in the Americas – which was the best-performing region globally anyway in M&A </news/what-are-ma-jobs>, according to LSEG, formerly Refinitiv.
As such, bonuses will likely be scant. Across 2025 as a whole, the investment bank’s operating expenses increased by just 3%, from €10.7bn to €11.0bn. In Q4 alone, expenses declined ever so slightly.
Perhaps more worryingly, the investment bank’s risk weighted assets (RWA) declined from €278bn to €258bn, a decrease of more than 7%. How RWA is calculated is complicated, but just for reference, consumer & personal banking RWA declined by just 1%, and investment & protection services RWA increased by 33%.

item.title: The top universities for investment banking technology jobs in the UK
item.description:
Investment banks don't just hire investment bankers for their internship </news/internship-investment-bank> and graduate </news/bank-acceptance-rate> roles. If you study maths </news/best-degree-for-hedge-fund-job>, computer science </news/unemployment-uk-graduates> or another STEM subject, you could get a technology role in a bank, </news/how-to-get-a-technology-job-bank> but which universities do banks love the most for these roles?
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
We've analysed data from our CV database and publicly available information on LinkedIn for 16 major UK universities to provide a proprietary score for getting a banking technology job, looking at total alumni working in banking as well as intern/graduate level professionals.
The results are clear. Imperial College is your best option, with next to no competition; it ranked first in every metric analysed and had almost triple the score of the second-best university, Warwick.
Many of the top technologists in banking worldwide have studied at Imperial. David Coulson, a Goldman Sachs partner and CTO of banking and markets, studied a PhD in theoretical physics at Imperial while Citi's chief technology officer, David Griffiths </news/citi-s-cto-says-these-are-the-kinds-of-jobs-he-s-eliminating-with-ai>, has a computer science masters from the university. Citi's chief information officer, Jonathan Lofthouse, </news/citi-hybrid-working-cio> studied at second-ranked Warwick.
Imperial ranks 22nd in the world for computer science in the QS university rankings <https://www.topuniversities.com/university-subject-rankings/computer-science-information-systems>, and third in the UK behind Oxford and Cambridge. Oxbridge graduates are less numerous in banking tech but are still present. They are favourites, for example, of electronic trading firms like Jane Street </news/the-20-universities-jane-street-loves-most-for-its-quants-and-engineers> and Citadel Securities </news/the-universities-that-will-get-you-a-300k-job-at-citadel-securities>, which tend to pay their tech staff much more money and poach a lot of the top talent. Other top-ranked universities are typical broad banking target schools, </news/target-universities-finance-uk> including LSE and UCL in London.
Getting a graduate technology job in banking isn't just about what school you attend. To get in, you'll need to brush up on Leetcode </news/how-much-leetcode-should-you-do-to-work-at-google-or-goldman-sachs> problems to pass banking technology assessments, and you'll probably need to have multiple personal projects or open-source contributions </news/hedge-fund-tech-cv-interview-advice#:~:text=Another%20way%20you,your%20own%20risk.> to stand out.

item.title: HSBC's zero bonuses risk upsetting already traumatised bankers
item.description:
When HSBC announced its bonuses last year, some people had a shock. Not only were they receiving zero bonuses, they were losing their jobs. In the words of CEO Georges Elhedery, the bank had decided to be ruthless. </news/hsbc-s-self-proclaimed-ruthless-ceo-is-not-its-most-feared-person>
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
"We were split into three categories," one HSBC insider told us at the time. </news/hsbc-zero-bonuses-fired> "a) Fired today (no bonus, here is your severance package); b; Short term retention (finish your project and then likely severance and small bonus); c). Long term retention." It was a surprise: "HSBC had a reputation for looking after [its] people,” another employee reflected. Recent reports suggest that 25% of managing directors </news/hsbc-michael-roberts> were let go.
Now it seems that HSBC is doubling down on its new reputation for ruthlessness. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-05/hsbc-to-cull-underperformers-as-some-bankers-face-zero-bonuses> reports that the bank is preparing to pay some people zero bonuses for 2025 as it moves to a Jefferies-style </news/jefferies-bonuses> 'eat what you kill' mentality, albeit without Jefferies' cash. MDs will be included in this new bonus approach, which is presumably being overseen by ex-Citi corporate banker Michael Roberts, head of the corporate and institutional bank, and his close colleague Gerry Keefe.
Eating what you kill is a fine aspiration, but it is not necessarily as clean cut as chasing and eating a horned beast. Banks are notoriously political places and if a beast is about to be killed, all the big cats will gather round and claim their part in taking it down. Evercore, for example, operates an eat what you kill </news/barclays-cost-cutting>approach to bonuses, and when its MDs submit numbers for deals they've each originated, those numbers reportedly <https://www.ft.com/content/51c51a6d-4727-413c-98f9-458afdf51ed0> always exceed the total.
Things could be particularly brutal at HSBC, where the corporate and institutional bank were combined in 2024. There are now corporate bankers, investment bankers, sector teams, product teams </news/hsbc-cuts> and the remaining M&A execution team all vying to claim that they made the kill.
Jefferies is supposed to be </news/it-s-bonus-week-at-jefferies-i-am-told-it-has-been-a-great-year> moving away from this model in an attempt to become more collusive. HSBC reportedly wants its zeroed bankers to leave. Unhappy people could always try there instead.

item.title: Morning Coffee: Regrets of the ex-JPMorgan banker on $30k a month. 25 year-old VCs received a salary reduction
item.description:
When should you leave your steady banking job, with its steady salary and its wealth of deferred bonuses? It's always a hard decision, particularly if you're a managing director who's worked at one bank for 20 years and your deferred is large.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Paul Barrett seems to have thought hard before leaving JPMorgan. After the event, Barrett wrote to his new employer and complained: “I walked away from all my JPM stock and now my annual compensation is reduced by 66% until I can sign more clients." Fortunately, he still seems to been in receipt of a $30k monthly management fee.
Barrett's travails are detailed in the Financial Times. <https://www.ft.com/content/649886ce-877e-4aac-80d5-57e1d6422028?accessToken=zwAAAZwpnrnakc9kmIbOh35KrNOA1Vfh1kIgKA.MEYCIQD1PmaNAuxA8cvQHfW6ONTyWrV7Ikk8cZ6IyH7t2RD3fAIhANvYhSSoKfZ69fj5xFJWzLDPKrUO3dtDdw60tiGvWVkT&segmentId=e95a9ae7-622c-6235-5f87-51e412b47e97&shareType=enterprise&shareId=8101f34a-f58f-4eb7-8405-18559b8065ad> Like many bankers, he left the carpeted corridors of the big institution for the thrill of the family office </news/family-office-jobs>. Unfortunately, the family he chose was the one-man-dynasty of Jeffrey Epstein.
It was a fatal move. Along with Peter Mandelson </news/peter-mandelson-deutsche-bank>, Jes Staley </news/jes-staley-bill-winters-jpmorgan> and many others, Barrett's subsequent career implosion is now public knowledge. As Jeffrey's private banker, he suffered all the standard problems of private office persons (can't always get hold of the founder, founder has own opinions about investments, founder loses confidence after a period of poor returns), plus the fact that his name became associated with the world's most notorious deceased sex offender.
It can't have been easy for Barrett, described by ex-colleagues to the FT as "sophisticated, intelligent" and "with a certain air of confidence." Fortunately, though, he was able to take himself off to Citi. After seemingly minimal due diligence, the bank hired Barrett in 2019 and appointed him to head its private capital group's North American region. <https://www.businessinsider.com/citi-private-bank-aiming-to-grow-junior-talent-by-20-2019-11>Barrett left again five years later once Citi apprehended his history. It's not clear whether he got to keep any stock that time instead.
Separately, young people love venture capital firms, but venture capital firms do not love young people.
Three years ago, VC jobs were all the rage </news/2023/01/venture-capitalism-jobs>with 26 year-olds aspiring to find the next unicorn. Now, a new compensation survey says their pay is shrivelling.
While senior VCs are still handsomely remunerated, newcomer <https://www.newcomer.co/p/heres-what-your-fellow-venture-capitalists?utm_source=substack&publication_id=82416&post_id=186864407&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share> notes that analyst salaries fell 25% last year to $78k and that few analysts in VC firms receive carried interest </news/what-is-carried-interest>, even when it is available.
AI is to blame. Large language models are proficient at market mapping, deal sourcing and competitive research and you don't have to pay them much at all.
Meanwhile...
Jeffrey Epstein was coaching Jes Staley on how to object to the Volcker Rule. “We should craft an arg why volcker is bad for europe..Peter can say he has spoken to you. It is bad for europe for the following reasons.” (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/e50f2f0a-f1b5-4c6d-b4c0-58435dbc9b63>
Rokos Capital Management had been thinking of hiring Peter Mandelson for an advisory role but has changed its mind. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/f638307f-8fc2-4193-a6b7-8551a3bfde27>
Jain Global hired five new portfolio managers in Asia. item.title: The art of the $4m+ job offer from Deutsche Bank
item.description:
If you're looking for a job with a $1m salary and a $4m-$10m bonus with Deutsche Bank in London, then the recently released Epstein Files <https://www.justice.gov/epstein> offer some helpful pointers on how this might be achieved.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
As has been noted, Peter Mandelson </news/jes-staley-bill-winters-jpmorgan>, the now disgraced ex-member of the Labour Party, ex-member of the House of Lords and ex-US ambassador, sent some emails to Jeffrey Epstein regarding a job at Deutsche Bank. These we have published below. They are also visible here. <https://taxpolicy.org.uk/2026/02/02/mandelson-epstein-no10-documents-4m-job/>
Mandelson's emails suggested that he received an offer to work for Deutsche Bank "on an international basis" in 2010. He claims that he was to be paid up to $4m for his services, but the first email in the chain below suggests he could have earned $11m at the most.
It seems that Mandelson never took the job. Deutsche Bank isn't commenting, but it's understood that Mandelson has never worked for the German bank. Nonetheless, Mandelson's email exchange suggests broad tactics that jobseekers may want to bear in mind.
Know a major networker. Mandelson knew Epstein. Epstein was also best chums with Disney fan and ex-Barclays CEO Jes Staley </news/jes-staley-bill-winters-jpmorgan>. We are not advocating that anyone befriend a paedophile, but Mandelson's emails with Epstein confirm that knowing people who know people unfortunately makes all the difference. Use an intermediary. One 'Martin Armstrong' spoke to Colin Grassie, Deutsche Bank's then CEO of the UK on Mandelson's behalf. There are Martin Armstrongs who fit this potential profile on Google. We asked one of them to comment; he declined. Be keen. Accept all job offers promptly Use one offer to get another. Having accepted the offer from Deutsche Bank, Mandelson tried to get a better offer from Kleinwort's from someone called Tim Collins, who had big opinions about Deutsche's strategy. Do not disclose your different offers. Epstein told Mandelson not to tell Tim about his Deutsche Bank discussions.
Ultimately, it seems that Mandelson took neither job. It is not clear why.

item.title: After brutal job cuts, Clear Street will make some tech people very rich
item.description:
If you are Matthew Cyzer or Phillip Hylander, you can be forgiven for shedding a tear today. The two men were cut along with others </news/brutal-job-cuts-at-new-york-fintech-s-london-office-are-raising-eyebrows>in July 2025 after a very brief period working for Clear Street. Today Clear Street filed <https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1881567/000119312526036739/d39893ds1a.htm> for a $1.05bn IPO.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
On February 12th, Clear Street is reportedly <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-04/wall-street-broker-clear-street-seeks-1-05-billion-in-ipo?taid=6983479eba85ed00014b86ab&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>proposing to sell 23.8bn shares for between $40 and $44 each. Today's filing reveals that 7.8 million restricted stock units were issued to employees in 2023 and 2024 respectively, at prices ranging between $5.5 and $7.4. In 2022 and 2023, employees were also given 3.7m and 5.8m of stock options at prices below $2 and $3.
Some people at Clear Street are therefore about to become very rich. The people cut last year are probably not among them.
Instead, Clear Street's coming IPO is likely to reward its senior executives and its top technology staff. That includes brothers in law and executive chairman and executive vice chairman, Uriel Cohen and Elli Ausubel. CEO Edward Tilly, who was in retirement before he joined from CBoe markets in 2024 has $71m in unvested stock.
Clear Street said today that 40% of its employees are engineers and that another 7.5% of them work in risk and control functions. It added that it's hired more than 200 engineers since 2023 and that paying them well is necessary because, "competition in the technology industry for qualified employees is intense and many of these employees hold extensive knowledge and experience in highly technical and complex areas spanning technology and capital markets, including the options, equities and futures trading and clearing industry."
Technology staff in banks, who are complaining of reduced bonuses this year, may find this energising.

item.title: How Andrea Orcel "purged" 11,000 people at UniCredit
item.description:
Andrea Orcel </news/andrea-orcel-unicredit-commerzbank>, the workaholic investment banker with a penchant for calling people at 5am </news/2012/03/what-ubss-investment-bankers-need-to-know-about-andrea-orcel#:~:text=2.%20He%20will%20be%20calling%20you%20at%205am>, became CEO of Italian bank UniCredit in 2021. Since then, the bank's stock price has increased by almost 10 times. This didn't come without sacrifice.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Speaking on a podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUCIBWBo1b4> with Norges Bank this week, Orcel said that "culture is the lynchpin of everything" and a good culture is a guarantee of eventual success. He also said that, "inevitably, to change it, you have to purge people who are not in that culture." Making cuts was one of the earliest things he did after assuming the role, including removing a co-head structure, <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/unicredits-new-ceo-orcel-streamlines-top-management-structure-2021-05-12/> much like Citi has (kind of </news/citi-has-a-lot-of-new-co-heads-for-a-bank-that-doesn-t-like-them>) been doing in recent years.
In the podcast, Orcel said that there were 80,000 people when he joined, but there are 69,000 today, implying that at least 11,000 have been purged. How did he decide who didn't make the cut?
Orcel said that one of his earliest tasks was "interviewing, directly or indirectly, 20,000-30,000 people" to find out their values and what "made them tick." He figured out the cultural "pillars" of the company from these responses (integrity, ownership and care, apparently) and built the company's strategy around them. People lacking those attributes have presumably been ejected.
Orcel also said he initially used a top-down management style to instil values, but that the culture is now bottom-up instead. He doesn't mandate that people come to the office </news/days-in-the-office-by-bank> at specific times. However, people at UniCredit work similarly long hours: "because I work really hard, I drag them."
UniCredit is attempting to hold onto its best people even in fields susceptible to AI </news/jpmorgan-ai-jobs> and automation. Orcel said that, a year after he joined, the bank created a "risk healing unit" to reskill high-quality people in disintermediated jobs. 650-700 people have gone through the unit so far.
While Orcel's purging seems to have benefitted the share price, he has reportedly faced criticism from UniCredit's board for the performance of its investment bank. Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/unicredit-ceo-under-renewed-board-pressure-over-ma-clarity-sources-say-2025-10-22/> reported in October that the bank had not landed any major deals despite large investments. Orcel said that a full cultural transformation for a company the size of UniCredit can take more than a decade; perhaps more purging is necessary.
