item.title: Evercore paid its people almost $1m per head in 2025
item.description:
After the big US banks reported back in January, America’s boutique investment banks </news/boutique-investment-banks> have started publishing their Q4 2025 results. PJT yesterday </news/pjt-q4-2025> did great, and Evercore today <https://investors.evercore.com/news-releases/news-release-details/evercore-reports-record-fourth-quarter-and-full-year-2025> did even better – and was more generous with the purse strings.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Net revenue and income at the firm shot up by 29% and 53% to $3.8bn and $641m respectively, which founder and chairman Roger Altman noted was a record. The firm’s market share was also at an all-time high.
The firm also added people last year. Headcount went from 2,380 at the start of 2025 to 2,570 by the end of the year, an 8% increase. And average pay also went up by 17%, from an already impressive $829k across 2024 to an eye-watering $973k across 2025.
That increase was partly related to who joined the bank. The number of senior managing directors (equivalent to MDs at a normal bank or Partners at other boutiques) in investment banking & equities went from 184 to 210, a 14% increase.
Although the bank itself admitted that the “senior new hires” helped to pump up the wage bill in Q4, it wasn’t the only reason. Accrual of “incentive compensation”, that is to say bonuses </news/banker-bonuses>, and “higher base salaries” also contributed to the increase across Q4 and the year as a whole. Evercore’s bankers will be eating well this bonus season.

item.title: "Students fail trading interviews because they talk too much about crypto"
item.description:
I am a senior macro trader </news/2021/05/how-to-get-a-job-in-a-global-macro-fund>on the buy-side. I've held senior roles at leading banks and have worked for multistrategy hedge funds. </news/big-multistrategy-hedge-funds> I have also interviewed a lot of students who want to be traders.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
In doing so, I have noticed that they repeatedly make the same mistakes. Once a student makes it through the HR interview and is actually talking to the desk, they will almost always start talking about all the risk they've taken in their own investments.
I often encounter students who tell me about their multi-hundred % returns and their crypto wins. They seem to think that this is what I am looking for.
They are wrong.
I don't want to hire people who take a lot of risk. I want to hire people who are prudent, with a selective risk appetite and sensible targets.
I am interested in people willing to run a marathon, not sprint heroically in search of quick profits.
Students don't seem to understand this.
When young people in interviews </news/70-top-banking-interview-questions-and-how-to-answer-them> say they make 20-50-100% returns, it's a red flag. Most of the instruments we trade move by 1-2% intraday.
Our worry, therefore, is that young people accustomed to crypto volatility will struggle on an institutional trading desk. Their sizing adjustment will be too much of an expensive lesson to learn.
What we are looking for is not people with big crypto wins. We want people with completely psychological and emotional control, who can take large notionals of risk with very prudent and tight management.
Please remember this next time you boast of your 400% bitcoin returns.
Ewan Rogers is a pseudonym

item.title: UBS will be cutting another $1.1bn from employment costs this year
item.description:
Today's fourth quarter results <https://www.ubs.com/content/dam/assets/cc/investor-relations/quarterlies/2025/4q25/full-report-ubs-group-consolidated-4q25.pdf> from UBS bring good news. In its own words, the bank is busy "executing final stages of integration to capture synergies." The integration of Credit Suisse is nearly over.
It is not, however, over completely.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Although 73% of applications have been decommissioned, although the 'CS legacy IT infrastructure wind-down and legal entities integration' is "materially complete", although $13bn has already been spent integrating Credit Suisse and even $10.7bn of cost savings have been squeezed, there are more costs to come out this year.
UBS said today that it intends to extract a further $2.8bn from costs in 2026. 40% of this is to come from people: $1.1bn will be removed from the compensation line across the bank. Heads will roll.
Who will go?
Maybe not the investment bankers, who are tasked with doubling revenues from the 2022 level by the end of 2025. Last year, UBS's M&A revenues were 10.5% while capital markets revenues fell by 7%. This year, CEO Sergio Ermotti said he's hopeful that IPOs will drive stronger revenues in ECM.
Maybe not UBS's equities sales and trading professionals, who achieved a "record share" in cash equities and a strong performance in prime and equity derivatives.
Maybe not the bank's FX or precious metals traders, who it says had a strong 2025. Nor the bank's rates traders </news/ubs-markets-bonuses>, who already look a little diminished.
Maybe not the technology team working on the integration. Although most has been done, Ermotti said today that the final stretch will be the hardest to achieve.
Within the investment bank at least, then, it might be mostly middle and back office </news/finance/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking> people who suffer. The bank has the standard "portfolio of large scale AI programs" which are intended to "unlock" efficiencies and cost savings. The key is turning on process-oriented jobs.

item.title: Morning Coffee: JPMorgan thinks bond salesmen can do banking deals. Hedge fund manager’s novel approach to harassment claims
item.description:
The two great noble houses of investment banking, alike in dignity, are “Sales and Trading” </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank>and “Capital Markets </news/capital-markets-jobs-ecm-and-dcm> and Advisory </news/get-a-job-in-ma>”. And relations between the two are often rather like the Montagues and Capulets; they’re two indispensable parts of the same show, but that doesn’t mean that they have much in common. Usually this is reflected in co-head structures; when you have joint leadership of a regional business unit, one co-head represents markets and one represents bankers.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Conor Hillery and Matthieu Wiltz </news/jp-morgan-s-new-london-leaders-are-possibly-more-popular-than-its-old-ones> are this star-crossed pair at JPMorgan. The two men were appointed co-CEOs of global banking in EMEA late last year, and have since been making a point about how well they get on </news/jpmorgan-bonus-cap>. Wiltz has a background in credit sales and runs JPMorgan's EMEA markets business. Hillery is a financial institutions group (FIG) banker by trade and runs JPMorgan's European investment banking business.
However, things are changing with their most recent promotion <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/jpmorgan-hands-hillery-and-wiltz-top-global-banking-roles-in-europe-d0e5d417>. Wiltz is being asked to cross the divide.
While Wiltz remains head of EMEA sales and global head of credit, securitised products and public finance sales, he is also going to be given “dealmaking” responsibilities. Hillery keeps his role as EMEA head of investment banking.
It’s not completely clear what deals Matthieu Wiltz is going to be doing, but we might speculate that it’s related to management’s decision to increase the pressure </news/jpmorgan-bankers-pressure-2026> on JPMorgan bankers to ask for more business <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/jpmorgans-new-emea-ceos-dont-be-afraid-to-ask-for-more-business-76091792> and win back market share. Among the core skills of any head of sales and trading is the ability to put pressure on people.
It might backfire. The culture of investment banking is different to the trading floor; M&A and capital markets deals intrinsically take longer to put together than bond trades. There is a fine line between hustle and hassle; it’s good to promote aggression and proactivity, but not if it starts to undermine long term relationships for the sake of quick transactional wins. Filippo Gori, the previous JP Morgan EMEA CEO once warned <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/an-audience-with-jpmorgans-filippo-gori-were-looking-at-things-that-havent-been-touched-for-20-years-02544e3f> that the switch from trading to banking was “a big cultural shock”.
Elsewhere, it's not easy to be a hedge fund founder facing an investigation by the board, which appears to have unearthed dozens <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-03/odey-investigators-uncovered-46-conduct-allegations-against-him-fca-says> of misconduct allegations. What do you do?
If you’re Crispin Odey, it seems that you tolerate it once, agreeing to a final written warning from the executive committee of Odey Asset Management. But if they begin a second investigation, following further complaints, your patience wanes.
A new filing by the Financial Conduct Authority, which is in a legal battle with Odey over its decision to ban him from financial services (which he disagrees with), suggest Odey didn't take kindly to being investigated.
After berating the board as “spineless” and telling them that “HR law doesn’t apply here”, the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/73b1c8b7-792e-4d36-8d1a-371d71710443> notes that the filing claims that Odey used his majority shareholding to dismiss the entire committee, appoint himself the only member and then vote to suspend the investigation into himself indefinitely.
Odey “strenuously denies all the allegations” (in this case, five personal injury claims brought against him by former employees and a libel claim against the FT). But it really feels like, whatever comes out in court, this is definitely an episode where a calmer temper and a bit of common sense could have saved a lot of trouble.
Meanwhile ...
Ken Griffin has admitted that CEOs find it “incredibly distasteful” to have to “suck up” to the White House in order to keep running their business. This might seem inconsistent with past statements the Citadel founder has made about President Trump, but it’s entirely in line with the pod shop model – if you lose a couple of per cent support in the opinion polls, you get your allocation cut. (WSJ <https://www.wsj.com/business/ken-griffin-says-ceos-find-trumps-interference-distasteful-3c388e8f>)
At the age of 71, Howard Silverblatt of S&P Global has decided that “that sixty hour workweek is not as much fun as it used to be”, even if you can spend it working from home in Florida. He is retiring, and now lots of investors are panicking about how they might replace the “pope of earnings”. (WSJ <https://www.wsj.com/finance/investing/howard-silverblatt-sp-global-retirement-ccbb929d>)
Never previously someone who has shown a huge amount of concern for his reputation, Lars Windhorst demonstrates that even his thick skin is not impenetrable; he’s been moved to strenous denials of any involvement with Jeffrey Epstein after an email showed up which appeared to suggest he’d been asking for a meeting. (Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/lars-windhorst-denies-link-to-jeffrey-epstein-as-email-claims-he-sought-meeting-1f519a06>)
The strain of working in finance can often break up marriages, but something weirder might have happened here. A senior official at the FDA is being accused of having concocted a “sham divorce” so that his venture capitalist wife wouldn’t have to divest some of her investments. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-03/senior-fda-official-under-oig-investigation-over-divorce-assets?embedded-checkout=true>)
The past is never dead in Swiss banking – it often isn’t even past. UBS is still dealing with further investigations into it (and Credit Suisse’s) actions with respect to the bank accounts of fugitives from the Nazis. (WSJ <https://www.wsj.com/finance/hundreds-of-swiss-bank-accounts-with-suspected-nazi-links-found-by-investigators-cda06807>)
Jason Ader was once a prominent activist investor, claiming CEO scalps like that of Marisa Meyer at Yahoo. He is now in court, being sued by his own mother over a defaulted mortgage and begging the judge not to “take the shirt from his back”. The good days are over. (NY Post <https://nypost.com/2026/02/02/business/deadbeat-hedge-fund-boss-sued-by-his-own-mother-declares-bankruptcy/>)

item.title: Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan, BofA & Citi ramped up US MD hiring last year
item.description:
2025 was a big year for US bank hiring. It was also a big year for US bank exits.
A new report says top US banks doubled their managing director (MD) hiring last year. This might discourage hiring in 2026, but for the fact many existing MDs also moved on.
The chart above is based on data from search firm Sheffield Haworth. It has not been validated by the banks concerned.
Sheffield Haworth estimates that Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, RBC and UBS each either doubled or more than doubled their hiring of external investment banking MDs in 2025 versus 2024. JPMorgan, Citi and Barclays also increased hiring dramatically during the period.
However, while MDs came in one door, they went out another. One bank is estimated to have ended the year down 23 US MDs and Citi - which hired heavily in 2024 </news/citi-hiring-barclays-stifel>- is estimated to have ended the year down eight.
The figures in the chart do not reflect MDs created by internal promotions.
By Sheffield Haworth's reckoning, last year's biggest US MD hirer was Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo ended 2025 with 21 more MDs than it began, not counting internal promotions.
Fernando Rivas </news/wells-fargo-md-hiring>, head of Wells Fargo's corporate and investment bank, told the FT <https://www.ft.com/content/f5ac8471-184e-4425-bd4e-8c2d0197c3d7>earlier this month that the bank intends to add 25-30 new managing directors (MDs) in 2026, and then again in 2027, following on from the 125 investment bank MDs it's hired since 2019.

item.title: JPMorgan hired the head of UBS' AI lab to assess employee performance
item.description:
JPMorgan's quest to implement AI </news/how-to-get-a-banking-ai-job> has continued in 2026. It just hired a veteran AI technologist that spent the last two decades working on technology for investment bankers. </news/what-is-an-investment-bank>Now, though he's doing something a little different.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Ronald Jansen </news/2018/08/ubs-poaches-goldman-sachs-veteran-run-data-lab>is joining JPMorgan in New York as its head of AI for human resources and employee experience. He spent the last seven years at UBS, where he was an MD and global head of its AI lab in its global banking division. Before that he spent 13 years at Goldman Sachs, eight of which as an MD, where he led a team of strats </news/strats-jobs-investment-banks>working on M&A, capital markets and derivatives structuring.
JPMorgan made multiple MD-level hires in its HR and employee experience division last year. Matt Brandt </news/the-new-jp-morgan-technology-md-that-might-decide-if-you-re-cut-or-promoted> joined in July as its head of data and analytics from Morgan Stanley. A month later, the bank hired a head of talent transformation </news/jp-morgan-s-new-head-of-talent-transformation-suggests-a-rise-in-moneyball-promotions> from tech consultancy Accenture.
AI is already part of the performance review process at JPMorgan. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-11-13/why-bosses-are-using-ai-for-performance-reviews> reported in November that the bank has allowed managers to use internal AI bots to write reviews. It's not the first bank to do so; Jane Fraser said in October <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-10-28/citi-looks-to-ai-to-help-bosses-write-performance-reviews> that there were supposedly cheers at Citi when the bank announced staff could use AI to assess performance.
The technology Jansen will develop at JPMorgan may decide who gets promoted... or cut. CEO Jamie Dimon said at Davos <https://www.hrgrapevine.com/us/content/article/2026-01-22-jp-morgan-ceo-jamie-dimon-says-governments-should-help-manage-ai-workforce-shift> last month that he expects JPMorgan to have fewer employees in five years time, and has already been eliminating entire categories of job </news/jpmorgan-ai-jobs> thanks to AI

item.title: Elite banking VPs in their late 20s may find themselves earning $740k
item.description:
If you're an associate </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds> somewhere like Bank of America </news/bank-of-america-associates-got-their-bonuses-and-they-feel-nostalgic>, your bonus </news/london-bankers-bigger-bonuses-are-fraught-with-complexity> may not be the best this year. But if you're a vice president (VP) at somewhere like PJT </news/pjt-q4-2025>, your reward may feel ample indeed.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Meridith Dennes, a former banker turned recruiter of bankers in New York City, says vice presidents have been allocated exceptional bonuses for 2025. She says elite first year VPs have had bonuses hiked 34% to earn median total compensation (bonus plus salary) of $500k (£365k), Elite third year VPs at bulge bracket banks are now on median total compensation of $740k (£541k), says Dennes.
VPs are typically in their late 20s.
Not every is an elite VP, though. Mediocre VPs are less well rewarded. If you're not a VP at a big US bank or top boutique, </news/boutique-investment-banks>but you work for the middle market </news/2023/02/middle-market-banking-jobs>, your pay will be less. Nor will you be a desired employee. "We're seeing more large, complex transactions - $5 billion-plus deals, AI-related acquisitions, transformational mergers," says Dennes. "Banks need VPs who've already operated at that scale." Midmarket VPs are therefore out of favour, however hard they grind. </news/baird-industrials>
Tom Ragland, CEO of recruitment firm Harrison Rush Group, confirms that VPs are banks' most sought after people in 2026. "Banks are paying up for execution support at the VP level. Associates have not had the opportunity to work on many deals," he observes. Banks need people who are ready to run; deals are expected to roar back this year.
It's not just about avoiding the midmarket. The VPs who are at a premium now are a particular breed. Good is longer measured simply in deal count. "It's deal quality and contribution level," says Dennes. The preference is for VPs who have been "meaningfully involved" in deals and who have interacted directly with C-suite executives.
VPs who have this kind of experience can switch between boutiques and big banks to maximize pay. Dennes says elite boutiques pay 20-25% more than banks in total compensation to their VP 1s and 2s. However, banks pay more than boutiques to their VP 3s.
The new pathway to earnings maximisation may therefore be to start with a bank, leave for a boutique, and then return where you came from. This looks different to last year </news/investment-banking-salaries-bonuses>, when a salary and bonus survey from Instagram account Litquidity found that VP3 pay was highest ($750k) in elite boutiques and $75k less in banks.
On the odd occasion, though, VP3s may still earn more in boutiques. Ragland says the highest pay he's seen at that level this year was $800k and that it wasn't in a bank.

item.title: The Hudson River Trading engineer who quit to build children's toys
item.description:
Working in electronic trading </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> opens up a lot of doors, but some are much more unusual than others. Ben Hansen spent six years in the sector, working across Headlands Technologies and Hudson River Trading </news/working-for-hudson-river-trading> (HRT). Latterly, he was a tech lead that helped set up HRT's credit trading business. Now, he spends his time developing toys for children.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Hansen left HRT in 2022 to found Boppo <https://boppo.com/>, a screen-free tablet that provides 40 different games and activities using ten buttons. It was inspired by his experience working at home with a one-year-old child for HRT during COVID; </news/2023/08/jane-street-remote-working-tools> "If I was on the computer working late, he'd come over and start clicking the keys with me," he said. Hansen, who was a manager at the time, missed being an individual contributor, so he learned electronics and circuitry to put Boppo together. He told us he "enjoyed being an absolute beginner again."
There are some surprising similarities between Hansen's work at HRT and his current work at Boppo. The tablet uses a microcontroller instead of a CPU to be price-competitive, which comes with "a lot of memory constraints." Boppo's software is written primarily in Rust, </news/rust-vs-c-plus-plus-financial-services-low-latency>with "some C and C++ </news/low-latency-c>" to address that issue. Hansen said that the focus with Boppo is more on performance than latency, as the tablet only needs to be as fast as human perception, but performs a lot of tasks simultaneously.
One of the biggest differences is user experience, which is "very different" for a child compared to a trader, who will often optimize their screen by a matter of pixels </news/jane-street-s-traders-on-1-4m-have-fighter-pilot-eyes-high-pain-thresholds> to deal with high information density. Boppo has a stripped back interface that guides children to certain tasks through sound and lighting.
Work-life balance </news/jane-street-pay-hourly> is very different for Hansen today. He told us he's "working later nights here than I ever did for HRT... the peak stress is way more, but there are times when there's less stress." Working in a startup means, as the adage goes, that Hansen is wearing many more hats, which has been a challenge "because I found out like I'm really not good in a lot of other areas like marketing."

item.title: Hedge funds are lining up inhouse recruiters for a big 2026
item.description:
If Goldman Sachs is right, </news/hedge-fund-hiring-2026>2026 will be another big year for hedge fund hiring. This year, it found that a net 45% of asset allocators </news/david-solomon-goldman-sachs-pay> plan to increase hedge fund exposure - the highest level ever for the survey since 2017.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
More assets usually mean more portfolio managers </news/2023/09/portfolio-manager-job-hedge-fund> and more support staff. This may explain why some hedge funds have started this year by adding the sorts of business development </news/as-hedge-funds-churn-talent-their-super-recruiters-are-more-important-than-ever>staff that help them find new talent.
Schonfeld, for example, has just onboarded BlueCrest's </news/bluecrest-mike-platt>global head of business development, Michael Grad, in New York City. Grad is not joining as a bus dev guy specifically but as the 'chief investment initiatives officer', which could conceivably include investing in human beings.
Citadel, which Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/business-development-execs-left-citadel-past-year-2025-11> says lost seven business development professionals last year, had replenished its ranks with Justas Povilenas, a former recruiter who's just arrived in London to focused on hiring in fixed income, and with Alana Althens, who arrived from Moody's in New York to focus on adding talent in equity quant research.
And Brevan Howard, which has had some turnover </news/hedge-fund-brevan-howard-parted-with-company-with-7-senior-technologists> in its technology team has hired quant recruiter Rhydian Lawrence to work in business development in London, as well as Oscar Willett who previously spent 17 years at search firm the Omerta Group.
The inflow of business development professionals is not the only positive indicator for hedge fund hiring. Investment staff are moving too. Most notably, Citadel added Florent Bénichou as head of US fixed income portfolio finance in January. Bénichou, a mathematics graduate of the prestigious École polytechnique in Paris was previously head of repo and indexing for the Americas at Credit Agricole.

item.title: Boutique bank PJT made the tiniest tweaks to pay and headcount
item.description:
Paul Taubman’s boutique investment bank </news/boutique-investment-banks>, PJT Partners, published its Q4 of 2025 results <https://ir.pjtpartners.com/news-events/press-releases/detail/110/pjt-partners-inc-reports-record-full-year-and-fourth-quarter-2025-results> today. On the face of it, they were pretty good – even if the bank doesn’t seem to be celebrating too much.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
The headline figures were strong. Both the firm’s revenue and profit reached record highs, up by 15% and 30% on 2024’s results respectively, to $1.7bn and $310m.
Curiously, however, the firm didn’t do much hiring in Q4. Headcount was down by two people in the last quarter: PJT reported that it employed 1,226 people at the end of Q3 2025 – and just 1,224 at the end of Q4. That isn’t to say it made cuts (people do leave of their own accord after all), but it also didn’t hire enough to make up the shortfall.
Perhaps more disappointingly for PJT’s people, pay did not go up as dramatically as revenue or profit did, despite the reduced headcount. Average pay per head at the bank went from $903k on average in 2024 to $946k on average in 2025, an increase of “just” 4.8%.
Despite the slow Q4, overall headcount was still up for the year as a whole, going from 1,143 souls to 1,224, an increase of 7%. The number of partners – revenue generators – also went up, from 119 to 133 across the year, an increase of 12%. The majority of the new partners were in M&A </news/what-are-ma-jobs>.
The firm had its usual gushing praise from staff in its earning presentation. “Outstanding people,” is how one anonymous contributor described colleagues, “with strong intellectual curiosity, passion, humor and empathy.” They make PJT “an incredible place to work,” apparently.

I found the insider on LinkedIn. I was networking there as I prepared for summer internship </news/internship-investment-bank> applications and I approached a young trader at a leading US bank. He mentioned that he sometimes gave classes to students and we got talking.
He ended up tutoring me for an hour or so a week for a few months. He was very knowledgeable and really knew his stuff. I paid him around £3k ($4.1k) for his help and he told me that he would be able to refer me to HR as I was such a strong candidate.
I don't think he did that. I am not even sure now whether he worked for the bank he claimed to work for and I don't think he was a trader.
Either way, I spent the money but I have no internship or job. I ended up applying for 50 internships in total, all without success. I was at a non-target university. </news/target-universities-finance-uk>

item.title: Morning Coffee: When JPMorgan ousted a steady male banker for one with dubious tastes. ExodusPoint's prolonged revival
item.description:
Hindsight is a fine thing and if it were applied to the case of Jes Staley and Bill Winters when they were at JPMorgan, things would probably turn out differently.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Winters, now aged 64, has had a career unmarked by scandal. Married to the same eclectic theatre director <https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2019/apr/13/building-ideas-creatives-spaces-inspire-them> for years, his most risqué moment was the exposure of a nipple <https://www.cityam.com/heres-new-standard-chartered-chief-executive-bill-winters-bare-chested-doing-falsetto/> in a fundraising video during 2015.
And yet, in 2009 the well-liked Winters was famously ousted </news/2009/09/five-possible-outcomes-from-the-swift-departure-of-bill-winters-at-jp-morgan>as co-head of JPMorgan's investment bank by disgraced banker Jes Staley. As of yesterday, we now know that Staley spent the following year in contact with Jeffrey Epstein, and that during that time he sent a woman in Epstein's purview instructions to dress up in a Snow White costume so that he could "take photos," possibly more.
Having a Disney fetish should not be career-ending. Staley's problem is that it was facilitated by Epstein, who had been convicted of sex offences involving minors in 2008. Staley's problem is that he subsequently denied all knowledge of Snow White in court, where he also proclaimed no knowledge of Epstein's “monstrous activities.”
As Staley is once again dragged through the residue of his relationship with Epstein, Winters - who has been happily running Standard Chartered since 2015 - can be excused a moment of schadenfreude. As accounts from the time make clear, <https://www.ft.com/content/a91dc5fc-ad25-11de-9caf-00144feabdc0> the mild-mannered Winters was rudely displaced by Staley in the run-up to his 48th birthday in 2009. Winters, who had successfully steered JPMorgan's investment bank through the financial crisis, <https://www.seattletimes.com/business/jpmorgan-dumps-exec-who-kept-it-out-of-risky-complicated-investments/> had no idea what was coming. "It was a complete bolt from the blue,”one colleague told the FT <https://www.ft.com/content/a91dc5fc-ad25-11de-9caf-00144feabdc0> of his firing at the time.
A good banker was replaced by a bad one. Maybe JPMorgan could send a retrospective apology.
Separately, it wasn't so long ago that hedge fund ExodusPoint was losing AUM and suffering shrinking headcount. </news/exoduspoint-hedge-fund-hiring>Now, the fund is on a roll.
Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/january-hedge-fund-performance-citadel-schonfeld-2026-2> reports that ExodusPoint returned 1.8% in January after 2025 was its best year ever. Citadel and Schonfeld both returned 1%, by comparison.
Meanwhile...
Goldman Sachs top lawyer Kathy Ruemmler asked Jeffrey Epstein to help her get a job at Facebook. He said:“I suggest you prep for your meeting as a case. Read up mark, sheryl, prepare an opening and summary. Along with a case strategy. III help.” She said: "These decade-old private emails you are selectively referencing and pruriently reporting on have nothing to do with my work at Goldman Sachs.” (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/1fdb1850-7ff8-4ca5-bc91-f4b683aad063>
Peter Mandelson sought advice from Jeffrey Epstein on a job offer worth up to $6m from Deutsche Bank. In 2010, he seemed to have an offer with a salary of $1m (£733k) with scope for a bonus of between $3m and $9m, in line with what “a senior banker would be paid in the UK market”. (CityAm) <https://www.cityam.com/mandelson-epstein-deutsche-bank-job-offer/>
Legal juniors would ask Jeffrey Epstein to review their CVs. (Legalcheek) <https://www.legalcheek.com/2026/02/epstein-files-show-aspiring-lawyer-asking-disgraced-financier-for-application-advice/>
The British Treasury wants to cut 300 people by 2030 and is offering them £100k exit packages if they've worked there for 21 years and earned £80k. (The Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/2f7107b4-8005-4af2-b433-9cde3f0bb88d>
Crispin Odey says the Financial Conduct Authority was under “political pressure” before it decided to ban him and fine him £1.8mn for a “lack of integrity”. (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/3e21fa4c-ad38-47f7-9b49-29e15f0d8ddc>
Victoria Buhler, who works for Robey Warshaw, now part of Evercore, is joining Keir Starmer instead. She will work with Varun Chandra, the prime minister's chief adviser on business, investment and trade. (Sky) <https://news.sky.com/story/starmer-bolsters-business-team-with-hiring-of-evercore-banker-13500997>
Barclays wants to grow securitized products. It just hired Chetan Vohra from Cerberus as global head of securitization, based in New York. (Businesswire) <https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20260129586173/en/Barclays-Appoints-Chetan-Vohra-as-Global-Head-of-Securitized-Products>
Jain Global hired Barclays director Jiujiu Xiong to its team of macro portfolio managers in Singapore. (Financial News) < https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/jain-global-hires-senior-barclays-trader-to-boost-macro-team-5c218fe5?mod=homepage>
ING hired Alexander Critien from JPMorgan as global head of rates and non-linear trading. He was just head of rates EMEA options trading at JPMorgan. (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/ing-hires-jpmorgans-critien-to-lead-rates-trading-de92e96a?mod=newswires>
Top hedge fund quant used agentic engineering tools to query a lifetime of Gmail emails. (WesMcKinney) <https://wesmckinney.com/blog/announcing-msgvault/>
China's "genius classes" which coach 100,000 gifted students a year to compete in international competitions in maths, physics, chemistry, biology and computer science are its secret source. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/68f60392-88bf-419c-96c7-c3d580ec9d97>
Viktoriia Honcharuk, a 25 year-old banking analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York is now a combat medic in Ukraine. “I was afraid of blood, I was afraid of needles, I’ve never done anything medical before, but I was like, ‘That’s what I need to do.'” (New York Post) <https://nypost.com/2026/01/30/lifestyle/morgan-stanley-analyst-victoriia-honcharuk-why-i-left-nyc-to-fight-for-ukraine/>

item.title: Deutsche Bank's new Citi MDs have little in common
item.description:
Deutsche Bank is no longer in full scale expansion mode. But nor has it sworn-off hiring entirely. At last year's investor day, it proclaimed its intention of hiring </news/deutsche-bank-gently-trimmed-45-people-in-q4-while-hiking-pay> bankers to cover "industrials, FIG, healthcare and tech," while also increasing its presence in US flow credit trading and US securitized products.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
One month into 2026, there are signs that Deutsche is indeed making senior hires, but not in any of these areas.
In New York, the German bank has recruited two managing directors from Citi, one to cover structured rates products, and one to handle regulation.
Andrew Sufka joined DB this month as head of US rates risk management solutions. He previously spent 11 years at Citi, latterly in corporate derivatives.
Rosalie Yee also joined DB this month from Citi, as head of US bank regulatory legal. Yee previously occupied a similar role at Citi, where she worked for nearly three years.
Deutsche Bank declined to comment on Sufka's arrival. Coincidentally or not, Pedro Goldbaum, </news/pedro-goldbaum-deutsche-bank> Deutsche's head of rates trading, also worked for Citi not so long ago.
Yee seems a fine fit for Deutsche Bank. Both Deutsche and Citi have had brushes with US regulators. DB was fined $186m <https://www.ft.com/content/c8ca8f31-b090-49f2-8a67-6467deed8b03> in 2023 for problems with its US controls. Citi was fined $400m in 2020 for deficiencies in internal controls, followed by $136m in 2024 for failing to fix them. <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/us-bank-regulators-fine-citi-136-million-failing-address-longstanding-data-2024-07-10/> Speaking a few weeks ago, Citi CEO Jane Fraser said the bank is closely to attaining its "target" state in the wake of these fines.

item.title: Hedge fund Brevan Howard's agentic AI spin off seems to have disappeared
item.description:
What if there were a platform, spun out of a leading hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job>, offering 'multi-agent generative investment copilots (MAGIC) </news/brevan-howard-s-ai-spinoff-is-using-ll-ms-to-turn-analysts-into-quants>,' to help with the investment process? If successful, it might put some hedge fund professionals out of a job.
Fortunately, then, there may not be.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
SigTech, the multigenerative AI platform that spun out of Brevan Howard in 2019 as a 'next generation quant </news/quant-jobs-finance>platform,' seems to have been relegated to the last generation withouth anyone noticing. Its website <https://www.sigtech.com/>is no longer functioning and a Companies House <https://find-and-update.company-information.service.gov.uk/company/11686070/filing-history>filing shows that founder and CEO Bin Ren was terminated as an employee in late December.
We haven't spoken to Bin Ren for this article and Brevan Howard declined to comment.
SigTech debuted its MAGIC product at Bloomberg Invest in 2025, boasting <https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/sigtech-magic-now-available-microsoft-teams-store-appsource-ocype/?trackingId=ZWzg4SZLCsVQl8i8MVY2XQ%3D%3D> that it could solve "domain specific problems" across macro research, equities fundamental analysis, and commercial loan underwriting. MAGIC was powered by "AI agents" based on "a carefully chosen Large Language Model," said SigTech. Those agents could accomplish tasks autonomously.
It's possible, then, that SigTech's agents might still be out there somewhere, solving problems. Bin Ren may have moved on to better things. A self-confessed child prodigy, Ren's LinkedIn profile says he was previously chief investment officer of Brevan Howard's Systematic Investments Group, before founding Elwood Technologies to manage crypto investments for Brevan Howard in 2018. Only then did he go agentic.
It's not clear what happened to SigTech's other people. Speaking in 2021, Ren said SigTech employed 50 people.
The revelation that SigTech may have vanished comes as Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-02/tekmerion-spins-out-of-brevan-howard-with-1-billion-hedge-fund?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260202&utm_campaign=author_19458291> is reporting that Tekmerion Capital Management is spinning out of Brevan Howard less than two years after joining. The data-driven hybrid systematic macro fund will be partnering with Engineer's Gate for infrastructure support and capital instead.

item.title: Goldman Sachs engineering pay: What you'll earn from analyst to VP
item.description:
Last week, we looked at how much software engineers earned at JPMorgan. </news/tech-pay-jpmorgan-software-engineer> Data from Levels.fyi <https://levels.fyi> suggests it's more lucrative to work at Goldman Sachs </news/how-to-get-a-job-goldman-sachs> instead.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Based on over 650 Levels.fyi datapoints from Goldman Sachs engineers </news/goldman-sachs-tech-fellows> in the US, UK and India since the start of 2025, we've found out the average engineering pay at each seniority of the bank in those regions. Goldman engineers outearned JPMorgan at each seniority in each location.
Engineering analysts at Goldman in the US earn ~15% more on average than those at JPMorgan, while engineers in Goldman's global capacity centre (GCC) </news/h1b-visa-investment-banking-jos> in India earn almost 40% more than JPMorgan's Indian analysts. As you progress up the ranks, the disparity between the banks narrows.
It's worth noting, however, that Goldman's VP class on Levels,fyi includes executive directors while EDs are broken out as their own class at JPMorgan.
What kinds of engineers earn the most at Goldman Sachs?
While JPMorgan's engineers had a lot of variation depending on what field they worked, pay is much more uniform at Goldman. Still, some types of engineers are better paid than others.
While full-stack engineers </news/2021/05/goldman-sachs-tech-stack> were some of the lowest paid technologists at JPMorgan, the opposite is true at Goldman. They earn $127.7k on average, more than any other major engineering type.
AI engineers came in second, earning $123.7k on average, but this pales in comparison to JPMorgan, where they earn over $200k.

item.title: Hedge fund Millennium hired a Goldman Sachs MD to expand its data centres team
item.description:
Millennium, the multistrategy hedge fund </news/big-multistrategy-hedge-funds>, has hired a managing director from Goldman Sachs </news/how-to-get-a-job-goldman-sachs> and he is now expanding the fund's data centres team.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Christian Blanc, who spent over six years at Goldman in London after time at Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan, joined Millennium this month as the London-based deputy head of networks and data centres. In this role, Blanc is already hiring a new engineer for the fund's two London data centres, which provide power, cabling and security for Millennium's multiple London office technology rooms.
Millennium declined to comment on Blanc's arrival. At Goldman Sachs, he latterly worked on the Foundational Infrastructure team under partner Orla Dunne.
Data centres everywhere are being upgraded to support the AI boom. Goldman Sachs <https://www.goldmansachs.com/insights/articles/how-ai-is-transforming-data-centers-and-ramping-up-power-demand>forecast last year that AI will account for 28% of the data centre market by the end of 2026.
Millennium has a global head of AI in the form of Gideon Mann, who joined from Bloomberg in 2023. It also has a head of AI for equities in the form of Mike Purewal, who joined from BofA the same year. In total, the firm currently has over 20 vacancies for which AI is an integral part of the role. Among other things, it's building an AI research agent.
AI needs data centres but it also needs data. In December, Millennium also hired Alexei Dvoretskii from Radix Trading as head of high speed historic market data and simulation. Dvoretskii once did a similar job at Tower Research.
In a separate incident of infrastructure hiring, Bob Van Zant, who was a principal software engineer at Citadel before disappearing on gardening leave in early 2025, has just reappeared at Balyasny as an infrastructure manager working with on-premises cloud.

item.title: "The morning I almost died on Wall Street"
item.description:
Monday morning. 10am. Thirty minutes after the stock market opening bell.
I am pulled out of an intense bout of concentration by a hard slap on my back from my boss.
"Pull your trades and get the hell out of the building.”
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Those were the words that were spoken, but all I heard was the sheer expression of horror dominating his face.
Inaction. Paralysis.
For what felt like an eternity, but must have been no more than a fraction of a second.
Then a dead sprint to the stairwell. If everyone else was running, I was going to run too.
Terrorist attack? Fire? Had our entire division just been dissolved?
Rationality was impossible. Instinct was unavoidable.
The stairwell is at first eerily quiet. More than a hundred of the world’s most intelligent, resourceful, inventive individuals, completely out of their element. An army of “I got this” personalities who don’t got this. Directors without direction. Controllers without control. Risk managers </news/risk-job-investment-bank>facing actual risk.
The effect is crippling, but the descent commences.
Floor 47. 46. 45.
No one is going fast enough.
Then the whispers begin.
Airplane. Something about an airplane.
Really, airplane? Shouldn’t we already be dead if an airplane had hit the building? But then again, it took the towers some time to fall. So maybe this is a race against time. Maybe the building is already on its way down and we have to beat it there.
The pregnant woman in front of me is not going fast enough.
The stairwell is too crowded to pass, and no one wants to be that guy forcing his way past a pregnant woman during a mass evacuation. I briefly consider asking if she would like help, imagining that a survivor might later tell the heroic tale of how I went down with honor.
Then I wonder if it might be useful to have an HOV lane.
With maximum speed unattainable, natural instinct takes over again and the multitasking begins.
The BlackBerrys emerge in force.
No one makes a phone call, unwilling to translate confused emotions into audible words, but the just-in-case “I love you” text messages must have been ubiquitous. I manage to send one before shouts of “get off the freakin’ BlackBerrys” cause me to slip mine back into my pocket.
They were right. My father would have been pleased to hear from me in my final moments, but he would have been even more pleased if these were not my final moments.
It doesn’t matter though. No one is going fast enough.
Floor 39. 38.
“Twenty five percent of the way there.”
Even in the face of death, long division is not a problem for PhDs in economics. The triathletes begin to get frustrated with the mathletes.
Floor 23. 22.
Calves burning. Moans of fatigue and fear.
I search for a familiar face.
“How you doing?” he asks
I want to tell him how my brain has accepted death, but my mind still believes in my invincibility. All I manage is a weak “alright,” which comes out as “right,” my voice cracking on the first syllable.
Floor 10. 9.
The end is in sight. Maybe I will make it after all.
But how does one go back from death to life? And now my mysterious text messages are going to cause some unnecessary concern. I better call as soon as I get down to let everyone know that everything is fine.
With one final burst, we spill out of the stairwell, into the lobby, and through the front door.
Oxygen. Daylight.
No screams. No blood. No debris.
I look up. The building is still standing.
Just chaos on the street. Feverish phone calls, text messages, and emails as people declare their “alrightness” and try to figure out what happened.
Then the email from corporate headquarters.
Air Force One, followed closely by an F-16 fighter jet, had flown just a little too close to our building during a photo shoot.
A photo shoot?
No apology. No explanation. Just the information, delivered with the calm neutrality normally reserved for system maintenance alerts.
It better have been a damn good photograph.
Michael Sloyer <https://www.linkedin.com/in/michael-sloyer-6162699/> is a leadership development coach at Upbuild and a former Managing Director at Goldman Sachs. Find out more information about his work at www.upbuild.com <http://www.upbuild.com/>. item.title: Morning Coffee: The bank that cut 25% of its MDs is ready to compete with JPMorgan. The 20 private equity firms you may not want to work for
item.description:
The last time that Michael Roberts </news/hsbc-is-increasingly-run-by-people-who-ve-joined-from-citi>, the ex-Citi corporate banker running HSBC's corporate and investment bank, suggested his new home is becoming superior to Wall Street banks, it didn't land well internally. </news/hsbc-townhall-emojis>Undeterred, Roberts is strumming the same song.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
In the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/3329ee04-b5d5-4393-a00c-640d6358ef92>today, Roberts says HSBC's aim is to become the number one corporate and institutional bank (CIB) globally. HSBC, which has a $3.2trn balance sheet, can compete with JPMorgan, which has a $4trn balance sheet, says Roberts. Jamie Dimon beware.
Roberts spent 33 years at Citi before joining HSBC in 2019. At Citi, he was a lending officer and global head of corporate banking. At HSBC, Roberts' focus is the areas he knows - he says the bank can compete most vigorously with JPMorgan in payments and transaction services. “We’re not a big investment bank," he declares. "We are a 99 per cent corporate commercial bank." JPMorgan is both.
HSBC combined its corporate and institutional banks in late 2024 and then shrank its investment bank this time last year. </news/hscb-closure-europe-us-job-cuts>The unexpected closure of the M&A and ECM businesses outside of Asia and the Middle East was seen by some insiders as brutal </news/hsbc-job-cuts>. Quoting unnamed sources, the FT says it resulted in 25% of HSBC's CIB managing directors (MDs) being cut.
Like HSBC's CEO Georges Elhedery </news/hsbc-s-self-proclaimed-ruthless-ceo-is-not-its-most-feared-person>, Roberts is unapologetic. There were "a lot of double roles, a lot of duplication, a lot of inefficiencies," he tells the FT. There was "excess cost," "excess people." Last June, </news/hsbc-bankers-pay> an unnamed senior executive at HSBC told the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/61e8d4e1-e49b-4048-9998-d33ac5f87d8e>HSBC had been paying many MDs seven figures for doing nothing much.
As Roberts reshapes the bank, his deputy Gerry Keefe </news/hsbc-s-self-proclaimed-ruthless-ceo-is-not-its-most-feared-person> has become known internally as his henchman. Roberts admits to finding it "frustrating" that some people are still not on the bank's combined CIB bus. As he seeks to make the bank a debt powerhouse, he still needs debt capital markets bankers to originate, package and distribute its loans. Last year, HSBC's DCM bankers were grumbling </news/hsbc-retention-bonuses> about poor pay. Several have since left of their own accords. </news/hsbc-s-dcm-people-are-slipping-away-before-bonuses-are-paid> If HSBC wants to be the top CIB, maybe their bonuses will be bigger this year.
Separately, as private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity>firms struggle with exits that don't involve their own secondary funds, Forbes <https://www.forbes.com/sites/hanktucker/2026/01/29/why-private-equity-is-suddenly-awash-with-zombie-firms/> has assembled a helpful list of 20 zombies that you possibly don't want to work for now.
We are not listing the zombies, some of whom already appear to be objecting to that designation but you can see them all here. <https://www.forbes.com/sites/hanktucker/2026/01/29/why-private-equity-is-suddenly-awash-with-zombie-firms/>Many seem to be busy raising continuation funds to buy their previous funds containing investments they haven't been able to exit.
“If you had two good funds and then a bad fund, you have some hope. You’ve got to convince people that the next fund will be better,” declares Steven Kaplan, who specialises in private equity at University of Chicago. “If you’ve had two bad funds, you’re probably out of luck.”
Meanwhile...
Newly released Epstein files show that Apollo Global Management executives including chief Marc Rowan </news/marc-rowan> held wide-ranging discussions over the firm’s tax arrangements with Jeffrey Epstein throughout the 2010s. (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/092d9e44-ec17-4da7-8b58-e43bf09113ab>
Apollo Commercial Real Estate Finance sold a $9bn loan portfolio that had traded at 77% of book value to Athene, its insurance arm, at 100% book value. (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/b2f8b3f6-257e-4a48-909c-673d31b9bb48?shareType=nongift>
New Holland Capital is a $7bn hedge fund that aspires to have eight to 10 equity sector specialists with no overlapping strategies. It considers itself an alternative to the multistrategy model. “I like to say it’s the ‘carousel of love’ — I went to Citadel, I went to Millennium — and that pretty much encompasses my view of pod exhaustion." (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-30/new-holland-starts-hedge-fund-for-traders-tired-of-multistrats?utm_source=website&utm_medium=share&utm_campaign=twitter>
Kevin Warsh wrote last year that reductions in the benchmark Fed funds rate should be offset by tighter money on Wall Street. (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/167c5c6b-97de-41da-911f-4f4f8193e620>
Remembering Scott Bessent's college days: "I went from computer science to art history and finally landed on political science, but if I were able to do it all over again, I would choose to double major in psychology and philosophy." (YaleAlumniMagazine) <https://yalealumnimagazine.org/articles/4159-scott-bessent?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email>
The Bank of England is cutting jobs and shifting employees to Leeds where it has 100 people currently and wants 500 by next year. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-30/even-the-bank-of-england-is-struggling-to-make-ends-meet>
33% of students in the UK get first class degrees now. (The Times) <https://www.thetimes.com/uk/education/article/one-in-three-students-graduate-first-class-degree-8mpcb3t9l>
Raman Bhatia, the boss of Starling Bank, made people return to the office four days a week. There were complaints that this was creating a “bland grey corporate hellscape filled with dead-eyed zombies” but Bhatia says only four or five of his 3,800 employees left for this reason. (The Times) <https://www.thetimes.com/business/companies-markets/article/starling-ceo-raman-bhatia-interview-jtgcwj08l>
Investment firm Architect Capital is buying a 60% stake in Only Fans at a $3.5bn valuation. (WSJ) <https://www.wsj.com/business/deals/onlyfans-in-talks-to-sell-majority-stake-to-investment-firm-61f9971f>
When an AI emails to apply for a job. (Marginal Revolution) <https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2026/02/those-new-service-sector-jobs-from-my-email-just-now.html>

item.title: "I am a female banker in Asia. People don't discuss sexism enough here"
item.description:
I am a female banker working in the Asian markets. Whenever I hear of people discussing sexist attitudes in banking, </news/some-female-citi-m-ds-created-a-site-to-share-women-s-banking-horror-stories> it is in relation to London or New York. What people don't understand is that it can be even worse in Asia.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Male bankers in Asia often think they have a right to treat young females however they like. If you try to object to this, they can make your life very difficult indeed. The men have all the power here and in my experience the senior women will not help you. There are usually only one or two women on teams of 15 people and those women feel very exposed. They close ranks and side with the men.
Wrongdoing is never discussed because when women leave banks where they've been mistreated, they always sign NDAs. These are often accompanied by packages which are big enough to persuade them to go quietly, but small compared to the amounts that the senior men are paid.
I've tried to speak out about the sexism I've experienced and it has made my life very difficult and been damaging to my career. I've had no messages of support from the other women who are very aware of my situation. I'm struggling and I would like to urge other women to take a stand when they see things they disagree with. Today it's me, tomorrow it could be you!
Tang Shuren is a pseudonym

item.title: UBS markets bonuses were fine, especially on the desk that lost 9 people
item.description:
Yesterday was UBS bonus day </news/ubs-bonuses-are-this-thursday-there-are-comings-and-goings-before-they-re-announced>. The early verdict seems to be that things weren't too bad, especially in the Swiss bank's markets business, where revenues rose 24% year-on-year. However, things seem to have been best of all on one London trading desk, which lost many of its people in 2025.
Insiders point to intense churn on Swiss bank's London rates desk. In the past year, at least nine people have left. Bonuses allocated to remaining staff on the desk are thought to be good.
We reported some, but not all, of the exits earlier this week. </news/ubs-bonuses-are-this-thursday-there-are-comings-and-goings-before-they-re-announced> We now know that they also included Kyriakos Manolis, a senior USD swaps trader, who joined from Citadel in June and is said to have left UBS again in December. The FCA Register says he is still technically employed by the bank.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
The other exits are: Dipo Abiola, who left in December to become head of UK insurance sales at UBS; Samuel Seyoum, a rates sales associate who left for Santander in June; Ali Sanai, </news/a-ubs-sales-head-left-for-citi-one-year-after-being-promoted-to-md>a rates sales MD who left for Citi in March; Mark Samarasinghe, a senior rates trader who left for Deutsche Bank in September; George Dramitinos, a London-based rates trader, who left late last year; Jason Colloupas, who was trading Australian rates in London; and Yilin Liu, another junior, who's going to Deutsche Bank.
Insiders say that many of those who left were hired by Mark Tinworth, who joined RBC last July. He was replaced by Shane O’Cuinn, who spent a long time running Credit Suisse's non-core unit. O'Cuinn recently hired Kilian Frensch </news/kilian-frensch> from Nomura.
Away from the rates desk, UBS insiders say M&A bonuses were fine, but for the juniors who are complaining. Across markets as a whole it's thought there may have been a double digit rise.
UBS didn't respond to a request to comment. Like other banks, it pays for performance.

item.title: Kevin Warsh: The ex-Morgan Stanley VP with a wealthy wife
item.description:
President Trump is nominating Kevin Warsh as the new chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Warsh has many things to recommend him for the role and is already receiving plaudits from the people that matter. The FT <https://www.ft.com/content/2030acc1-4026-4ad1-81bc-12754389f71d> says ex-Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein rates him "unflappable" in a crisis and <https://www.ft.com/content/a08f1b78-4816-4ff1-819c-e67e59c8d767> that Jamie Dimon voiced their support.
Warsh has a storied CV. </news/the-absolutely-perfect-investment-banking-cv> As Trump noted on Truth Social, Warsh is a Harvard and Stanford graduate who once worked in M&A for Morgan Stanley and who then became the Fed's youngest governor ever at the age of 35.
As we reported in April, </news/kevin-warsh>Warsh worked for Morgan Stanley between 1995 and 2002. He became a vice president and executive director (ED) at the bank during the dot com boom.
In his post M&A existence, Warsh was on the board of governors of the Federal Reserve during the last financial crisis and helped counsel then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke. He's latterly been working in Stanley Druckenmiller's family office. <https://www.ft.com/content/4ec81de7-eb59-4be8-81db-bff657e6c5d3> As Trump observes, Warsh appears to be out of "central casting" for the role of Fed Chair.
Warsh also has a wealthy wife. As Bloomberg notes, Warsh is married <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-30/trump-picks-a-reinvented-kevin-warsh-to-lead-the-federal-reserve?srnd=homepage-americas&sref=vuYGislZ> to Jane Lauder, the daughter of makeup scion and Republican donor Ronald Lauder, who is a former classmate of Trump's and who donated $5m in March to MAGA Inc.
Forbes <https://www.forbes.com/profile/lauder/> says the Lauder family are worth nearly $26bn. Ronald was reportedly one of the first people to suggest to Trump <https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/15/ronald-lauder-billionaire-donor-donald-trump-ukraine-greenland> over six years ago that he buy Greenland.
Trump said today that he has known Lauder for a "long period of time" and that he will be a "GREAT Fed chairman, maybe the best."

item.title: At Morgan Stanley, some operations professionals are still complaining about bonuses
item.description:
As we reported last week, </news/goldman-sachs-and-morgan-stanley-people-complain-of-poor-bonuses-away-from-the-front-office> while bonuses may have been mixed </news/at-bank-of-america-some-equities-traders-would-like-bigger-bonuses>for front office </news/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking> bankers and traders this year, they seem more unambiguously disappointing for the middle and back office staff whose jobs are most susceptible to being automated out of existence.
Morgan Stanley appears to be a case in point. The bank still isn't commenting, but US-based operations staff in its wealth management division remain aggrieved by a change to their compensation structure.
It's understood that the bank flagged a change to the wealth management operations compensation structure at the end of 2024, making the 2025 bonus round the guinea pig. Insiders claim they were told they would receive larger base salaries in return for a drop in their bonuses.
Instead, they claim that bonuses were cut while many of their salaries remained the same. To make matters worse, they say the new compensation structure has only been implemented at vice president level and below, with executive directors and managing directors still receiving bonuses.
"I've had to tell people in my team that they won't be getting a bonus or a salary increase because their salary is already considered at the top of the pay range," says one operations VP at the bank. "They have been baffled and stunned. We had a great year and these are top performers."
It may not only be Morgan Stanley where non-revenue generating staff are being squeezed. Insiders at Citi and Goldman Sachs have also complained about reduced bonuses in the middle and back office.
In the ideal world, banks would like people to leave voluntarily to avoid paying them severance. If so, AI may be around to take the strain. Lloyds' CEO Charlie Nunn <https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/29/lloyds-charlie-nunn-warns-bankers-reskill-themselves-impact-ai>said yesterday that the bank can now use AI to process complaints in one second instead of five minutes. And Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan said earlier this month </news/banking-recruitment-s-sorry-story-more-candidates-fewer-jobs> that the bank " has built a capability" involving a "series of prompts" enabling it to reduce headcount in the audit team.

item.title: Nomura's bankers and equities traders will deserve their bonuses this year. FICC less so
item.description:
While other, mainly American banks have released their Q4 and 2025 full-year results, Japanese bank Nomura has released <https://www.nomuraholdings.com/en/investor/summary/finance.html> its Q3 results, also for the quarter ending December 2025. They were pretty good – mostly.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
The happiest times were for Nomura’s investment bankers and equities traders. Across 2025 (the calendar year, not the financial year – Nomura’s financial year ends in March), revenue from the former was up by 6% on last year and the latter up by 22%. The equities result was particularly notable – the bank noted that its equities revenue reached a second consecutive record high. Banking revenue also reached an all-time high.
The bank credited the strong equities performance to “robust” performance in execution services and equity products. The strength of banking revenue came from strong equity capital markets </news/capital-markets-jobs-ecm-and-dcm> performance in Japan.
There was less good news for the firm’s fixed income traders. Full-year revenue for 2025 declined by 5% compared to 2024, mostly due to a fall in the first quarter of the year of 14%. At the time, the bank blamed the decline on a fall in its rates and credit businesses, but they didn’t make up the shortfall across the rest of the year. All eyes on Q4.
Luckily, Nomura’s bonuses have historically been paid </news/investment-banking-bonus-schedule-calendar> in May, which is after the end of their financial year in March. That painful quarter might be discarded in calculations.
Nomura’s results were overshadowed by an ugly loss in Europe, as well as compensation scheme costs related to acquiring Macquarie’s asset management business. Japan Times <https://www.japantimes.co.jp/business/2026/01/30/companies/nomura-profit-fall/> said that the firm’s crypto asset business also posted a loss, and noted that the firm had a crypto subsidiary in Switzerland. Hedging against FX also impacted that loss, the firm said.

item.title: Joining a fintech startup for the stock pay is a dead end unless you're an AI engineer
item.description:
Historically, the appeal of leaving your corporate career behind in favour of a startup was the potential equity. Early employees at fintechs </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-fintech>like Revolut </news/revolut-hiring-slows-down-average-pay> received company stock that became worth tens of millions </news/revolut-s-new-accounts-reveal-the-huge-pay-day-coming-to-some-employees> once their firms took off. If you join an early stage fintech today, it's a different story.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Accounting infrastructure firm Carta recently released a report <https://carta.com/data/resources/state-of-startups-2025/> that broke down the hiring and pay trends of startups using its platform. Unfortunately, the data only covers a period up to Q2'25, but it found that the average initial equity grant for employees joining a US-based startup in the month of June 2025 is 50% smaller than it was in April 2022. The average value of equity offers dropped starkly between November 2022 and September 2023, and have remained stagnant ever since. In that same time, salaries have increased but only marginally.
This is despite the fact that hiring for engineers, who typically earn higher equity packages, has increased. They made up 29.7% of new hires in H1 2025, up from ~25% in 2022. Operations staff made up just 5.2% of hires in 2025.
AI and machine learning engineers at startups are making more than ever. For the year ending June 2025, the average equity package for those technologists was up at least 19% across all seniorities. Senior directors received a 52% increase in equity pay alongside a 12.8% increase in salaries.
Hiring is stagnant across most industries, but fintech is ever-so-slightly growing. Total headcount in fintech grew by ~10% in 2025; by contrast headcount in gaming startups fell by 20% while education tech headcount fell by 40%
Fintech may be faring better outside the US. A recent report <https://www.morganmckinley.com/uk/article/finance-hiring-climbs-13-technology-and-fintech-drive-growth-across-uk> from recruitment firm Morgan McKinley found that fintech was the fastest growing sector in the UK's </news/top-london-fintechs> finance sector, with sale </news/sales-vs-engineering-jobs-fintech-startups>s roles up 47% year-on-year in 2025 and engineering roles up 71%. US fintechs have increasingly hired in London </news/london-is-the-new-cheap-location-for-new-york-fintechs-to-hire-engineers> in recent years, as you can pay up to 50% less for early/mid-level engineers.

item.title: Morning Coffee: Veteran banker sending 3am emails passed over for top job. Extreme prestige of the banking intern
item.description:
Rick Rieder, what a guy! In a hagiographic account of Rieder's ride from Wharton to Lehman to BlackRock, Fortune <https://fortune.com/2026/01/27/rick-rieder-fed-chair-race-2-3-trillion-polymarket-kalshi-bond-trading/> details the phenomenal work ethic of one of the many men who might have been chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Rieder doesn't seem to sleep much. There are suggestions that he stops emailing at 11pm and starts emailing at 3am. In a podcast <https://www.theinvestorspodcast.com/richer-wiser-happier/the-2-6-trillion-man-w-rick-rieder/> two years ago, Rieder said, “I hate the feeling of not being in control while sleeping.” A biometric ring monitoring his vitals reportedly revealed that his stress peaked at 11.30pm when he was forced to sleep despite Asian markets being opened. His stress was relieved at 3.45am, when he woke up and began trading again.
Despite being sleep-deprived, and plastering his house with signs declaring "Work hard, play hard, give back." Rieder is reportedly "magnetic" and known for his humility. He's attracted a troop of 42 followers, who follow him everywhere.
Fortunately, they will not need to pack their bags in the near future. Rieder, who is currently chief investment officer of global fixed income for BlackRock, is not becoming chairman of the Fed after all. The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/e227d99a-3144-465a-8108-209fb7d433cb> says Kevin Warsh, formerly the youngest Fed governor ever, will be nominated as the next chairman today. Maybe Rieder can go to bed early as a result.
Separately, if you're a second year student who has done a summer internship </news/finance/internship-investment-bank> at a leading investment bank </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-banking>or hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job>, you are briefly a person of extreme prestige and importance among your university peers, and ex-interns are absolutely making the most of this moment.
The FT <https://www.ft.com/content/4d1b3603-9d94-46d0-b70c-1dc28e5f7cc1> reports that second and third year students at elite schools who've previously completed prestigious internships are "throwing their weight around on campus" and acting as gatekeepers to elite finance societies that only a few can join.
Business Insider had a similar story </news/college-finance-clubs> last year, in which it noted that the inflated interns running the clubs were reducing would-be members to tears with aggressive questioning during their interview process. Queues of people want to join; only 10% are admitted.
If you make it into one of the special clubs, you will be at an advantage over your peers. At the University of Chicago, the FT says elite finance club members get to attend a six-week training program and then take an exam. It's very stressful, but it prepares you for applying to finance jobs and you have privileged access to the most prestigious students on campus.
Meanwhile...
Carried interest </news/private-equity-credit-pay> paid to Blackstone executives who profitably sold assets last year soared 15% to $1.1bn. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-29/blackstone-posts-surprise-profit-jump-as-deals-gain-velocity?taid=697b508a68c9b90001d1a205&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>
HSBC is “maniacally focused” on rebuilding its investment bank in Hong Kong. It “lost some people it shouldn’t have but that is normal.” (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/77686338-b041-4fd1-8612-7d1d097b8cb9>
JPMorgan wants more private bankers in France. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-28/jp-morgan-expand-paris-private-bankers-in-push-to-attract-wealthy>
Microsoft shares dropped and Meta's did not because Microsoft has to allocate limited Nvidia chips for both its internal AI development efforts and the external customers using its cloud-computing services for AI computing. (WSJ) <https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/meta-overshadows-microsoft-by-showing-ai-payoff-in-ad-business-39f392e0?mod=e2tw>
XTX traded 50% more European equities with clients last year. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-28/xtx-tops-ranking-for-bilateral-stock-trading-as-volumes-jump-50?sref=DK3y4h9>
Brevan Howard closed a fund run by star trader Fash Golchin and promoted him to run its Brevan Howard Master fund instead. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-28/brevan-to-shut-golchin-s-hedge-fund-as-focus-turns-to-main-fund>
Morgan Stanley banker Michael Grimes is leaving the US Commerce dept. (Semafor) <https://www.semafor.com/newsletter/01/29/2026/anthropic-robinhood-ceos-debate-ai-doomsdays?utm_source=headernewsletterlink&utm_medium=business>
Lloyds has been using AI to process complaints, which can now be categorised in one second rather than five minutes. It's also halved the time spent on coding. (Guardian) <https://www.theguardian.com/business/2026/jan/29/lloyds-charlie-nunn-warns-bankers-reskill-themselves-impact-ai>

item.title: At Bank of America, some equities traders would quite like bigger bonuses
item.description:
It was Bank of America bonus </news/bank-of-america-associates-got-their-bonuses-and-they-feel-nostalgic> day on Monday. Some of the bank's London equities EMEA equities professionals have since reached the conclusion that it was a poor start to the week.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Bank of America declined to comment for this article, but multiple equities professionals at the bank in EMEA said they were hoping for big bonuses and their hopes were not met.
It's possible that we spoke only to poor performers with unreasonable opinions of their own talents. Our pre-Christmas bonus expectations survey </news/bonus-expectations-by-bank> found that BofA people across all business areas were expecting bonuses to increase by an average of 60%. If so, they were destined for disappointment.
Nonetheless, the BofA equities traders and salespeople </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank> we spoke to today, insist their hopes were not unreasonable. "We smashed it last year," says one. "In EMEA we hit our budget for equities in September." This has not been verified by the bank.
Bank of America's global equities revenues rose by 23% in the last quarter of 2025 and by 16% during the year as a whole. This was good, but not great compared to the 33% and 28% full-year equities revenue increases at JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley respectively.
BofA's equities insiders say they were not, in fact, expecting a 60% increase in their bonuses and would have been happy with just 10-20%. Instead, many seem to have received increases substantially below this, with some middle and back office staff being zeroed. One EMEA quant said the average increase seemed to have been 2%.
Part of the problem appears to have been the unequal geographical distribution of revenues. US equities traders are thought to have done badly in the fourth quarter. Multiple insiders said European bonuses had been diverted to pay the US after the US subsidized EMEA bonuses in previous years.
Within equities, some areas did better than others from the bonus round. Structured products professionals and equity derivatives traders are thought to have been paid relatively well. Cash equities professionals are thought to have been paid badly.
Equity researchers </news/research-job-investment-bank>at the bank have also been voicing complaints. One said the research bonus pool appeared to have increased only by single digits in percentage terms and considered analysts under-compensated relative to workload. Even researchers covering "broader energy and energy infrastructure, clean energy and the energy transition, defense and aerospace, healthcare services," had been paid poorly, he claimed.
A London research headhunter confirmed he's had "a lot of incoming" from BofA equity analysts interested in new roles. However, he also said it was unsurprising that pay was poor given low IPOs in Europe last year. "I don't think they understand the dynamics of research," he observed.
