item.title: Ex-Barclays trader who quit to make NFTs won't get his job back. But it's okay
item.description:
Ovie Faruq was a good credit trader. He liked being a credit trader, even. But eventually the boredom of using only half of your brain got to him, and he quit for the world of non-fungible tokens (NFTs). That was in 2022.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
It’s now 2026, and the NFT world has collapsed, for lack of better term. From a peak market size of $1.6bn in 2022, research from CoinLedger <https://coinledger.io/research/how-much-is-the-nft-market-worth> last year suggested it’s barely a third of that now. Bloomberg reported <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/gemini-to-close-nft-marketplace-nifty-gateway-in-february?utm_source=website&utm_medium=share&utm_campaign=twitter> earlier this week that Cryptocurrency exchange Gemini was planning to close its NFT marketplace by March.
Faruq is unfazed. In the OFF SCRIPT podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KnPhB3d2R8c> yesterday, he said that his NFT style – Rekt guy – was launched during the NFT decline anyway. People could related to the Rekt Guy, because they were also Rekt guys. It was almost a metaphysical commentary.
Despite the NFT market being Rekt, Faruq has no interest in returning to the world of trading. "I could never go [back]”, he said. “If everything failed in my life and I needed to get a normal job, so to speak, I would do something different. I couldn't go back to it."
Despite leaving finance, Faruq has fond-ish memories of the experience. He told the OFF SCRIPT podcast that he loved the excitement of taking risks and credited the bank and his mentors there for teaching him a lot – and noted that he learned a lot about ethics, regulation, macroeconomics, and risk management.
Eventually however, the risk-aversion made him quit. “If something didn’t go well for you, people would be quick to say you need to cut your losses. And it would be frustrating if you turned out to be right further down the line.”
Still, it’s not all negative. Rekt is a whole brand now. We’ve mentioned </news/ovie-faruq> their energy drink offerings before, which once upon a time sold for £60 for a case of 12 – now only £47, but still. There’s also the Rekt Coin <https://rekt.com/pages/rekt-coin>, the brand’s own meme coin. It currently has a market cap of around $81m, with a total supply of 420.69 trillion coins.
If you’re curious to know how Faruq’s NFTs are doing, we found an artwork in 2022 of a self-portrait (of sorts) was on sale for $3.4k (USD). It’s now on sale <https://opensea.io/item/ethereum/0xc23a563a26afff06e945ace77173e1568f288ce5/3> for $212. Just for reference.

item.title: "The hedge fund I work for treats non-PMs as disposable assets"
item.description:
I work for one of the well-known hedge funds </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job>. I'm not going to disclose my function because I do not want to be traced. Since I have worked here, the number of people coming and going has been astonishing.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
It's common knowledge that hedge funds churn through portfolio managers </news/2023/09/portfolio-manager-job-hedge-fund>, who jump from fund to fund after drawdowns. To some extent, this is to be expected: portfolio managers are well paid </news/pay-for-equity-portfolio-managers-vs-equity-researchers-in-london>and if they make a loss it is their issue.
I am not a portfolio manager. Nor are people in my team paid that kind of money. And yet, the fund seems to think it's ok to hire and fire arbitrarily as we're earning seven figures.
This is a problem. I have seen people's careers being ruined. Signing up for a supporting role is not the same as signing up for a big pod. We don't get big bonuses and we are only as good as our last projects. Finding something new can be hard.
The fund doesn't seem to care about this. It just keeps hiring and letting people go and pay them money to go quietly. In my opinion, it's playing fast and loose with people's livelihoods.
It will be interesting to see what happens to this approach if the UK government changes the rules regarding unfair dismissal </news/unlimited-compensation-for-unfair-dismissal-bankers-uk>. For the moment, people are tapped on the shoulder, given a payment for their hurt feelings and asked to leave immediately. My understanding is that this won't be possible in the future and that a proper process will have to be followed. I know many people will welcome that. It's not worth taking a job if you're just going to be fired for no reason.
Roland Mace is a pseudonym

item.title: How European private equity & credit firms can still pay you €37m+ in 2026
item.description:
Private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity> has had a bit of a rough time of things recently, with exits plummeting and the favoured method of cashing out of investment recently being a game of hot potato </news/private-capital-advisory-jobs-investment-banking>. Private credit </news/2022/12/private-credit-jobs>, which has done better, is starting to face similar headwinds <https://www.ft.com/content/c071fa65-5517-4224-90c9-d73718165367>. But if things work out for the industry, however, there are still some huge pay packages on the table.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Data from recruitment consultancy Heidrick & Struggles suggests that top managing partners </news/private-equity-job-titles> at European private capital (including both private equity and credit) firms can earn compensation (salaries and bonuses) of up to €1.4m ($1.6m), as well as carried interest payments </news/what-is-carried-interest> of €37m ($44m), depending on the size of their employer – with bigger firms, known as megafunds, being more generous than smaller ones.
Heidrick says that slightly lower-tier partners, meanwhile, might expect salaries and bonuses of up to €957k ($1.1m) and carried interest payments of up to €24m ($29m). Principals, who are the equivalent of banking VPs or Directors </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds>, can expect compensation of up to €442k ($528k) and carried interest of up to €9m ($11m).
There is significant variation in carried interest payments depending on sector. Managing partners and regular partners working at buyout funds – “traditional” private equity – are the best paid, while those in venture capital are the worst paid (still millionaires, though).
Interestingly, despite the success of the private credit sector </news/2022/12/private-credit-jobs> in recent years, carried interest for its professionals is lacking. Carried interest paid to direct lending (the single largest component of private credit) partners and managing partners was significantly less than the carried interest paid to buyout partners and managing partners.
It’s worth noting two things. The first is that carried interest is not a yearly payment – it’s based on a fund’s lifecycle performance, which is usually round five years. It’s also dependent on a fund being successfully exited, which is something that private equity funds have struggled with in recent years. We go into more detail in our carried interest article here </news/what-is-carried-interest>.

item.title: Lazard had an unremarkable year, but raised pay a tiny bit anyway
item.description:
After boutique bank </news/boutique-investment-banks> Lazard published its Q2 results this year, we noted </news/lazard-presentation> that its presentation were remarkable stale in between quarters. Although this seems to have changed (slightly), nothing much else seems to have happened at Lazard in 2025 – its Q4 results were published today, and it seemed to have had a very average year.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
The average year was driven by average revenues. Total revenue increased by just 1%, from $3.14bn to $3.19bn. Those average revenues meant a drop in operating income for the bank, which fell by 15%, from $386m to $328m.
Pay, as a consequence, was pretty flat. The firm paid an average of $614k across 2024, and an average of $630k across 2025, an increase of less than 3%.
That can’t be blamed on substantial headcount increases, either. The firm’s wage bill increased by just 4%, and headcount barely budged, going from 3,263 people at the end of Q4 2024 to 3,309 at the end of Q4 2025, an increase of just 1.4%.
What might tie those two numbers is that a lot of the new hires would have been rather expensive: Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/lazard-doubles-md-hires-as-advisory-fees-hit-record-b6a2927b?mod=homepage> reported today that Lazard had hired "more than twice as many" MDs in 2025 as it did in 2024, when it hired 11. It also reported that the bank planned to hire 10-15 new MDs per year until 2030.
By its own account, Lazard is balancing its hiring appetite with its desire to save costs. “We focus on the adjusted compensation ratio to manage costs,” the firm said, “balancing a view of current conditions in the market for talent alongside our objective to drive long-term shareholder value,” related to Peter Orszag's Lazard 2030 strategy. Its managing of costs might have to wait for the future.
And, for what it’s worth, the number of Americans at the firm increased slightly: 53% of the firm's employees were based in the Americas across 2025, which was a return to form </news/lazard-q4-2024> after it spent a few quarters hiring Europeans. The percentage of employees based in APAC also declined, from 5% to 4%.

item.title: Standard Chartered hires private bank MD from Deutsche Bank in Dubai to run EMEA
item.description:
Deutsche Bank </news/deutsche-bank-gently-trimmed-45-people-in-q4-while-hiking-pay>'s private bank </news/private-banking-jobs-vs-investment-banking-jobs> had a great 2025, bringing in record revenues after a slight dip last year. Despite its success, a managing director running a global team of relationship managers has moved on.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Dhanajay Singh Rathore has joined Standard Chartered in Dubai </news/work-in-banking-cannot-retire> as an MD and cluster head for Europe, the Middle East and Africa. He spent four and a half years at Deutsche Bank, also in Dubai, where he was a private banking team head for the Middle East, Africa and South Asia.
Rathore also worked in the Middle Eastern private banks of Credit Suisse, Julius Baer and UBS. His early specialism was on high net-worth Indians working in the region.
Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing has high hopes for his private bank. He said today that it "has made tremendous progress with its transformation," achieving returns of over 10% in 2025.
Standard Chartered, meanwhile, spent much of last year growing its UAE private banking team. It hired the head of HSBC's Middle East private bank, <https://www.privatebankerinternational.com/news/standard-chartered-uae-private-banking-team/>as well as a senior MD from Julius Baer. <https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/standard-chartered-expands-uae-private-banking-team-2025-05-21/>CEO Bill Winters said late last year <https://www.thenationalnews.com/business/banking/2025/10/29/standard-chartered-bets-on-affluent-business-to-boost-middle-east-growth/> that 5% of the bank's AUM is from its UAE private bank, but that "could become 15 per cent or 20 per cent" in the next few years.

item.description:

item.title: Morning Coffee: Why Goldman Sachs' most desirable trader chose neither bank nor hedge fund. What if your 20s are your top earning years in finance?
item.description:
Goldman Sachs has some hot traders </news/top-goldman-traders>. The hottest among them now may be metals traders. With gold, silver and copper <https://www.goldmansachs.com/insights/articles/why-record-high-copper-prices-arent-forecast-to-last>prices all breaking records <https://www.ft.com/content/f12a38cb-bf19-4f1f-b09b-53fbc62dc159>, metals traders are particularly desired. - Citadel </news/2022/10/how-to-get-a-job-at-citadel> is building <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/citadel-joins-trading-rush-into-metals-as-prices-soar-to-records> a new metals trading business. Deutsche Bank <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-11-21/deutsche-bank-makes-gold-trading-comeback-with-bumper-earnings>returned to gold trading in November. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-10-26/gold-trader-hiring-spree-drives-up-pay-as-bullion-market-booms>reported in October that banks and hedge funds have been battling for precious metals traders and driving up their pay.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
In this context, it's worth noting at Goldman Sachs' head of precious metals trading, Benjamin Binet-Laisne has chosen to join commodities trading </news/commodities-trading-jobs-pay>firm Mercuria rather than a bank or a hedge fund </news/finance/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job>. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-28/goldman-s-former-head-of-precious-metals-set-to-join-mercuria?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260128&utm_campaign=author_22490032>reported Binet-Laisne's move yesterday.
He's not alone in selecting Mercuria as his preferred destination. Nick O'Kane, </news/nick-o-kane-macquarie-mercuria> Macquarie's top commodities trader also went there in 2024.
What makes Mercuria so alluring? The appeal might be related to its combination of high profitability and low level of employees. The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/4ad46815-da46-496f-bc8f-ca6e673aec3b> reported earlier this month that Mercuria generated $1.3bn in profits for 2025. The firm employs circa 1,300 people, implying profits of $1m per head. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-01-10/mercuria-s-top-duo-shared-1-billion-payday-amid-energy-crisis> reported a few weeks ago that Mercuria's co-CEOs, Marco Dunand and President Daniel Jaeggi, shared dividends of $1bn for 2023.
In this context, earning $47m as CEO of Goldman Sachs </news/david-solomon-goldman-sachs-pay> doesn't look as impressive. Citadel's pay </news/pay-at-hedge-fund-citadel-in-london-500k-to-21mm>seems more appealing, particularly in the commodities team </news/citadel-hedge-fund-bonuses>, but Binet-Laisne obviously liked the look of Mercuria more.
Separately, Instagram personality High Yield Harry <https://www.instagram.com/highyield.harry/?hl=en>has been telling some hard truths on X. <https://x.com/HighyieldHarry/status/2016266554149629984?s=20> "I think a lot of folks need to remember that your mid-20s to late 30s might be peak earnings years," he warns. "You should be saving a lot of money and compounding. If you get bounced from a seat, you might not get a new one."
Harry was referring to buy-side jobs at credit funds, where he says portfolio manager seats are limited compared to analyst jobs and therefore "you need to have high conviction that you’ll be a PM one day." However, a similar dynamic is coming to banking, where juniors in M&A tell us they're competing to make VP before AI automates roles out of existence.
Meanwhile...
State Street is creating 300 operations jobs in Abu Dhabi. (Bloomberg) <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/state-street-to-create-300-jobs-with-new-middle-east-operations-hub-8c2e4779>
Umesh Subramanian is stepping down as Citadel CTO after seven years and doing a non-technology role internally. Andrew Janian is returning as interim CTO after leaving in May 2025. (Business Insider) <https://www.businessinsider.com/citadel-umesh-subramanian-chief-tech-officer-steps-down-2026-1>
Deutsche Bank made two hires in emerging credit trading. Thomas Fitzpatrick, joined from Mizuho Securities. Christopher Staudt joined from HSBC. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-28/deutsche-bank-deepens-emerging-market-rebuild-adds-two-traders?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260128&utm_campaign=author_23851719>
Santander hired Philip Lindop, Barclays’s global co-head of metals and mining dealmaking. (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/amp/articles/santander-taps-barclayss-lindop-to-head-metals-and-mining-dealmaking-453cf6b2>
The Netherlands has lifted its regulations restricting bonuses to one fifth of fixed pay. However, it will remain in place for senior material risk-takers. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/netherlands-set-to-scrap-bonus-caps-for-some-banking-fintech-staff>
KPMG's partners received an average of £880k for the 12 months to September 2025. This is the first time they've earned more than partners at PwC and EY for a decade. (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/17f0aada-30b2-46ef-84c2-dc563e22c486>
Cameron Bird, a veteran EY partner in infrastructure advisory, sent an email saying the firm has become 'dominated by a rigid, top-down culture.' (The Times) <https://www.thetimes.com/business/companies-markets/article/veteran-ey-partner-takes-parting-shot-at-autocratic-consultancy-cvs02xp9j>
Cannot stress how much of an advantage it is to be a normal, well adjusted, applicant for banking roles. I reviewed a resume that listed “olive oil” as an interest. That is not an interest. (X) <https://x.com/90daysliquidity/status/2016196998852919573?s=20>

item.title: Deutsche Bank gently trimmed 45 people in Q4, while hiking pay
item.description:
Deutsche Bank's fourth quarter results are out <https://investor-relations.db.com/files/documents/quarterly-results/2025/FDS-Q4-2025-29012026.pdf>and are not bad for all who work in its investment bank. Profits there were up 20% year-on-year last year. Revenues were up 9%. Headcount was up 3% in the front office </news/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking> and down by 1% in operations </news/operations-jobs-banking>, but pay was up 8%.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
It may therefore be concluded that Deutsche Bank will pay individuals in the investment bank more for 2025 than for 2024.
The German bank seems to indicate as much in the comments accompanying its results. Rising compensation costs in the fourth quarter were, "driven by higher accruals for performance related compensation", says CFO James Von Moltke.
In the case of Deutsche Bank, higher compensation costs are as much about salaries as bonuses. </news/deutsche-bank-bonuses-2025> While US banks like Citi </news/citi-salaries-london> are free of the EU bonus cap </news/bonus-cap> which limited bonuses to twice salaries in London (and continues to do so in the EU), as a German bank, Deutsche Bank is stuck with it.
To the extent that bonuses are higher at Deutsche this year, they may go to its FX and emerging markets traders, who are credited with driving a 7% fixed income trading revenue increase in the final quarter. By comparison, Deutsche's advisory (M&A) </news/get-a-job-in-ma> bankers saw revenues fall 9% year-on-year in Q4 and rise by only 1% for the year as a whole. This was the worst performance of any bank to report so far, and comes despite years of heavy senior banker hiring.
Deutsche wants to hire some more senior bankers in 2025. Speaking at November's investor day, </news/deutsche-bank-s-investor-day> head of the investment bank Fabrizio Campelli said the bank wants to increase its presence across "industrials, FIG, healthcare and tech," while also increasing its presence in US flow credit trading and US securitized products.
With this in mind, perhaps, Deutsche Bank reduced net front office headcount in its investment bank by 45 people in Q4. Even if bonuses are good this year, those people won't be getting any.
In 2026, Deutsche says it expects fixed income sales and trading revenues to remain steady, although the year is off to a good start. Banking revenues are supposed to grow "in line with strategy."

item.title: Citi's London MDs accepted lower salaries in return for faster vesting bonuses
item.description:
It's bonus </news/ubs-bonuses-are-this-thursday-there-are-comings-and-goings-before-they-re-announced> season in banks, but it is also salary season. At many banks, salary increases appear to have been marginal. At Citi in London, we understand that material risk-takers (MRTs) have been signing contracts that actually lower their salaries, but pay their bonuses sooner.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
The changes come after pre-Christmas complaints that the bank had a two tier compensation system </news/citi-s-london-bankers-and-traders-are-complaining-about-two-tier-pay> in which historic managing directors (MDs) received high salaries with limited bonus potential, whereas new MDs received lower salaries with higher bonus potential.
The high salaries paid to historic MDs at Citi reflected the requirements of the EU bonus cap, which restricted bonuses in London to 2x salaries. This was lifted </news/bonus-cap> for the current London bonus round, in which Citi said it might pay bonuses of up to 6x salaries instead. A subsequent loosening of the rules </news/banking-bonuses-london>also provided for London banks to relax deferral conditions for material risk takers, most of whom are MDs.
At Citi, insiders say the new lower MRT salaries are being accompanied by bonuses which vest within one year instead of four. MRTs must then wait another year for bonuses to be available, making the total deferral two years. In the past, they had to wait five years in total to receive a full bonus.
It's not clear how much lower Citi's new MRT salaries are. In 2024, the average MRT at Citi in London earned a salary of $594k and a bonus of $697k. </news/salaries-and-bonuses-goldman-sachs-jpmorgan-citi-baml-morgan-stanley> Other banks have been able to flex their fixed pay without changing salaries; they paid salaries plus allowances </news/london-bankers-bigger-bonuses-are-fraught-with-complexity>whereas Citi did not.
Below MRT level, Citi insiders say salary increases were haphazard, as were bonuses. One Citi insider told us he received no increase at all and a dramatically lower bonus. Another says his salary was up in double digits and that he was told this was to compensate for sub-inflation increases in previous years.
In investment banking, one Citi MD in London said Citi paid well for those who performed, but that this was dependent upon actual revenues generated rather than pipeline. He observed that many of the recent hires made by Vis Raghavan have joined at a global level, enabling them to be paid according to US norms.
If anyone deserves a larger bonus at Citi this year, it may be Jenny Mai, the bank's Hong Kong-based head of equity derivative sales. Mai wrote on LinkedIn that she increased PnL 900% last year.
Citi declined to comment on Mai's achievement. However, a spokesperson said the bank welcomes changes to remuneration rules for UK Material Risk Takers, including deferral requirements. "These changes allow us to better align our UK MRTs with Citi's broader compensation structure and will help keep our compensation competitive within the UK regulatory landscape," she added.

item.title: Jane Street crypto pioneer: "imposter syndrome quietly weighed on me for years"
item.description:
While the majority of Jane Street </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-jane-street>'s modern hires come from its expanding internship </news/this-is-what-it-takes-to-get-a-64k-jane-street-internship> and graduate </news/the-20-universities-jane-street-loves-most-for-its-quants-and-engineers> programs, some of its traders had far more unusual routes in. Thomas Uhm </news/2022/10/jane-street-trader-sets-out-crypto-roadmap>, joined the firm aged 30 and spent 22 years there before leaving last year; he recently reflected on his time there via X. <https://x.com/ThomasUhm/status/2008509689827377347?s=20>
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Uhm said he "often felt out of place" at Jane Street because he lacked the "background or skillset" of his colleagues </news/jane-street-s-traders-on-1-4m-have-fighter-pilot-eyes-high-pain-thresholds>. He spent his 20s pursuing a career as an actor in New York before joining Jane Street's New York office (initially as a clerk, according to a previous appearance on the FTX Podcast <https://youtu.be/y1WA4gbOZUE?si=3fDhP86YsWp4FDzY&t=463>). He said on that podcast that he spent most of his Jane Street career "surfing the wave" and taking interesting opportunities as they arose. One opportunity was joining Jane Street's London office as it was being built. Another was leading its initial push into crypto in 2017.
Since the collapse of FTX </news/2023/11/sam-bankman-fried-ftx-fallout>and demise of its Jane Street alumni founders </news/2023/10/jane-street-interview-process-sam-bankman-fried>, Jane Street has been less bullish on crypto. Uhm said on a podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uk6vxNNB9_c> last year that firm "had to scale back some of the digital asset business in Q2 2023;" he spent his last 18 months at the firm building out its exotic options business which was "very, very different to crypto." He left Jane Street to join the Jito Foundation, a non-profit supporting infrastructure on the Solana blockchain.
Despite his "imposter syndrome," Uhm said working at Jito helped him learn "that I’m more valuable than I realised, and, what's more, that others see me that way too." The firm describes itself as "extremely lean and relentlessly effective" in its singular current job opening.
Jane Street has been tentatively returning to crypto despite Uhm's departure. It reportedly tripled its crypto trading volumes in 2024 <https://www.theinformation.com/articles/jane-streets-crypto-trading-tripled-last-year>, and was seen hiring </news/jane-street-hired-an-infrastructure-head-from-a-crypto-firm-after-tripling-crypto-trading> from crypto infrastructure firms like Copper last year. It has also been investing in multiple crypto firms like the Kraken exchange <https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/hsg-jane-street-among-investors-krakens-september-fundraising-sources-say-2025-10-22/> and infrastructure firm Antithesis. <https://www.coindesk.com/business/2025/12/03/jane-street-leads-usd105m-funding-for-antithesis-a-testing-tool-used-by-ethereum-network>

item.title: Bankers frustrated with AI liken their jobs to manual labour
item.description:
Banks and other financial services firms are certainly eager to implement AI </news/how-to-get-a-banking-ai-job>, but it's easier said than done. At Bank of America, implementing NVIDIA </news/2023/05/nvidia-engineering-jobs-jpmorgan>'s AI enterprise software has been a struggle, according to leaked communications reported by Business Insider. <https://www.businessinsider.com/bank-of-america-nvidia-ai-internal-emails-2026-1>
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Speaking to NVIDIA executives at a conference late last year, Bank of America reportedly likened itself to a local car mechanic trying to operate a Formula 1 car (which, for reference, is not road legal). An NVIDIA spokesperson said that the deployment of the software has since been completed. BofA also reportedly said that its in-house staff lacked machine learning operations (MLOps) skills. Today, just six openings at Bank of America mention MLOps.
Elsewhere in finance, sentiment on AI is mixed. The recent release of Claude for Excel, for example, has faced criticism on X over hallucinations and inaccuracy </news/goldman-sachs-new-ai-trepidation-means-big-compliance-salaries-for-now>when performing complex tasks. Ex-Citadel portfolio manager Brett Caughran <https://www.linkedin.com/in/brettcaughran/details/experience/> said that the technology received poor feedback from his buy-side colleagues and is "still quite far from ready for the institutional use case of 3-statement financial modelling." Michael Yuan <https://x.com/myuan95/status/2016122243516919844?s=20>, an ex-Goldman banker turned AI startup founder, said the technology's approach is "fundamentally flawed" for banking and private equity use cases. An anonymous former hedge fund manager called Claude for Excel a "complete and utter mess." <https://x.com/TechFundies/status/2016214903644881314?s=20>
The evident flaws haven't stopped large enterprises from using AI to cut headcount. Just today, Amazon announced it was cutting 16,000 jobs today <https://www.reuters.com/legal/litigation/amazon-cuts-16000-jobs-globally-broader-restructuring-2026-01-28/> after its CEO said last year that AI would lead to automation-induced job losses. The layoffs were first revealed to staff from an email sent in error <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cx2ywzxlxnlo>; perhaps it was scheduled using AI. The technology has been cited by both Citi <https://fortune.com/2026/01/27/citigroup-ceo-jane-fraser-employees-trained-reinvent-themselves-with-ai-before-tech-changes-roles-forever/> and Goldman Sachs <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-10-14/goldman-sachs-tells-staff-it-plans-to-cut-more-jobs-this-year> when making job cuts in recent months
Bank of America's leaked communications suggest that there will be increased appetite for MLOps specialists in banking, perhaps supplanting traditional DevOps engineers <https://medium.com/nerd-for-tech/will-ai-replace-devops-engineers-2b0e23e8f588>. JPMorgan, for example, has ~50 current openings mentioning MLOps, mostly in London and New York. At the high end, a senior MLOps engineer in New York can earn a salary of $260k. However, one AI engineer speaking anonymously via our new forum, The Bubble <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/t/i-m-a-senior-technologist-who-specializes-in-ai-at-a-top-bank-in-america-ask-me-anything-about-ai-in-financial-services-and-i-will-answer-as-best-i-can/3768/23#:~:text=There%E2%80%99s%20enough%20free%20educational%20content%20where%20this%20is%20unnecessary%20to%20learn%20the%20material.%20However%2C%20for%20those%20hiring%20managers%20who%20arent%20able%20to%20discern%20skills%20and%20rely%20on%20accreditations%2C%20it%20could%20make%20a%20difference%20in%20whether%20you%20are%20considered%20for%20a%20role>, said that some hiring managers in banks "aren't able to discern [AI] skills and rely on accreditations."

item.title: Citadel's head of Asia long short equity left, but the fund has growth plans
item.description:
Change is afoot in Citadel's Asian equities business. Bloomberg reported yesterday that Sachin Kewalramani, the hedge fund's </news/finance/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> head of Asian fundamental equities, has disappeared. No reason was given for the exit and Citadel isn't commenting, but people familiar with the issue say Citadel parted ways with him. Kewalramani didn't respond to a request to elaborate, and it's not clear where he's going next.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter&_gl=1*1oihgn9*_up*MQ..*_ga*ODUwNjg2MDk5LjE3Njg0Njc0OTE.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3Njg0Njc0OTEkbzEkZzAkdDE3Njg0Njc0OTEkajYwJGwwJGgxMTgxOTg4NTM1>
Despite Kewalramani's vanishing, Citadel is positive about growth in Asia. Drew Gillanders, the man in London </news/citadel-hedge-fund-jobs-london> who runs international equities for the fund reportedly has hiring plans. Bloomberg says Citadel plans to allocate more capital to the business in Asia and that Gillanders has been spending time recruiting in the region.
If you would like to join Gillanders, he said last year that he likes to hire people with "intense curiosity about markets and performance drivers," and that when he interviews he likes to understand how people react during draw-downs.
Citadel built three equities teams in Singapore last year. 2025's hires included Ran Wei from Sylebra Capital, who appeared to run a TMT team. It's also added juniors like Griffith Goh, a former Balyasny </news/2023/10/balyasny-hedge-fund> gaming analyst whose LinkedIn profile says he joined in December.
Kewalramani once worked for Balyasny too. He was the fund's head of Asia for ten years until he was poached by Citadel in March 2021. Balyasny's Asia business is run by Archana Parekh </news/questions-over-role-of-balyasny-s-singapore-superstar-as-she-builds-the-equities-business>, who joined from Millennium in 2022. In 2024 she reportedly had her book trimmed in order to help Stephen Schurr, a senior equities PM at Balyasny with recruiting. Schurr left for Millennium last year. Balyasny might have space for Kewalramani to return.

item.title: Goldman Sachs hired an MD from hedge fund Point72 in its top Europe tech hub
item.description:
Goldman Sachs is big on hiring in Warsaw </news/2017/12/warsaw-banking-jobs>. According to the students union of GSH Warsaw, the city is home to Goldman's largest office in continental Europe <https://www.instagram.com/p/DTkPXRvjWMA/>. Goldman's latest major hire in the region came from one of the earliest adopters of Polish talent in the hedge fund space.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Maciej Wolański has joined Goldman, working on global banking and markets and engineering. He spent the last five years at Point72, where he was most recently the hedge fund's country head for Poland, taking over the role from Rafa Lopez Espinosa who left for Citadel <https://www.hedgeweek.com/citadel-appoints-point72s-lopez-espinosa-as-coo-for-global-equities-division/> last March.
Wolański held a number of senior roles at Point72, including head of technology for Poland, and head of middle/back office technology. He also previously spent three years at UBS in its Krakow office, working as head of technology for Poland as well as global head of AI and data platforms for investment banking technology.
Wolański is a Point72 Polish veteran. He joined the fund when it was first pushing into Warsaw and was one of the first 60 employees </news/2021/04/point72-warsaw> hired as part of a push to reach a headcount of 150 by 2021. Today, LinkedIn data suggests Point72 employs over 300 people in Poland while the fund's website says it has over 200 people. More hedge funds have since built offices in Poland, including Balyasny </news/another-hedge-fund-opened-a-warsaw-office-for-developer-hires> and Qube Research. </news/fast-growing-quant-fund-building-new-team-in-low-cost-tech-hub>
Polish offices, predominantly tech </news/how-to-get-a-technology-job-bank> and back office </news/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking> hubs, have been on the rise in recent years. Last year, </news/tech-jobs-finance-poland-warsaw>JPMorgan was accused of ousting London tech staff with poor bonuses to replace them with Polish engineers. This year, </news/cantor-fitzgerald-hiring-warsaw> brokerage firm Cantor Fitzgerald appears to have opened a new office in Warsaw.

item.title: Boutique bank MD takes fun new job at sovereign wealth fund
item.description:
Most financial services professionals would consider working at a boutique investment bank </news/boutique-investment-banks> as a managing director </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds> as the pinnacle of their career – but clearly not all of them.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Tom Bashwiner joined Mubadala Capital earlier this month to be an executive director in its strategic partnerships & acquisitions team, based in New York. He joined the private capital firm, a subsidiary of Mubadala Investment Company, from boutique bank Lazard, where he was a managing director and head of its corporate development team.
Bashwiner spent just two years at Lazard before leaving and had similarly brief stints in the Bank of America and Barclays FIG teams before that.
Leaving a high-paying bank like Lazard </news/lazard-q4-2024> for a less senior role at a sovereign wealth fund </news/2023/05/sovereign-wealth-funds> seems like a relatively risky career move, but it makes sense. Mubadala Capital, which accepts outsider money, has around $30bn in assets under management, and acts like a strikingly modern asset manager like Blackstone: Bloomberg noted last August <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2025-08-07/abu-dhabi-wealth-funds-face-pressure-to-offer-carried-interest-awards> that Mubadala Capital even pays some of its employees with carried interest </news/what-is-carried-interest>. And while Lazard pays well, it doesn’t pay carried interest levels of well.
Mabadala Capital is growing, too. Semafor reported yesterday <https://www.semafor.com/article/01/27/2026/mubadala-capital-raises-550m-for-debut-co-investment-fund> that the firm had raised a fresh $550m for its first co-investment fund, including from outside investors, far above its $400m target. It's preparing to launch a second co-investment fund as a consequence.

item.title: There have been some exits at SMBC and ANZ in Asia
item.description:
Chinese New Year is approaching but in Asia, at least, hiring is happening. As we reported last week </news/us-banks-are-big-on-asia-hiring-in-2026>, US banks have big plans for Asian markets this year. And last year, one recruiter says <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-02/asia-senior-investment-banker-hires-jump-60-survey-shows>senior investment banker hiring in APAC jumped 60%.
As moves commence, some banks in the region have been losing staff in their banking and markets businesses.
At SMBC, for example, we understand that Kyoko Murai, the head of loan origination for South and South East Asia, is no longer there. Similarly, Aaron Chow, a managing director and general manager for the loans business is on gardening leave.
At ANZ, we understand that Herr-Ling Yeo, the bank's head of Global FX and commodities, has left the bank after 15 years. He is thought to be exploring other opportunities. Stuart Smith, the head of commodities at the bank is also thought to be retiring, and G4 rates trader Ed Gibson quit several weeks ago.
SMBC and ANZ declined to comment.
SMBC has hired multiple people in Asia in recent years, after adding Carsten Stoehr from Credit Suisse as deputy head of APAC in 2024.
ANZ has lost various people from its credit trading business </news/anz-credit-traders-standard-chartered>, including exits to Standard Chartered. Last September, the bank admitted to engaging in "unconscionable conduct" when raising money for the federal government and paid a $240m fine.
Alongside Herr-Ling Yeo, ANZ's exits include Anshul Sidher <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-09-10/anz-global-markets-chief-steps-down-amid-bank-overhaul>, the global markets chief who stepped down in September. There is no implication that Yeo, Sidher, or the others who left were involved in wrongdoing, which involved a different area of the business. Instead, it's thought that recent exits might be more related to the expansion of hedge funds in Asia.

item.title: Morning Coffee: JPMorgan bankers under pressure as Citi hikes bonuses. Private credit's cracks
item.description:
These days, JPMorgan and Citi's investment banking teams are a bit like one big blended family. In the past year, the two banks have swapped all sorts </news/jp-morgan-s-latest-big-citi-hire-might-be-joined-by-more-after-bonuses> of people </news/jpmorgan-to-citi>. And now those people are under pressure to perform.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter&_gl=1*1oihgn9*_up*MQ..*_ga*ODUwNjg2MDk5LjE3Njg0Njc0OTE.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3Njg0Njc0OTEkbzEkZzAkdDE3Njg0Njc0OTEkajYwJGwwJGgxMTgxOTg4NTM1>
At JPMorgan, Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/jpmorgan-tells-its-m-a-bankers-do-more-to-close-the-goldman-gap> reports that bankers are being asked to work harder in 2026. Fourth quarter M&A revenues at JPMorgan fell by 2.5% while at Citi they were up 84%. Arch rival Goldman Sachs was top of the global M&A league tables for 2025. JPMorgan, was a lowly third behind Morgan Stanley. Citi was a lowlier fourth.
JPMorgan bankers are therefore being encouraged to put themselves about. Last year, JPMorgan hired 100 new managing directors (MDs). This year, the bank says its senior bankers begun the year by touring clients in Europe and the US. In a pep talk last week, JPMorgan's global heads of banking John Simmons and Filippo Gori told their people to work harder to win back market share.
2026 is therefore shaping up to be a battle for M&A </news/get-a-job-in-ma>revenues between all four top US banks, but that battle may be particularly intense between the incestuous parties of JPMorgan and Citi.
Citi's bankers have had their own pep talk </news/citi-jane-fraser-memo-layoffs>from CEO Jane Fraser, who started the year with a memo extolling them to be out there "competing for the full wallet, and not settling for a secondary role or missed opportunity." This follows previous pepping </news/vis-raghavan-citi-jpmorgan> from head of banking Vis Raghavan, who suggested in 2024 that Citi's bankers were lacking gumption.
As the race heats up and CEOs find themselves feted by bankers touting deals, Citi's people should at least be enthused by their bonuses for 2025. Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/citigroup-hikes-bonuses-for-london-dealmakers-by-up-to-15-1388b8ed?mod=topic_news>reports today that they've been paid up by 'up to 15%' and that some people got 20%. Others, however, got nothing. It's not clear where Citi's ex-JPMorgan people featured in this spread.
Separately, private credit </news/2022/12/private-credit-jobs> woes were a theme of late 2025, and now they're a theme of early 2026.
It emerged <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/apollo-took-loss-on-asset-backed-loan-deemed-protected> yesterday that Apollo has written down a portion of its $170m financing to Amazon aggregator Perch to zero. This comes after it also emerged <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-23/blackrock-private-debt-fund-expects-19-net-asset-value-cut?utm_source=website&utm_medium=share&utm_campaign=twitter?sref=R17xFhjo> after markets closed on Friday that a BlackRock private debt fund has cut the value of its assets by 19%. And it comes after the FT <https://www.ft.com/content/8d7a9c3d-8e1c-40be-915c-7118c4946468>reported that private credit investors have attempted to redeem 5% of shares from a $34bn Blue Owl fund.
While this is going on, the FT <https://www.ft.com/content/c071fa65-5517-4224-90c9-d73718165367?utm_sf_post_ref=660138487&utm_sf_cserv_ref=18949452> reports that private credit funds have been busy selling debt back to themselves. It cites Jefferies note observing there were $15bn of private credit continuation deals globally last year, up from almost $4bn in 2024.
"There’s loans sitting there, nobody knows what to do with them, and credit managers are not in a position to sell them,” one lawyer told the FT. This may not be the best time to get a job in the industry.
Meanwhile...
David Solomon said some densely worded things about hiring. “It’s probably a bit more constrained in 2026, we see opportunities for efficiency and we try to deploy those. Those efficiency opportunities give us more of an opportunity to invest in parts of our business where we can scale growth and some of that growth scales with additional headcount.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/goldman-s-solomon-sees-slower-trajectory-for-talent-growth?taid=3a34d6bb-b68d-4feb-8c12-4c212126f422&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>
Goldman Sachs says its risk appetite indicator hit 1.09 last week, the highest since 2021. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/goldman-says-market-most-risk-on-since-2021-on-global-growth?sref=vuYGislZ>
Citi would like to move the sexual harassment case </news/citi-andy-sieg-case> lodged by ex-managing director Julia Carreon to arbitration. It says Carreon sent Andy Sieg sycophantic messages like: “Thank you for recognising my talent, for putting me in the room, and for treating me with respect. You are truly one of the most exceptional people & leaders I’ve ever met. Your integrity is irreproachable.” (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/4e1b334a-688d-436e-b72b-49ad072843cb>
A former Citi MD pleaded guilty to drugging and sexually assaulting women as well as purchasing child pornography. Citi says: “We moved to terminate Mr. Smith immediately upon learning about law enforcement’s initial investigation, well before the allegations of this depraved behavior came to light.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/ex-citi-managing-director-pleads-guilty-in-rape-child-porn-case>
UBS wants to dismiss Tom Hayes' $400m case against it. It says he can't prove that UBS prosecuted him or initiated his prosecution” or “that UBS acted maliciously.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/ubs-asks-us-court-to-throw-hayes-400-million-libor-suit-out?taid=69789e042840fc000164d921&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>
DCM bankers need to get friendly with big tech. Morgan Stanley estimates that hyperscalers and adjacent companies will raise $400bn from the US high-grade market in 2026, up from $44bn in 2024. (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/8264122b-cb6b-4af5-85b8-3789c3ae3a78?utm_sf_cserv_ref=18949452&utm_sf_post_ref=660094826>
RIP NFTs. Gemini is closing Nifty Gateway its NFT marketplace whose trading volume totalled $1.58 billion, down 87% from the first three months of 2022. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/gemini-to-close-nft-marketplace-nifty-gateway-in-february?utm_source=website&utm_medium=share&utm_campaign=twitter>
Diego Megia hired Richard Hughes for his hedge fund Taula Capital. Hughes will be an economic advisor. He was previously head of the Office for Budgetary Responsibility </news/obr-releases-hedge-funds>, until the budget was accidentally released early. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/megia-s-hedge-fund-hires-ex-uk-budget-chair-hughes-as-adviser?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260127&utm_campaign=author_19458291>
Everyone wants to trade precious metals. Citadel hired Yan Adler to do it too. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-27/citadel-joins-trading-rush-into-metals-as-prices-soar-to-records>
Tech bros think it's about to become too late to make generational money, what with AI. (WSJ) <https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/why-the-tech-world-thinks-the-american-dream-is-dying-daf793dc?utm_sf_post_ref=660030667&mod=e2tw&utm_sf_cserv_ref=3108351>
A possibly apocryphal story about dating a banker. (DatingbyBlaine) <https://x.com/datingbyblaine/status/2015913768954286391?s=20>

item.title: The programming languages that will get you a banking job now
item.description:
Despite the looming threat of AI </news/how-to-get-a-banking-ai-job>, people who can code </news/python-interview-questions> are in high demand across banking. Some languages are much more popular than others.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
We've looked at job listings for 13 major investment banks to find which languages are most frequently requested. While we found Python </news/2021/08/python-for-banking-jobs>to be the most popular language across all areas of finance when we looked at this in September </news/programming-languages-for-a-career-in-finance>, it seems that major banks have a different favourite: SQL.
SQL is the de facto language in finance for data analysis and is used by multiple different types of role. Data scientists, quants, risk managers </news/2020/07/need-to-code-if-work-in-risk-management> and even investment bankers </news/data-science-investment-banking-internship> use it.
Behind it are Python and Java. Python is the most popular language in the world right now, and is used in all manner of functions, including data analysis and machine learning </news/python-ocaml-jane-street-ai>. Java is banks' historic favourite; jobs with that language more often involve working on legacy or back office technology </news/2021/10/java-17-banks>. There are some exceptionally high paying jobs for Java developers </news/2023/03/low-latency-java-developer> in finance, but they're predominantly found outside of banking, at hedge funds and trading firms.
It's notable that hiring for tech roles in India is greater than the US and UK combined </news/best-coding-language-for-banking-jobs-london-new-york>. Roughly half of all Java </news/2019/03/java-or-python-banking> roles in the banks we looked at are in the subcontinent.
C++ roles </news/finance/c-coding-language-problems>, which can often be some of the highest paying </news/low-latency-c> tech jobs, are proportionally high in Hong Kong and Singapore </news/best-university-for-banking-jobs-hong-kong-singapore>. While ~10% of global banking jobs are in C++, the language is mentioned in roughly a quarter of listings in these Asian cities.
Roughly 9% of tech candidates in our CV database claim C++ experience. The incidence of C++ jobs is therefore 1.2x times higher than the incidence of C++ candidates. C++ is an outlier compared to the likes of Python, SQL and Java which have huge candidate bases; almost 50% of candidates have SQL experience.
At all but two banks, Java roles made up 20% to 23% of total openings. More niche languages are less equally distributed.
For example, Q, </news/should-you-learn-the-obtuse-niche-language-paying-700k-in-finance>another high-paying niche language, is particularly popular at Goldman Sachs. It makes up 2.8% of job listings at the bank compared to just 1% at JPMorgan and 0.5% at HSBC.

item.title: The programming languages that will get you a banking job now
item.description:
Despite the looming threat of AI </news/how-to-get-a-banking-ai-job>, people who can code </news/python-interview-questions> are in high demand across banking. Some languages are much more popular than others.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
We've looked at job listings for 13 major investment banks to find which languages are most frequently requested. While we found Python </news/2021/08/python-for-banking-jobs>to be the most popular language across all areas of finance when we looked at this in September </news/programming-languages-for-a-career-in-finance>, it seems that major banks have a different favourite: SQL.
SQL is the de facto language in finance for data analysis and is used by multiple different types of role. Data scientists, quants, risk managers </news/2020/07/need-to-code-if-work-in-risk-management> and even investment bankers </news/data-science-investment-banking-internship> use it.
Behind it are Python and Java. Python is the most popular language in the world right now, and is used in all manner of functions, including data analysis and machine learning </news/python-ocaml-jane-street-ai>. Java is banks' historic favourite; jobs with that language more often involve working on legacy or back office technology </news/2021/10/java-17-banks>. There are some exceptionally high paying jobs for Java developers </news/2023/03/low-latency-java-developer> in finance, but they're predominantly found outside of banking, at hedge funds and trading firms.
It's notable that hiring for tech roles in India is greater than the US and UK combined </news/best-coding-language-for-banking-jobs-london-new-york>. Roughly half of all Java </news/2019/03/java-or-python-banking> roles in the banks we looked at are in the subcontinent.
C++ roles </news/finance/c-coding-language-problems>, which can often be some of the highest paying </news/low-latency-c> tech jobs, are proportionally high in Hong Kong and Singapore </news/best-university-for-banking-jobs-hong-kong-singapore>. While ~10% of global banking jobs are in C++, the language is mentioned in roughly a quarter of listings in these Asian cities.
Roughly 9% of tech candidates in our CV database claim C++ experience. The incidence of C++ jobs is therefore 1.2x times higher than the incidence of C++ candidates. C++ is an outlier compared to the likes of Python, SQL and Java which have huge candidate bases; almost 50% of candidates have SQL experience.
At all but two banks, Java roles made up 20% to 23% of total openings. More niche languages are less equally distributed.
For example, Q, </news/should-you-learn-the-obtuse-niche-language-paying-700k-in-finance>another high-paying niche language, is particularly popular at Goldman Sachs. It makes up 2.8% of job listings at the bank compared to just 1% at JPMorgan and 0.5% at HSBC.

item.title: Bank of America associates learned their bonuses and they feel nostalgic
item.description:
Bank of America announced its bonuses yesterday. They were moderately </news/bank-of-america-bonuses-are-out-they-may-be-moderately-good> good but if you're an associate </news/finance/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds-really> there, you might be inclined to think of the past.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter&_gl=1*1oihgn9*_up*MQ..*_ga*ODUwNjg2MDk5LjE3Njg0Njc0OTE.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3Njg0Njc0OTEkbzEkZzAkdDE3Njg0Njc0OTEkajYwJGwwJGgxMTgxOTg4NTM1>
Bank of America isn't commenting, but multiple associates in the investment bank tell us their bonuses were ok for last year, but were not the best. The disappointment is most acute when 2025 bonuses are juxtaposed with what associates were earning a few years ago.
"Top-ranked people got bonuses that were 75% of salaries," says one associate at the bank in London who purports to have canvassed colleagues. "A few years ago, it was more like 110%."
Another BofA associate in the investment bank in Europe says associate bonuses there this year vary between $25k and $120k and that sentiment is "mixed." "Expectations were strong after a strong year, but on balance it is ok," he says.
When combined with associate salaries of $160k, this year's bonuses mean BofA's top-performing associates are earning total compensation of $280k.
Their lack of excitement about this isn't just due to the historically diminished bonuses, but to deferrals. "75% of base is not very exciting once you take into account that 30% of the bonus is paid in stock vested over four years," says one associate.
Disgruntled people can always move. "There will be more jobs this year, the market is opening up," says one junior, hopefully. "Hiring will be slower because of AI, but banks still need to train future MDs," he also adds.
Logan Naidu, CEO of Kernel Global says early indications are that this was a down round for associate bonuses in the UK. In the US, though, bonuses across the market seem to be higher. Meridith Dennes at New York search firm Prospect Rock Partners says bonuses there are up 28% to 42% this year.
As a result, Dennes says associates two and three in the US are earning between $333k and $380k (2) and $370k and $418k (3).

item.title: What is carried interest? (And why do you want it?)
item.description:
For a long time, the big appeal to working in private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity> was the prospect of a big carried interest payout. But what exactly is carried interest? Why does everyone want it? And does it still exist?
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
The simple version is that carried interest is a percentage of a successfully exited private equity deal paid out to the people in the private equity firm who worked on it.
However, there's a more complicated version too.
Private equity firms go into deals with outside investors. In those deals, the passive investors – pension funds and ultra-high net worth individuals and the likes – are known as Limited Partners (LPs), and the private equity funds are known as General Partners (GPs).
GPs, after raising money from LPs, go shopping with the money they’ve raised. They identify a good potential target company which is private and purchase it. They spend a few years “improving” it (this is contentious, but a story for another time) and then sell it again, either to the public markets </news/capital-markets-jobs-ecm-and-dcm> via an IPO or to another company that is looking to expand as a bolt-on M&A deal </news/what-are-ma-jobs>.
Once the deal is exited, the private equity firm has (hopefully) made a profit. Before it began the deal, it negotiated a benchmark, known as a hurdle rate, with its LPs. This hurdle rate is a rate of return at which the GP can actually begin to pay itself – everything below that belongs to the LPs.
Once the hurdle rate (usually around 7%) – is hit in a deal, a GP begins to allocate payments in the form of carried interest to the staff that worked on it. Depending on seniority, this can hit some mind-boggling figures – recruitment consultancy One Search </news/private-equity-pay-london> said last year that London-based PE partners can take up more than 10% of a carried interest fee pool after a successful deal, cashing out more than $25m in personal compensation. Even VPs on the deal can expect 2-4% of the pool and earn more than $1m in compensation. Heidrick & Struggles noted <https://www.heidrick.com/-/media/heidrickcom/publications-and-reports/2025-europe-private-capital-compensation-survey.pdf?rev=a5fa543d2f0b4da99b5e5385a83e37c1> last month that carried interest could still accumulate to €32m ($38m) for managing partners at the biggest firms, while even principals (VP/Director equivalents </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds>) could expect between €1.1m ($1.4m) and €5.2m ($6.3m) in carried interest depending on fund size.
On top of the huge pay packages, carried interested has usually enjoyed a favourable tax regime compared to other compensation methods. In the USA, it's taxed at capital gains rates (up to 20%) as opposed to income rates (up to 37%). The UK has enjoyed a similarly beneficial tax rate (up to 28%) which is due to end in April this year, when the tax rate will go up to 34%.
So, what’s the problem?
Private equity (PE) as an industry has not been doing well recently. Higher interest rates mean funds are not as easy to raise <https://www.wellington.com/en/insights/impact-of-higher-interest-rates-on-private-equity> as they used to be. It’s also become difficult for PE firms to exit their deals at a profit. S&P Global <https://www.spglobal.com/market-intelligence/en/news-insights/articles/2025/10/private-equity-exit-count-grew-in-q3-as-transaction-sizes-shrank-93889635> said that IPOs and "trade" (M&A) sell-ons were at the lowest levels they've been in years, at around $33.5bn in Q3 of 2025, compared to a $242bn peak in Q2 2022.
As a result, many PE firms are turning to the secondaries market </news/private-capital-advisory-jobs-investment-banking>, where firms sell their stakes in an investment to each other - a kind of financial game of hot potato. S&P Global said last October that secondaries had their largest market share since at least 2021 in Q3 of 2025. Secondaries are a relatively new way of discarding assets, and probably not sustainable – hot potato is not a game about holding onto the potato for as long as possible, after all.
The lack of real exit options is biting the industry. Back in November </news/andy-sieg-wealth-citi>, private equity professionals admitted to the Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/finance/the-golden-handcuffs-are-off-private-equity-employees-leave-for-smaller-firms-375573c6?mod=lead_feature_below_a_pos2> that they were downsizing their expectations for theoretical windfalls that might not materialize, and were more concerned with paying their kids’ private school tuition than with private jets.
It’s important to note that carried interest isn’t the primary way that private equity firms make money. Like other asset management firms, they charge investors a percentage of their assets under management (AuM) as a fee (around 2%). They also charge a management fee to the companies that they manage.
Likewise, carried interest isn't the only aspect of private equity compensation - and according to our compensation report </banking-compensation-guide> last year, private equity salaries and bonuses are roughly on par with investment banking already.
Carried interest and AuM management fees are also charged in private credit deals. These have grown in popularity since the financial crisis, but have questions are now being raised over some private credit investments. For example, a series of loans to e-commerce aggregators have led to some brutal write-downs in recent years. Bloomberg reported yesterday <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/apollo-took-loss-on-asset-backed-loan-deemed-protected?srnd=phx-markets> that Apollo wrote down a portion of its $170m financing to Perch, an Amazon brand aggregator, by 100%.

item.title: UBS bonuses are this Thursday. There are comings & goings before they're announced
item.description:
US banks have announced their bonuses </news/bank-of-america-bonuses-are-out-they-may-be-moderately-good>already. Now, it's European banks' turn. UBS will go first, announcing its bonuses on January 29th (Thursday). However, the Swiss banks' insiders have mixed opinions about the imminent bonuses' likely size, and there have been some curious arrivals and departures ahead of time in the rates business.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter&_gl=1*1oihgn9*_up*MQ..*_ga*ODUwNjg2MDk5LjE3Njg0Njc0OTE.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3Njg0Njc0OTEkbzEkZzAkdDE3Njg0Njc0OTEkajYwJGwwJGgxMTgxOTg4NTM1>
UBS isn't commenting, but prognoses for the bank's bonus pool vary from down 10-15% globally, to up 3-5% in some support functions and up 10-15% in investment banking. All are below the 29% increase in bonuses apparently </news/bonus-expectations-by-bank> anticipated by UBS people before Christmas.
Last year </news/ubs-bonuses>, UBS increased its overall bonus pool by 4% and raised its average key risk-taker bonus by 27%. This year, people at the investment bank are optimistic after integration costs fell 61% year-on-year to $211m and profits rose 52% to $2,2bn in the first nine months of 2025.
UBS's investment bankers are particularly excited. "The market is up and they will have to pay competitively," explains one MD in London.
In trading, insiders point to changes in UBS's London rates trading team before bonuses are announced. Kilian Frensch </news/kilian-frensch>, the friendly ex-Nomura ex-Deutsche Bank rates trader turned up yesterday, while George Dramitinos, a London-based rates trader who joined from Brevan Howard in late 2023, seems to have disappeared. Jason Colloupas, an Australian market trader in London is also thought to have gone.
At the same time, and unrelated to bonuses, UBS has been hiring new people in. Yumin Wang, a rates salesperson, joined in December. Both Wang and Frensch previously worked for Credit Suisse with UBS's top macro trader Shane O’Cuinn, but O'Cuinn is understood to have hired four other traders with whom he did not have prior relations.
Last year, Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-12-18/ubs-plans-january-job-cuts-to-kick-off-final-year-of-integration?embedded-checkout=true> said UBS was planning another round of job cuts </news/ubs-layoffs-credit-suisse> in January. However, Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/europe-investment-bank-bosses-stay-cautious-on-hiring-even-as-2026-boom-predicted-51905b8b?mod=homepage> also reported that it plans to hire bankers this year.

item.title: The difference between quant jobs in electronic trading and research jobs in an AI lab
item.description:
In recent years, a tug of war has developed between prominent electronic trading firms </news/best-electronic-trading-for-to-work-for> and AI laboratories for talent. Last year, OpenAI was reportedly offering junior quants $3m compensation packages </news/openai-culture>, and other labs like Anthropic were hosting dinners to tempt high-frequency trading </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> quants </news/quant-jobs-finance> to make the switch. If you're considering a move, an ex-Citadel Securities </news/citadel-securities-vs-jane-street>quant has revealed just how different AI research jobs are.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Nimit Sohoni spent two years as a quant at Citadel Securities, joining as a graduate after completing his PhD. </news/do-you-need-a-phd-for-a-quant-job-in-finance> He's spent the last two years at Cartesia, a voice AI firm. Appearing on a podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_jECS37M3dQ>yesterday, he explained the differences between is current job and his time at Citadel Securities.
For one, he said quants in finance work far fewer hours than researchers in AI. In finance, Sohoni said he had "a pretty great life balance, as funny as that might sound." Sohoni said his finance colleagues were "really clustered working around trading hours and don't take their work home all too much." This was confirmed last year by ex-Jane Street engineer Leila Clark </news/jane-street-pay-hourly>, who said Jane Street staff work nine-hour days on average.
It's not like that in AI. Sohoni said the AI space includes "a lot of people who are working around the clock." Competition for positions is high and "you can gain a comparative advantage just by outworking your competition." Ex-quants in AI have told us </news/chatgpt-openai-culture>that the long hours aren't mandatory, but researchers choose to work late out of passion.
There are advantages, though. Sohoni said AI labs have far more open cultures, to the point that it was "jarring" for him to hear colleagues speak so openly about their projects. In finance, by contrast, "a lot of people are reluctant or even forbidden to talk about any details of what they do." Culture differs between the big and small AI labs, however. Sohoni said that the larger firms like OpenAI have massive compute power, but "can be more averse to out-of-the-box ideas and more susceptible to groupthink."
Both AI and finance pay well. Sohoni said the two offer the potential to earn "NBA salaries." In quant finance, however, pay is "not exactly outlandish" and outperformance is difficult to achieve. "Hard metrics [mean] that it's easier to evaluate how somebody does, especially if you're an alpha quant."
He said finance quant careers can become "U-shaped" as a result. Seniority comes with higher pay, but the quality of your alpha can't always keep up. "Even a good quant can stop being worth it after a while," he said, "whereas early career quants </news/high-frequency-trading-internship> might be very good and also not command as much of a salary." AI labs seem to have much more reverence for their senior staff; according to Levels.fyi <https://www.levels.fyi/2025/>, OpenAI is the second-highest paying firm in the world for staff engineers, and fifth-highest for principal engineers.

item.title: The little tiny hedge funds managing tens of billions
item.description:
Hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> SurgoCap Partners made the news recently for its assets under management (AuM) reaching $6bn. The most remarkable part of its story, however, is how few people it reached that point with.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
SurgoCap, which was founded by Mala Gaonkar – a rare female hedge fund chief – employed just 24 people, according to its latest form ADV, a US regulatory disclosure. It’s a remarkably efficient firm, and it’s a rare example of a lean hedge fund in an industry generally pushing towards institutionalisation.
Egerton Capital is another. The London-based fund, which was founded in 1994, has around $19.1bn in AuM, and proudly says on its website that it also only has a 13-person investment team. Public disclosures from its subsidiary that appears to employ most people, Egerton Capital Limited, showed 20 total employees for the year ending March 2025.
The Children’s Investment (TCI) Fund Management is another big (pun intended) one. With some $70bn in assets under management, the London-based fund, which was founded and is still run by spiritualist </news/chris-hohn> Chris Hohn, has just fifty employees in total, according to its most recent public filings.
The funds above have over $100bn in total assets under management, with a collective 100 or so employees, averaging $1bn in managed assets per employee. It’s vastly more than their multi-strategy rivals </news/big-multistrategy-hedge-funds>, the biggest of which, Millennium and Citadel, employed more than 6,000 and 3,000 employees respectively to manage smaller assets. The two firms averaged around $13m and $20m in assets per employee across 2025.
Working for one of these tiny hedge funds brings benefits. Being so small, you're likely in the same room as someone making massive investment decisions on a daily basis - something likely to be a much rarer occurrence in a Millennium- or Citadel-sized fund. Mentorship and networking are easy access. And not to mention that a smaller team means there are less mouths to feed - and more bonus money to go around.
