item.title: Morning Coffee: Citi's strange new court case and the secret song. Goldman traders' bad time at Verition
item.description:
Not so long ago, Andy Sieg at Citi seemed to have put complaints </news/andy-sieg-investigation>by various senior female employees </news/andy-sieg-citi-complaints-exits> behind him. He was focused on getting on with his new and bigger job </news/andy-sieg-wealth-citi> while repeating the mantra that "change is hard" </news/andy-sieg-citi-sarcasm> and talking about growth stories <https://www.instagram.com/reels/DT0nvHqCJBC/> at Davos. Yesterday, however, a new Sieg-related lawsuit was filed, and it seems more peculiar than the complaints preceding it.
The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/6b539d0f-d469-40ad-a967-5d712221038a> reported that Julia Carreon, who was Citi Wealth’s global head of platform and experience until 2024, has filed a lawsuit in which she says Citi wrongly claimed that she had an inappropriate relationship with Sieg while she worked there.
Citi says Carreon's lawsuit has "absolutely no merit" and that it will be demonstrating this "through legal process."
Whereas earlier complaints about Sieg - which Citi insists <https://www.ft.com/content/be4ab80a-40f8-4cb2-81a3-cde101b5fa7a> it thoroughly investigated - focused on his alleged hard-charging approach </news/andy-sieg-citi-sarcasm>, Carreon's suit portrays an isolated individual at the top of one of Citi's most challenging businesses who, she claims, called and texted her multiple times a week - sometimes from a burner phone - because he had no one to talk to.
Carreon says she wasn't having a relationship with Sieg, but claims that Sieg insinuated that they were. She says Sieg's insinuations included claiming that they shared a "secret song." The song is not divulged.
When Carreon and Sieg's alleged closeness was discerned by Citi and by colleagues, who the Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/finance/banking/former-citi-executive-sues-bank-alleging-sexual-harassment-bbf6b5b0?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqel9G1N8VrsH00UzPXa-AOGMNsomKj0Wtl-UjBnejHyjUd-3aplDYYy4K1fehk%3D&gaa_ts=697890f3&gaa_sig=xqDAh-tswhRGNWXSogdhZinMNhiPgw9zmiFkKNcOsGkL00eIUctOiX4VzR7I50r5ic12D1kp7xNvFgfQsSz4LA%3D%3D> says assumed that she was having an affair with Sieg, Carreon says the bank conducted an investigation. She says this was biased against her and that the HR team sided with Sieg. In her complaint filed yesterday, she accuses the bank of having a “discriminatory and sexually harassing culture.” Citi denies this.
As Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/citi-executives-jane-fraser-raghavan-sieg-ryan-2026-1>observed this week, Sieg is one of Citi CEO Jane Fraser's prize hires. Fraser said in September </news/andy-sieg-wealth-citi> that the bank "looked at the matter seriously" when earlier complaints were made about him, and concluded that they were invalid. Sieg was tasked with cutting costs and restructuring </news/Andy-Sieg-Citi> the wealth business, where revenues have increased 22% in the past two years. Fraser said last September that Sieg had "delivered" on his mandate and that she was very pleased with both he and his team.
Separately, Sina Lashgari and Jon Paul </news/2022/08/highest-paying-jobs-at-goldman-sachs> seemed to be having a fine time at Goldman Sachs, where their 20-person program trading team made $700m a year for two years to 2022 and an unnamed individual received a $9m bonus.
Like many talented traders, the two decided to move to a hedge fund. </news/finance/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> Unfortunately, the move seems to have been fraught from the start. First, Goldman accused them of, "accessing sensitive Firm proprietary computer software...without authorization or a valid business purpose, and attempting to remove or hide evidence." Now, Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/verition-shutters-team-led-by-ex-goldman-traders-lashgari-paul?srnd=phx-industries-finance>reports that Verition has closed their team three years after they joined.
The reason for the closure is unclear, but Bloomberg suggests it was down to the poor performance of some event-driven bets. Lashgari didn't respond to a request to comment.
Some Verition insiders have described the fund </news/2023/05/verition-hedge-fund> as being run by "really nice people" and having a fine culture. Others have told us that the London office is very nice and has good snacks. However, like all hedge funds, Verition has a limited tolerance for drawdowns. </news/hedge-fund-interviews>It is also not unfamiliar with hiring good people and letting them go again - Sara Nainzadeh </news/hedge-fund-verition-s-top-hire-from-millennium-appears-to-have-left-again>, who spent 20 years at Milllennium, came and went within a year or so.
Meanwhile...
Benjamin Binet-Laisne, Goldman's head of precious metals trading, has left the bank amidst heavy competition for metals traders. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/goldman-s-top-precious-metals-trader-binet-laisne-leaves-bank?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260126&utm_campaign=author_19458291>
Europe's IPO market is having a fine start to the year. It's a good time to bring defence manufacturers to market. Ammunition maker Czechoslovak Group (CSG) raised €3.8bn on Friday. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/264bf83c-7c5b-4ced-aa4e-edb9327f4986>
Morgan Stanley is recruiting financial advisers, and people in capital markets and commodities in Asia. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/morgan-stanley-looks-to-expand-in-asia-as-markets-deregulate>
Mizuho hired Jon Connor and Thibaud de Maria from HSBC and JPMorgan. It also hired Armand de Vienne from HSBC and Richard Robinson from Deutsche Bank as it accumulates bankers. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/mizuho-adds-hsbc-s-connor-jpmorgan-s-de-maria-to-hiring-wave>
BNP Paribas is firing 1,200 people as it integrates Axa Investment Managers. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-22/bnp-paribas-seeks-to-cut-about-1-200-roles-on-axa-im-integration>
Vanguard is plotting a major international expansion and wants to double its customers and assets within five years. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/28e0cbf6-65de-4e18-9c2c-32283c23fd9d>
Goldman Sachs loves its wealth and asset management business. It's just promoted seven new partners to its 46 person management committee, including the global heads of private credit, the global co-heads of wealth management, the chief investment officer of the external investment group, and the global co-head of public investing. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/goldman-sachs-promotes-seven-partners-to-top-leadership-group?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260126&utm_campaign=author_21835441>
Hedge funds are using prediction markets. Research has found that 95% of the time, the consensus from traditional sources like economists and consultants aligns with that of prediction markets. (Business Insider) <https://www.businessinsider.com/how-hedge-funds-are-using-prediction-markets-data-2026-1>
You can get a premium residence of Saudi Arabia if you have $30m, a large yacht, or are a top student. All three would be great. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-26/saudis-weigh-expanding-premium-residency-net-to-lure-ultra-rich?utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=facebook>
The worst outcome of a financial services career: you spend more as you earn more, spend no time with your children while they're growing up, and then feel obliged to buy them a house to compensate. (Fortune) <https://fortune.com/article/genz-consulting-banking-oxford-harvard-golden-handcuffs-taking-risks-simon-van-teutem/>

item.title: "I'm a 30 year-old Goldman Sachs quant. I would never leave for a market making firm"
item.description:
I'm a trader at Goldman Sachs. My bonus this year was good but not great. It's a perpetual reminder that I am making money for the machine.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Despite this, I have no intention of leaving. I see plenty of colleagues going to places like Jane Street, Optiver or Citadel Securities, </news/2022/10/how-to-get-a-job-at-citadel>but I think it's a significant risk. Market makers are a good bet when you're 22 years old, but when you're in your 30s, I think they're a mistake. It seems to me that the median age there is incredibly low, and it can be very difficult to survive. It's worth taking the risk if you're a fresh graduate, but dangerous beyond that.
I say this based only on personal observation. I've seen friends go to market makers, and they've either been paid terribly or have left quickly. Yes, you're working for the machine at Goldman, but in my opinion it's even worse at market making firms. You have very little ownership and in my opinion the culture can be ruthless, as it can be elsewhere. They also skew pay very highly towards top-performers and the median can be low. I've got friends who've joined these firms and then worked 15 hours a day just to learn the systems.
By comparison, my job at Goldman Sachs seems relatively safe. I'm in a management role and am well-respected. Working for Goldman Sachs seems a steady long-term career. The firm is a top market leader in my area and we have an edge. It makes far more sense for me to stay here than to jump to a trading firm for a high bonus that probably won't materialise and that - if it does - will simply increase the risk that I'm cut the next time there are layoffs.
Bruno Thaler is a pseudonym

item.title: BNP Paribas hires ex-JPMorgan MD to make AI tools for its investment bankers
item.description:
It's not just the US banks going all in on AI. </news/how-to-get-a-banking-ai-job> French bank BNP Paribas </news/bnp-q4-2024>has rolled out AI tools to various teams, including its investment bankers. </news/what-is-an-investment-bank> Now it's bringing in a former JPMorgan </news/jpmorgan-pay-executives> MD to further the charge.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Charles Holive is joining BNP Paribas as an MD and chief AI officer for its corporate and institutional bank (CIB), home to its markets </news/capital-markets-jobs-ecm-and-dcm>and advisory </news/get-a-job-in-ma> teams. He joins after an 18-month stint at PepsiCo, where he was SVP of AI solutions.
It's a return to banking for Holive. Before PepsiCo, he spent three years at JPMorgan as an MD. There, he joined as head of CIB applied AI and machine learning (ML) operations, before becoming head of AI/ML and digital tools services for the division.
BNP Paribas has been developing various AI products in its CIB. Last month, it rolled out an AI tool for bankers <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/bnp-paribas-rolls-out-ai-portal-to-cut-pitch-time-for-dealmakers-8453517a> to analyze previous pitch data, while older AI tools have focused on analyzing the ESG performance <https://www.finextra.com/newsarticle/46894/bnp-paribas-deploys-ai-to-speed-up-esg-assessments>of companies.
As a French bank, BNP is big on Mistral, the French AI lab that created the very on-the-nose French chatbot 'Le Chat'. The bank signed a deal in 2024 <https://group.bnpparibas/en/press-release/bnp-paribas-and-mistral-ai-sign-a-partnership-agreement-covering-all-mistral-ai-models> giving it access to current and future Mistral large language models. Insiders suggest that Mistral LLMs aren't universally popular among employees, however.
BNP Paribas did not respond to a request for comment.

item.title: Goldman Sachs' hedge fund survey suggests 2026 hiring will happen here
item.description:
As we note in Morning Coffee </news/david-solomon-goldman-sachs-pay> today, 2026 stands to be a big year for hedge funds </news/finance/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job>. Goldman Sachs' recent hedge fund survey found that investors plan to allocate money to hedge funds this year than at any point since 2017. More money typically means more staff.
However, that money will not be allocated equally. As the chart below, from Goldman's presentation based on the survey, shows, allocators are most keen on allocating money to quant funds and equity long/short funds in 2026. By implication, this is where the hiring will be strongest.
By comparison, credit funds have fallen out of favour. Multistrategy funds are still popular, but less so than during the heyday of 2023.
Source: Goldman Sachs Goldman also indicates where in the world hedge fund hiring is likely to happen in 2026. The answer would seem to be especially Asia.Strategy appetite by geography:
Source: Goldman Sachs
And, for anyone looking in the rearview mirror, Goldman has the following helpful chart looking at how assets by strategy (and by proxy portfolio managers associated with these strategies) have changed since 2021. It's been a good time to be a quant...

item.title: JPMorgan Engineering Pay: What you'll earn as an analyst, associate and VP
item.description:
JPMorgan </news/jpmorgan-pay-executives> spends a lot of money on tech. According to its 2025 investor day, the bank budgeted $18bn </news/jp-morgan-s-18bn-tech-spending-suggests-these-developers-are-in-high-demand> for technology. It ended the year with a non-compensation technology expense of $11bn according to its Q4 results, which implies a lot has been set aside for engineering pay.
The bank's technology team is rapidly expanding, accounting for over 1,000 of its 7,000+ current job openings, but how much can you expect to make if you get in?
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
How much are engineering analysts, associates and VPs paid at JPMorgan?
Using self-reported compensation numbers posted to Levels.fyi <https://www.levels.fyi/en-gb/companies/jpmorgan-chase/salaries> since the start of 2025, we've analyzed over 1,200 datapoints to calculate average total compensation figures at each level of seniority at JPMorgan.
The US naturally pays the most at each level of seniority, with the UK lagging slightly behind. There is a big disparity between pay in those two regions and the bank's global capacity centres (GCCs) in India </news/h1b-visa-investment-banking-jos>; pay for Indian engineering analysts is just $23.5k on average compared to $61k in the UK and $108k in the US.
From analyst to associate, the UK has the largest average rise in pay. Total compensation increases by over 70% to $105k. Pay for Indian engineers increases by ~50% while the pay increase for US associates is closer to 35%.
The US, similarly, has the smallest pay increase for VPs. Pay for UK engineers at JPMorgan rises over 70% again from associate to VP while pay in India almost doubles to $71k.
At executive director level, pay in each seniority rises massively. JPMorgan pays US-based EDs the most, $348k on average, but Indian engineers once again had the largest pay increase, more than doubling compensation to an average of $144k at ED level.
Which types of engineers earn the most at JPMorgan
Levels.fyi also breaks down the engineering divisions of its datapoints. When looking at global average figures for a number of its most prominent divisions, it may come as no surprise to see what pays the most.
AI engineers at JPMorgan earn an average of $207k. In New York, they can earn much more; one VP reported a total compensation of $400k with a salary of $260k, while another earned a total of $300k. For some of its most unique AI roles, JPMorgan offers up to $325k in salary alone. </news/jp-morgan-paying-325k-salaries-for-its-new-ai-strike-team>
The lowest paying division, by contrast, is full-stack. This is in part because these roles are much more common in its lower paying offices. Pay for US full-stack engineers was $146k, with pay reaching as high as $440k for one Texas-based full-stack executive director.

item.title: Bank of America bonuses are out. They may be moderately good
item.description:
It's bonus </news/goldman-sachs-and-morgan-stanley-people-complain-of-poor-bonuses-away-from-the-front-office> day at Bank of America. People at the bank are being informed of their numbers moment by moment. It's too early to say exactly what they're like, but the vibe seems moderately good. Bank of America is not commenting.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter&_gl=1*1oihgn9*_up*MQ..*_ga*ODUwNjg2MDk5LjE3Njg0Njc0OTE.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3Njg0Njc0OTEkbzEkZzAkdDE3Njg0Njc0OTEkajYwJGwwJGgxMTgxOTg4NTM1>
In markets, sources say BofA's bonuses are "ok." The pool is up, but only by a small amount. There's more differentiation between strong and poor performers. One London insider confirmed that they are "moderate." Asian bonuses at BofA are thought to be strong relative to the US and EMEA.
In investment banking, where Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/boards-policy-regulation/bofa-bonuses-will-jump-investment-bankers-this-year-sources-say-2025-12-19/> suggested in December that BofA's bonus pool was up 20% on last year, people may be more pleased, although we cannot confirm that this has come to pass.
Pre-Christmas, BofA people told us </news/bonus-expectations-by-bank> they were expecting a wild 59% increase in their bonuses. This seems unlikely.
Bank of America's global markets team generated record revenues last year. However, the bank is squeezing compensation costs as it throttles hiring </news/banking-recruitment-s-sorry-story-more-candidates-fewer-jobs>and tries to do more with AI. "Headcount remains our key driver of expense from compensation and benefits to real estate and technology," said CFO Alastair Borthwick, speaking during the bank's fourth quarter investor call.
In a seeming vote against bonuses, Bank of America lost Kal El Wahab </news/bof-a-s-head-of-linear-rates-trading-resigned-for-a-hedge-fund-before-bonuses>, its EMEA head of linear rates trading, to Bluecrest </news/what-s-it-like-to-work-for-mike-platt-at-blue-crest-capital-management> in Dubai earlier this month. Speaking to Semafor <https://www.semafor.com/article/01/23/2026/bank-of-americas-brian-moynihan-the-pipelines-are-full> at Davos, CEO Brian Moynihan said investment banking pipelines are full but that although regulations are lifting, "the real best time to be a banker is when the economy’s decent."
Profits in BofA's markets business rose 9% last year. In global banking, which includes corporate and investment banking, they were down 2%.
At Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley </news/goldman-sachs-and-morgan-stanley-people-complain-of-poor-bonuses-away-from-the-front-office>, people appear to have been paid well in the front office but not so well elsewhere.

item.title: JPMorgan hired a senior systematic equities MD from hedge fund Millennium
item.description:
Not all people who leave banks for hedge funds </news/best-paying-hedge-funds> stay there. In 2024 John Jose left Goldman Sachs and joined Millennium </news/millennium-hedge-fund-pay-london> as a senior equities <https://www.investmentnews.com/independent-broker-dealers/goldman-sachs-loses-another-long-term-senior-leader/252080> portfolio manager. Now he's leaving the hedge fund and joining JPMorgan instead.

item.title: Cantor Fitzgerald succumbed to East European offshoring
item.description:
If you’re looking for job at Cantor Fitzgerald, the brokerage firm with ties to Washington DC </news/howard-lutnick>, you’re in luck – if you don’t live anywhere near Washington DC, that is.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Cantor Fitzgerald is hiring in Poland </news/tech-jobs-finance-poland-warsaw>.
The brokerage firm is looking for nine new staff in Warsaw, working across operations </news/operations-jobs-banking>, finance </news/accounting-job-finance-banking>, compliance </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-compliance>, and technology </news/how-to-get-a-technology-job-bank>, of course. The vacancies are for international support roles, with a senior tax role noting that it requires liaising with offices in the UK, EMEA, and APAC.
Cantor Fitzgerald’s website does not mention a presence in Poland at all. The jobs may be the start of a new office there.
Warsaw is a popular option for nearshoring, with investment banks like Goldman Sachs </news/2017/12/warsaw-banking-jobs> and JPMorgan <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/jpmorgan-confirms-plans-for-3000-new-staff-in-warsaw-20170926> already heavily invested in the city, as well as hedge funds such as Point72 </news/2021/04/point72-warsaw> and Balyasny </news/another-hedge-fund-opened-a-warsaw-office-for-developer-hires>.
UBS has a huge presence down the road in Krakow, some 5,000 people. BNY Mellon has its own massive presence in Wroclaw – around 3,000. Morgan Stanley has a 3,000-strong Budapest office.
Cantor Fitzgerald declined to comment.

item.title: Morning Coffee: How to earn $47m at Goldman Sachs. Hedge fund hiring is only going to intensify
item.description:
For a brief moment last week, Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan, may have felt rich. Dimon found out on Thursday that he earned $43m for 2025, which was 10% more than the previous year and more than all his JPMorgan executive colleagues. </news/jpmorgan-pay-executives>But then David Solomon </news/david-solomon-goldman-sachs-wrath> came along.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
David Solomon, who is CEO of Goldman Sachs </news/how-to-get-a-job-goldman-sachs>, is being paid $47m for last year. The Wall Street Journal <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-23/goldman-sachs-boosts-ceo-david-solomon-s-pay-21-to-47-million> notes that this is 21% more than Solomon was paid for 2024. It includes $3.4m of carried interest </news/private-equity-carried-interest>so that he feels like he works in private equity.
What's required to earn that kind of money at Goldman Sachs? You can possibly do it as a very, very successful trader - three years ago, Goldman's commodities traders were reportedly </news/2022/01/goldman-sachs-bonuses>anticipating $30m each. And every year, Goldman pays a mysterious group of 13 </news/goldman-sachs-pay-london> people over $9.5m in London.
In Solomon's case, though, the big payday reflects his fine job running Goldman Sachs and there is the helpful equivalent of a report card <https://www.goldmansachs.com/investor-relations/financials/8k/2026/8k-01-23-26.pdf> explaining why Goldman felt moved to pay him so much. This says that Solomon "continued" doing many things, including creating "shareholder value", generating "strong momentum" on executing strategic priorities and emphasizing a strong risk and controls environment. Solomon's report says he also displayed a desirable, "enduring and relentless focus" on Goldman's culture and core values.
All of this sounds relatively easy. Goldman's share price is up 32% on last year, but this is partly to do with the easing of bank capital rules <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-06-26/us-bank-stocks-xlf-bnks-revival-depend-on-relaxed-rules-and-deal-recovery> imposed after the financial crisis than Solomon's prowess personally. "The regulatory environment over the last five years put costs and burdens on the firm that we now won't have going forward," he said on the firm's results call this month. The FT <https://www.ft.com/content/bb658ce5-95a8-4888-a253-8f3b8ea10f36> noted last July that revisions to US stress test methodology have benefitted Goldman in particular, which saw its potential losses under the tests fall from an estimated $18bn to just $300m after private equity investments were excluded from the Fed's market shock scenario. Goldman, in particular, has a lot of these.
While David Solomon's pay may be nice for David Solomon, his report card contains some reassurance for others at Goldman, too. Solomon has also continued with the "advancement" of Goldman's "people strategy," says the card. In doing so, he has considered, "the ongoing competitive threat to our best talent from both traditional banking peers as well as alternative asset managers and other non-bank liquidity providers."
In simple language, this means that Solomon's pay reflects his awareness that Goldman's best people are being tempted by hedge funds </news/finance/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> and electronic trading firms. </news/difference-between-electronic-trading-firms>He's being paid generously to reflect that. Maybe they are too?
Separately, hedge funds might pinch more of Goldman's people this year. The Wall Street Journal < https://www.wsj.com/finance/investing/hedge-funds-are-back-on-top-after-a-long-alpha-winter-f5c7cd21?mod=hp_lead_pos2> notes that a recent Goldman Sachs survey of fund managers found that a net 45% of them plan to increase their exposure to hedge fund this year. This is an all-time high for the survey, which dates back to 2017.
Meanwhile...
Chris Hohn </news/chris-hohn> has made a lot of money, but his hedge fund TCI Fund Management doesn't look much like a hedge fund. He manages a concentrated portfolio of stocks, hasn’t put a short on for three years and holds positions for an average of eight years. His investment team is only seven or eight people. (Net Interest) <https://www.netinterest.co/p/the-last-active-manager?utm_source=substack&publication_id=43559&post_id=185555879&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share&action=share&triggerShare=true&isFreemail=true&token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjoxMjQ4ODg0LCJwb3N0X2lkIjoxODU1NTU4NzksImlhdCI6MTc2OTE4ODU2NiwiZXhwIjoxNzcxNzgwNTY2LCJpc3MiOiJwdWItNDM1NTkiLCJzdWIiOiJwb3N0LXJlYWN0aW9uIn0.9LA3zx-cBw4L5UBdhx_uZWM_haTORnNPkSjHPoJvEnU&r=qrn8&triedRedirect=true>
Jamie Gavin, head of prime brokerage clearing for Europe, the Middle East and Africa at Societe General, left the bank to work as an external consultant for the London Stock Exchange Group’s SwapAgent platform. (Risk) <https://www.risk.net/people/7962988/socgen%E2%80%99s-pb-clearing-head-departs-for-swapagent-role>
TCP Capital Corp, a BlackRock private credit fund, expects to mark its assets down 19%. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-23/blackrock-private-debt-fund-expects-19-net-asset-value-cut?utm_source=website&utm_medium=share&utm_campaign=twitter?sref=R17xFhjo>
Revolut is expanding in Switzerland, where it wants to hire a head of risk, head of legal, a treasury manager, tax manager, business risk manager, and a strategy & operations person. (FiNews) <https://www.finews.com/news/english-news/70932-revolut-seeks-senior-management-in-switzerland-julian-biegmann-ceo>
Revolut may not buy an existing bank in the US and might apply for its own license instead (implying a lot of hiring). (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/908e261f-2b78-4798-8aa2-aff2e828d31a>
Ken Griffin was one of the few dissenting voices at Davos. “Why are we fighting over a piece of rock covered by ice,” he asked. “We have frayed relationships with our European allies in ways that I don’t understand or appreciate.” (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/49286969-ab39-4cbd-bb18-f563cc2eb31b>
Natural gas prices jumped unexpectedly and maybe this was bad for hedge funds. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-24/natural-gas-market-in-panic-mode-after-mild-winter-bets?srnd=phx-industries-finance>
Credentials were a fiction. The credential was a proxy, a compression algorithm for trust. It worked when the cost of direct evaluation was prohibitive. That cost is collapsing. (Exponential View) <https://www.exponentialview.co/p/the-end-of-the-fictions?hide_intro_popup=true>
Accounting firm Grant Thornton has been deluged with students applying using AI. It is closing job ads earlier and capping the volume of applicants in response and now has 39 applicants per job instead of 60. (The Times <https://www.thetimes.com/business/companies-markets/article/want-a-top-accounting-job-stop-using-ai-to-write-your-cv-8bwbzbfmw>)
Mercor is paying young professionals $95 an hour to train AI that can do their jobs. “I give [the AI] a problem, [such as] how a company like Boeing could handle the challenge post-crash — damage control, how would it impact the business, how would they handle stakeholders . . . and look at how the AI responds. You’re challenging [the models] and correcting them.” (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/0cab0fcd-e355-40e8-83a3-2ad5066d7b48>
Overall, across all occupations and certification levels, AI skill signals raise interview probabilities by between 8 and 15 percentage points. (Arvix) <https://arxiv.org/pdf/2601.13286>
Jeremy Coller is a vegan activist who failed his A-levels three times and just sold his private equity secondaries business for £3.2bn. When he retires he will probably campaign against factory farming. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/4d2e7429-dc82-4fd9-8044-61921a5a28bf>

item.title: Bain, McKinsey, BCG, and Big Four pay: a bad time to be a consultant
item.description:
McKinsey, Bain – and BCG, collectively known as MBB – are the gold standard of management consulting jobs. Deloitte, EY, PwC, and KPMG </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-the-big-four> – collectively known as the Big Four </news/working-for-the-big-four-pwc-deloitte-ey-kpmg> – are the silver standard. What do they have in common? They’re both subjecting their junior recruits to brutal pay cuts. Kind of.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
It’s more complicated than that. Compensation for entry-level consultants has risen in recent years, just not by very much – and generally far below the US inflation rate since 2020.
Figures in the tables below are taken from careers coaching firm Management Consulted. The final row of each table, detailing the “real decline” after adjusting for inflation, was calculated by the change in pay from 2020 to 2026 accounting for the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for inflation in the USA.
Undergraduates and masters’ degree students who went into consulting this year found themselves with a rough draw. In real terms, their compensation was overwhelmingly down on their colleagues who joined in 2020. The situation was worst at PwC, where graduate compensation had been fixed at $102k since the pandemic. The equivalent pay this year with an adjustment for inflation would be around $127k, a figure 24% higher than today’s.
Only McKinsey paid its undergraduate and masters graduate hires better than they did in 2020, adjusted for inflation – all the MBB firms were more generous than their Big Four peers, in fact.
Unfortunately, the situation was not much better for graduates of MBA and PhD programs who went into consulting. Compensation was again lower across the board, with only EY paying a higher rate than it did in 2020 adjusted for inflation. The worst decline was at KPMG, where real pay was down by 13%.
What’s driving the pressure on consultant pay? Among other things, Artificial Intelligence (AI). Accenture, for example <https://www.ft.com/content/a74f8564-ed5a-42e9-8fb3-d2bddb2b8675>, commenced a $865m restructuring project in September last year specifically targeting employees that could not be “retrained for the age of artificial intelligence”, in the words of the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/a74f8564-ed5a-42e9-8fb3-d2bddb2b8675>.
The biggest AI evangelists, however, are at McKinsey & Co. The firm confirmed to Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/mckinsey-workforce-ai-agents-consulting-industry-bob-sternfels-2026-1> last week that it employed around 25,000 AI agents to work alongside its 40,000 flesh-and-blood human beings. 18 months ago, it employed only a few thousand. In another 18 months from now, it planned to have one AI agent per employee.
Additionally, the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/de7855f0-f586-4708-a8ed-f0458eb25586> noted last week that McKinsey was restructuring its recruitment tests by asking junior aspirants to use an AI assistant called Lilli in its tests for business school graduates. The use of Lilli appears to be mandatory.
There are other factors at play beyond AI. In 2025, government spending on consultants came under fire both in Canada <https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-feds-consultants> and the USA <https://www.irishtimes.com/business/2025/03/31/deloitte-is-hit-hardest-by-trumps-spending-clampdown-on-consultants/>, a market worth more than US$75bn annually.

item.title: Citi insiders with poor appraisals apprehensive ahead of cuts before and after bonuses
item.description:
As we reported last week, Citi is cutting jobs </news/citi-job-cuts-2026-bonuses> before it announces bonuses. </news/banker-bonuses>Now, it appears to be cutting jobs after it announces bonuses, too.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Alongside the bank's 1,000 pre-bonus job cuts flagged last week, Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/world/citigroup-lay-off-more-employees-march-sources-say-2026-01-23/> reports that Citi also intends to cut an undisclosed number of employees in March, once bonuses are paid.
The cuts are causing apprehension. Insiders at Citi tell us that in both cases they are wary that the bank has paved the way for mass redundancies with an unusually strict round of performance reviews.
Citi's staff appraisals </news/citi-promotions-investment-banking> are based on a rating system. Employees are rated between one (the highest) and four (the lowest). This year, insiders who claim they were historically always rated as a one or two, say they have suddenly been rated as three for "no reason."
"I got dreadful ratings for the first time in 10 years at the bank," one Citi employee tells us. "The reasoning behind it was vague and other internal stakeholders were very positive. I feel very exposed!"
Another Citi insider says long-term employees accustomed to being ranked as 1s and 2s are increasingly being ranked as 3s. "They are targeting long-term high performers by issuing a low performance grade," they allege.
The complaints, which may be unfounded, come after Citi has hired heavily into its investment bank under Vis Raghavan </news/citi-vis-raghavan>. Despite the addition of numerous banking recruits, many from JPMorgan </news/jp-morgan-s-latest-big-citi-hire-might-be-joined-by-more-after-bonuses>, Citi kept expenses in its investment bank flat last year.
At the same time, there are early reports of "mixed" bonuses, with some in Citi's markets business allegedly zeroed. However, for 2026, Citi has relaxed its cost guidance with the bank now targeting a group-wide cost ratio of "around" 60%, instead of the below 60% number it was aiming for previously.
A Citi spokesperson said: "Citi has always held our colleagues to high standards, and we will continue to do so as we build on the strong results we’re delivering." They added that Citi will continue cutting headcount this year and that the cuts, "reflect adjustments we’re making to ensure our staffing levels, locations and expertise align with current business needs; efficiencies we have gained through technology; and progress against our transformation work, which is nearing target state. "

item.title: Goldman Sachs & Morgan Stanley people complain of poor bonuses away from the front office
item.description:
Bank of America excepted, US banks have announced their bonuses </news/goldman-sachs-bonuses-are-announced-thursday-jp-morgan-people-must-wait>for 2025. If you work in M&A they seem to have been strong. But if you work in a support role, a new feebleness has appeared.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter&_gl=1*1oihgn9*_up*MQ..*_ga*ODUwNjg2MDk5LjE3Njg0Njc0OTE.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3Njg0Njc0OTEkbzEkZzAkdDE3Njg0Njc0OTEkajYwJGwwJGgxMTgxOTg4NTM1>
At Morgan Stanley, where Asian bankers reportedly </news/goldman-sachs-bonuses-are-announced-thursday-jp-morgan-people-must-wait> received 20% bonus increases and London bankers received uplifts of 15%, insiders say mid-ranking operations staff were greeted with less favourable news when their bonuses were announced.
"We were told that the compensation plan architecture had changed for VPs and above and that we'd get a smaller bonus and higher base pay," says one Morgan Stanley operations insider. "It soon became clear that this wasn't the case - many of us received no base salary increase and were told we were at the upper end of the pay range."
Morgan Stanley declined to comment.
At Goldman Sachs, people say that bankers received fine bonuses but that markets professionals were less happy and that engineering and operations bonuses were "hit badly." The firm also declined to comment.
Poor bonuses can be a catalyst for quitting jobs. When staff leave voluntarily, banks don't have to pay severance.
Roles in technology, operations and the middle office </news/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking> are particularly susceptible to automation. Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan said last week that the bank has replaced 2,000 technologists with AI, and that BofA has cut headcount in the finance team using a "series of prompts." Notably, AI does not require a salary or a bonus.

item.title: FCA staff objecting to their imminent office return say they've been ignored
item.description:
As we reported this week </news/fca-back-to-the-office>, the Financial Conduct Authority wants its people back in the office but many of them would really like to stay at home.
Emails sent to staff by the FCA, combined with the contents of an internal chatroom, both shared with eFinancialCareers, highlight the awkward stand-off.
On one hand, the FCA has tried to be accommodating. It's only asking for most of its people to be in the office 50% of the time (60% for executive directors and directors). It's only assessing compliance with this diktat every three months, giving staff leeway to distribute in-office days across 60-day periods. And it's delaying the imposition of the new requirements until September, so that parents can work from home during the summer holidays. It's even paying £300 to support its homeworkers, again.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
As at SocGen </news/french-bank-s-gentle-job-cuts-don-t-mean-people-are-happy-there>, however, FCA people seem disinclined to feel all that grateful. Working from home is very popular. It seems that coming into the office is not.
When the change was announced this week, an FCA meeting (attended online by its homeworkers) was deluged with disparaging comments. Employees seemed particularly exercised by the fact that the regulator had asked them whether they wanted to return to the office, that they'd said "no," and yet, they were being ignored. “It seems slightly odd to have a staff survey and then ignore the majority response to the main question,” said one typical commenter.
Another claimed that staff weren't being listened to and said: “What’s best for the organisation is a happy ship. A happy ship is a productive ship." The same person observed that the summons to the office followed other unpopular changes like a higher excess on Bupa, the removal of bonuses and the introduction of "the awful bell curve" rating system. In combination, they said these are not the best for morale. The comment received 31 likes and six 100% emojis.
Sarah Pritchard, the FCA's deputy chief executive, emailed staff on Tuesday to explain that the increased time in the office will encourage "greater collaboration and innovation" and strengthen a "shared sense of purpose" among other things. Her staff are not so sure. “Apparently we are all going to have more ad hoc conversations in the lifts and that will magically produce an improvement in organisational productivity,” wrote one. “How does this improve f2f collaboration when there is no guarantee that those you wish to collaborate with attend the office on the same days?,” wrote another.
A spokesperson for the FCA told us: “Colleagues will inevitably have a range of views on the change, and most of the discussions we’ve had have focused on how we make it work. We believe a 50/50 split between time in the office and at home will deliver greater collaboration and innovation, support the mentoring and development of colleagues, help us to solve complex or novel problems more easily, improve communication and strengthen our shared sense of purpose – all of which enrich us an organisation.”
Many banks now expect people in the office full-time. As well as allowing people to spend 50% of the week at home, the regulator has a subsidized restaurant,a subsidized coffee bar and a subsidized fitness centre. It also offers interest free loans for season tickets (to get into the office as required).

item.title: French bank's gentle job cuts don't mean people are happy there
item.description:
SocGen is cutting some more people. The French bank doesn't report its fourth quarter results until February and won't pay its bonuses until March, but the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/493fc3f1-50bc-4724-939f-d9ec2889459f> reported earlier this week that it intends to cut 1,800 jobs. This is seemingly supplementary to its other plan, reported by Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-13/socgen-s-bernstein-jv-seeks-to-cut-france-workforce-by-third>, to cut a third of the people (70 jobs) at its Paris equities joint venture with Alliance Bernstein.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
The 1,800 job cuts will, at least, be gently executed. They're due to happen before the end of 2027 and will be entirely the result of natural attrition. At 4.5% of SocGen's total 40,000 person headcount, the implication is that SocGen will simply wait for people to leave of their own accords. </news/banking-recruitment-s-sorry-story-more-candidates-fewer-jobs>
Are SocGen's French staff happy with this approach? Sadly not. More details are due imminently but for the moment, a post <https://www.cgtsocgen.fr/component/content/article/la-politique-du-fait-accompli-rencontre-avec-alexis-kohler-mercredi-21-janvier-2026?catid=210&Itemid=101> by representatives of the CGT Union in relation to the plan suggests discontentment.
The CGT claims it's been asking to meet SocGen management to discuss the reorganisation since June 2025, but has now been hit by a plan that's already conceived. The plan includes more digitalisation, the removal of layers of management, more internal mobility (including a mobility career campus) and the formation of multidisciplinary teams of combined skills across areas like data management, lending and KYC.
The cuts come after SocGen people were summoned back to the office <https://www.cgtsocgen.fr/component/content/article/la-politique-du-fait-accompli-rencontre-avec-alexis-kohler-mercredi-21-janvier-2026?catid=210&Itemid=101> four days a week in June. Many are still grumbling about this. "A significant percentage of employees applied for formal flexible working," says one employee at SocGen in London. "Even people with written medical and occupational health recommendations are being rejected."
Maybe they will leave, and add to the 1,800 cuts.
SocGen didn't respond to a request to comment.

item.title: Morning Coffee: JPMorgan's pay hierarchy shows who it likes best. The most petulant client in the world
item.description:
JPMorgan has made some regulatory filings. They are about pay. Not for the rank and file, who don't get their own regulatory filings, but for the executives who run the bank and who receive more than the rest.
The filings, which are here <https://jpmorganchaseco.gcs-web.com/?field_nir_sec_cik_target_id=&field_nir_sec_date_filed_value=&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B471%5D=471&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B611%5D=611&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B616%5D=616&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1821%5D=1821&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1826%5D=1826&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B676%5D=676&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B681%5D=681&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1666%5D=1666&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1671%5D=1671&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1946%5D=1946&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1971%5D=1971&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B516%5D=516&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1166%5D=1166&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B1436%5D=1436&field_nir_sec_form_group_target_id_1%5B2316%5D=2316&items_per_page_toggle=0&&&page=0>, depict the hierarchy at the top of the hierarchy. CEO Jamie Dimon is predictably at the pinnacle. JPMorgan revealed yesterday <https://jpmorganchaseco.gcs-web.com/static-files/0a08f13c-bba9-4915-abb1-18adbc8138fd>that after consideration of his "holistic performance", it will be paying Dimon a $1.5m salary and a $41m bonus, of which the FT <https://www.ft.com/content/340ee8ce-46fe-4107-ac9b-595fbb16ca1e>notes that $5m will be in cash and $36.5m will be in stock. At today's share price, this implies that Dimon is getting over 120,000 JPMorgan shares.
Filings for Dimon's underlings aren't as complete. They only reflect the stock bonuses awarded to the C-Suite. These bonuses have been distributed as follows:
Once again, therefore, it appears that JPMorgan's smile is falling particularly warmly on Mary Callahan Erdoes </news/mary-callahan-erdoes-jpmorgan>, the CEO of its asset and wealth management business, and a historic proselytizer for the 12-hour day six-day week. </news/mary-callahan-erdoes-jpmorgan>Erdoes, who began working for JPMorgan in 1996, is frequently one of the bank's best rewarded people. This year, she has been awarded three times as many shares as Leopold, the head of HR.
Neither Erdoes nor Leopold can sell their stock and immediate lie on a beach with their riches. It vests in two tranches, in January 2028 and January 2029.
Separately, you probably don't want to annoy Donald Trump. Not only will you be omitted from the invitation to what the Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/politics/policy/inside-trumps-private-reception-with-ceos-in-davos-543ef7d8?mod=panda_wsj_author_alert> suggests was a peculiar party at Davos with no chairs and some high tables, but you might be sued $5bn.
Jamie Dimon was invited to Donald's peculiar party, but the WSJ says he left early when Donald was 90 minutes late. Brian Moynihan of Bank of America didn't seem to be invited at all.
It's not clear whether Dimon's disappearance was noticed by Trump, but yesterday Trump sued JPMorgan for $5bn <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-22/trump-sues-jpmorgan-dimon-for-5-billion-over-alleged-debanking> for "debanking" him after the US Capitol riots. The FT <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-22/trump-sues-jpmorgan-dimon-for-5-billion-over-alleged-debanking>suggests that Brian's absence from the table party was a possible punishment for Bank of America's similar refusal to open a bank account for Trump in 2021.
Not attending a party is one thing. Being hit with a $5bn fine, even if it does turn out to be spurious, is another. Trump is not exactly a client, but senior bankers used to dealing with singular characters may want to treat him as such. Dimon previously <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-21/dimon-says-he-would-be-more-polite-in-criticizing-europe>told a Davos meeting that he “would be more polite" than Trump when referring to Europe's weaknesses. This may not have gone unnoticed.
For the moment, JPMorgan is attempting to patch things up with gentle language intimating that the government's own money laundering legislation gave it no choice but to close Trump's accounts.
“We do close accounts because they create legal or regulatory risk for the company,” a spokesman for the bank told the WSJ <https://www.wsj.com/finance/president-trump-sues-jpmorgan-for-5-billion-for-closing-his-bank-accounts-17892253?mod=hp_lead_pos1>. “We regret having to do so but often rules and regulatory expectations lead us to do so. We have been asking both this Administration and prior administrations to change the rules and regulations that put us in this position...”
Meanwhile...
Jeremy Coller, a former philosophy student from the University of Sussex, sold Coller Capital, his London private equity secondaries business for £3.2bn. Most is going to him. His executives are getting a £500m earn out over three years. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2026-01-22/pe-billionaire-jeremy-coller-times-his-eqt-secondary-exit-perfectly>
It's not easy being a Stanford MBA on a H1B visa. Stanford MBAs who are US citizens or have work authorisation achieve an average base salary of $197k after graduation; foreign-born graduates without permanent work authorization earn an average of $176k. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-23/us-loses-top-tech-talent-to-india-in-wake-of-h-1b-visa-chaos?taid=6973016d7707d00001122f34&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter&sref=DK3y4h9m>
Dan Friedman is the new man to know in credit trading at Millennium. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-22/millennium-creates-new-credit-trading-business-led-by-friedman?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260122&utm_campaign=author_17940573>
Société Générale is cutting 1,800 jobs in France. As usual, staff are being asked to leave voluntarily or retire. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/493fc3f1-50bc-4724-939f-d9ec2889459f>
Oliver Wyman's boss has been using the company chatbot to help him role play performance reviews for cutting staff. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-21/white-collar-workers-use-ai-to-have-tough-conversations-at-work>
Richard Handler is not at Davos. He is hanging out with Jefferies restructuring juniors. (Instagram) < https://www.instagram.com/stories/handlerrich/3815398006279124776/>

item.title: 50 interview questions that Morgan Stanley might ask you
item.description:
Getting a job in an investment bank is tough – and getting a job at Morgan Stanley is about as tough as it gets.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
When we last had comparable figures </news/graduate-applications-to-banking-jobs>, Morgan Stanley had the lowest acceptance rate of its peer group, with only 0.43% of intern applicants being accepted to its EMEA programs. Goldman Sachs and Citi, the only other firms for which we had EMEA figures, accepted 1% and 1.58% of applicants respectively.
Getting a job offer with more than 200 people competing per place is difficult. Very difficult, even. You’ll want to be extensively prepared – including for the critical interview process.
Luckily, if you’ve gotten this far, you’ve done the tough part. If a bank is interviewing you, that means they want you – and that means the ball is in your court. Don’t mess it up – it shouldn’t be too hard, as long as you prepare enough.
The questions below come from a variety of sources, including (but not limited to) Glassdoor, WallStreetOasis, and Reddit. They’re mostly, but not exclusively, questions asked of interns, mostly in America and the UK. And they’re all, as far as we can tell, questions that have been asked in the last six months.
General Morgan Stanley Interview Question
Walk me through your resume.
Why are you interested in Morgan Stanley specifically?
Why are you interested in this role specifically?
Tell me about a time you worked on a team and faced a significant challenge.
Describe a time you had to collaborate with a difficult colleague.
How do you handle feedback and criticism from your supervisor?
Where do you see yourself in five years?
What sets Morgan Stanley apart from its competitors?
What are you hoping for from this role?
Tell me about a time you failed. What did you learn from it?
Why did you apply to work at this specific office?
Describe a time you showed leadership.
How do you handle high-pressure situations?
What are the core values of Morgan Stanley?
Describe yourself in three words.
Tell me about a time that you persuaded someone of your POV?
What would you call your achievement to date? Why?
How do you stay organised when you have competing priorities?
Why/how did you choose your field of study?
Describe your ideal daily schedule.
Sales & Trading Morgan Stanley Interview Questions
What do you know about derivatives?
Where did the S&P and 10Y close yesterday?
Explain the Greeks.
Explain how they [the Greeks] impact option pricing.
How do changes in the interest rate typically impact bond prices?
Who are our primary clients in the S&T space?
If the Fed maintains rates, what is the likely impact on equity prices?
Are convertibles more like bonds or equities, in your opinion?
Talk about a specific trade idea you have right now, including entry and exit points.
How do you explain complex financial products to non-financial clients?
Investment Banking Morgan Stanley Interview Questions
Tell me a recent news story involving a client of ours.
Tell me a recent news story involving a client of ours.
Walk me through the DCF to value a sports team.
What multiples would you use to value a high-growth app, enterprise software, and a semiconductor company?
How are the three main financial statements linked?
How would you assess the creditworthiness of a client?
Explain the concept of an LBO.
What is the difference between enterprise value and equity value?
How does a $10 increase in depreciation affect the three financial statements?
If you have $100m to invest, where would you? Why?
Talk about a recent M&A transaction that interested you.
Technology Morgan Stanley Interview Questions
What major technological trends do you expect to see in the financial sector over the next six months?
Explain the core principles of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP).
How do you reverse a string without using any built-in functions or libraries?
What is the difference between a Singleton pattern and a Factory pattern?
Describe a project where you had to make a difficult technical design choice.
How would you design a system to process a high frequency of trading data in real-time?
Explain the trade-offs between using a SQL database and a NoSQL database.
Describe a (technical) conflict you had with a teammate and the specific steps you took to resolve it.
Explain the difference between git rebase and git remap.
How you handle pressure when coding/designing under time pressure.

item.title: Quant researcher salaries revealed at 30 hedge funds & trading firms: Citadel, Jane Street and more
item.description:
The big appeal of working as a quant researcher </news/quant-jobs-finance> at a hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> or trading firm is the performance-based bonuses, but it's always nice to have a healthy base salary. According to data from the H1B salary database, there are plenty of firms paying a base above $200k
Click here to follow our new WhatsApp channel, and get instant news updates straight to your phone 📱 <https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029VacsPmzKGGGK91C7dR39>.
Below, we've broken down average pay for quant researchers </news/what-is-a-quant-researcher-hedge-fund> at 30 hedge funds and trading firms that posted H1B salaries for multiple quant employees. Based on over 270 data points for quantitative researchers since the start of 2025, the average salary in the US is $190k, slightly lower than the New York average of $198k.
Miami </news/citadel-miami> is the top paying city in the US, but one of the joint-top paying firm is a lesser-known prop trading firm from New York.
Since the start of 2024, Five Rings </news/2023/05/hedge-fund-prop-trading-firm-salaries> has paid eight H1B quantitative researchers a salary of exactly $300k. Each of those has been based in New York. Current job listings reflect those figures; experienced quant researcher openings and even quant internships at the firm post a flat average salary of $300k. Overall pay is likely much higher than that; Five Rings paid $1.06m per head to its London office in 2024 despite the firm making an $11m loss. Five Rings describes itself as having an "open and fun culture", <https://fiverings.com/> and is notably founded by ex-Jane Street partner (and Ferrari driver <https://www.ferrari.com/en-EN/corse-clienti/drivers/jason-mccarthy>) Jason McCarthy. Jane Street also pays $300k to its 'researchers' (quant is absent from their title).
The highest paying hedge fund is Point72, which hires multiple H1B quants in its IAC (internal alpha capture) team and pays almost $250k on average. At the higher end, one of these IAC researchers earned a salary of $400k. The next highest paying hedge funds are Citadel and Two Sigma, which each pay ~$230k
It's worth noting that these salaries are just a snapshot of earning potential and don't reflect the full picture for salaries. Funds are known not to play the H1B lottery </news/quants-on-h1-b-visas> when hiring quants, meaning most of these hires have been brought in from larger multinational corporations like banks or FAANG firms. The data, therefore, leaves out homegrown talent </news/hedge-funds-with-graduate-training-programmes> that funds and trading firms have been increasingly prioritizing the development of. It also doesn't include some of the most senior employees who've worked in the US long enough to obtain a green card, or workers brought in on 'exceptional talent' O1-A visas.
These days, the highest paying roles for quants aren't pure quant researchers. Instead, elite trading firms want hybrid </news/the-rise-of-the-quant-engineer-infra-hybrid> candidates who can do a little bit of everything, including quant development </news/2023/03/quant-developers-vs-quant-researchers> and infrastructure engineering.

item.title: Hedge fund Two Sigma hired a top Goldman Sachs AI technologist in London
item.description:
Goldman Sachs is one of the banks (cautiously </news/the-study-suggesting-goldman-sachs-was-right-about-ai-all-along>) leading the charge on AI, </news/how-to-get-a-banking-ai-job> so much so that it's already using the technology as a justification to cut staff. </news/goldman-sachs-job-cuts-ai> Some hedge funds </news/best-place-to-work-hedge-fund> have been on the hype train even earlier, however, and one that has been using generative AI </news/agentic-ai-generative-use-cases-finance> as early as 2019 just poached one of Goldman's top AI technologists.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Francesco Maria Delle Fave has joined Two Sigma in London as a senior vice president for AI and machine learning, working on tools that power the quant fund's research platform. He's a PhD mathematician that spent the last eight years working at Goldman across a number of roles, including EMEA head of applied AI and EMEA head of its data science and machine learning in quantitative finance (DSML QF) team. He first joined the firm as a quant strat. </news/strats-jobs-investment-banks>
Delle Fave has previously professed an interest in reinforcement learning (RL) </news/2023/10/will-ai-replace-traders-goldman-sachs>, a comparatively niche AI technique compared to machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP). He's also a big fan of synthetic data. Two Sigma, too, has been working on RL since at least 2021 <https://www.twosigma.com/articles/a-24x-speedup-for-reinforcement-learning-with-rllib-ray/>. The fund is also a veteran in the natural language processing space; AI core team lead Mike Schuster said <https://www.twosigma.com/articles/how-to-get-the-most-from-llms/> at a Columbia University conference in 2024 that Two Sigma had used generative AI for at least five years and NLP for more than a decade.
Two Sigma's London office pays staff well; 'wages and salaries' in its UK entity were £377k ($507k) </news/two-sigma-pay-london> per head in its most recent annual accounts via Companies House, above the likes of Citadel and Brevan Howard. </news/best-paying-hedge-funds> In the US, Two Sigma employs AI researchers on $220k in salary alone. </news/top-paying-ai-jobs>

item.title: Morning Coffee: The world’s best banker freebie is coming to an end. Hong Kong’s hottest new jobs
item.description:
Larry Fink must have known that it was going to be a tough job when he agreed <https://www.ft.com/content/f8a5c4e8-8706-4c29-96b7-fb6cd4eb8cb4> to become interim co-chair of the World Economic Forum, the organising committee of Davos. It must have felt like the billionaire equivalent of the PTA job or carnival organising committee board that nobody wants to do, and so which ends up being done by the most public-spirited person present. But even in his worst stress dreams about this year’s party, he can’t have foreseen himself trying to calm down a hostile crowd <https://www.ft.com/content/e2ae0417-6146-4428-96db-0484a6b024d1> at a dinner where Al Gore heckled the US Secretary of Commerce and the President of the European Central Bank walked out.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
It has been that kind of a year. Historically, the criticism of Davos has been that it’s tended to be a bit boring or vapid, with middlebrow celebrities <https://www.politico.eu/article/davos-desirables-celebrities-world-economic-forum-altman-benioff-william-yeoh-macron-amherd-dimon-reeves-dalio-maxima-philippe-mathilde-sting-coster-waldau/> trying to act like serious businesspeople and philanthropists, as CEOs sang show tunes <https://kiteinsights.com/issues-that-matter/investing-in-skills-is-the-commitment-that-counts-0> and pretended to understand algorithms. This year, the headlines have been more about “possible imminent annexation <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjrzjqg8dlwt> of NATO” than “whither women in biotechnology”. Even the celebs <https://news.sky.com/story/sir-david-beckham-refuses-to-answer-sky-news-questions-in-davos-13496537> have been more newsworthy than usual.
So even if nobody else remembers their thank you letters, the news media ought to be wishing Larry a hearty “best Davos ever” as they pack up their snow boots. But it might be the last one.
Because apparently, Fink is considering moving the WEF meetings <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-21/fink-ponders-moving-wef-meetings-from-davos-to-dublin-or-detroit> to “Dublin or Detroit” (these might have been picked because they begin with the same letter) or to “Jakarta and Buenos Aires”. And that would be a totally different vibe.
It’s obviously more convenient for the attendees to hold the conference in a normal city where you aren’t booking up the entire hotel space plus a little bit more. And the embarrassment factor of having all the private jets practically visible from the climate change panels would be reduced. But it’s not all about convenience.
If the WEF takes place in a city, the CEOs of major banks are likely to spend most of their time at their local office doing normal work, and then just hop downtown for their panels and meetings. That reduces the opportunities for informal contact and chance meetings that take place when there’s nothing else to do and you’re suddenly in a town where half the population are CEOs.
Also, you can’t ski in Dublin or Jakarta, and if you wander round central Detroit looking for a piano bar you might have a nasty encounter. For decades, Davos has been the ultimate banker freebie. It’s incredibly expensive, but the company pays and you get to have fun. If it’s just another economic forum, it’s gradually only going to attract the kind of people who actually enjoy panel sessions about opportunities in African telecoms.
If this happens to Davos, it might as well be a Zoom call. That would be a lot less stress for BlackRock’s CEO to organise, but a sad day for ambitious and fun-loving bankers. At least they will have gone out with an unforgettable bang.
Elsewhere in the world, the general atmosphere of chaos that’s characterised the beginning of 2026 is fantastic news for those who profit from volatility. And among that number are bankers in the equity-linked bond market <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/newsletters/2026-01-21/asia-equity-linked-deals-start-2026-strongly>. The Hong Kong market has already done $2.5bn of convertibles deals so far this year; that’s the best start since 2021 and just about double the pace of 2025, which was itself a record year for issuance.
Convertibles are always attractive to investors and issuers when equity volatility is high, because this increases the value of the embedded option, giving the companies a lower coupon and investors more upside. They also tend to benefit from a “success breeds success” effect – they are slightly unconventional financial instruments, so it’s good to be able to point nervous clients toward recent deals that have gone well. And a healthy convertibles market is always good for the overall industry, because the investor base tends to include a lot of hedge funds who actively trade them. Local specialists for global banks like Goldman Sachs’ Christian Lhert and BoA’s Sam Ng are going to be good people to know this year.
Meanwhile…
Barclays has started the formal process to begin moving its European headquarters from Dublin to Paris. While this may make it less convenient for future Davos summits, it recognises that the “financial capital of Euroland” battle has been definitively won. (Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/barclays-to-move-ahead-with-relocation-of-european-base-to-paris-31359756?mod=topic_news>)
More Davos kerfuffle – US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has claimed that Christian Sewing called him up to disavow George Saravelos’ research report. Deutsche is neither confirming nor denying, saying that “We generally do not comment on potential communication between the bank and government representatives” and reminding everyone that the point of an independent research department is that it’s not telling you what the management thinks in the first place. (Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/business/davos/bessent-says-deutsche-bank-ceo-called-distance-bank-analysts-greenland-report-2026-01-21/>)
After yesterday’s announcement of Alex Berkett, Citi have made another hire from industry. Anand Govind was until recently the CFO of O9 Solutions, a cloud computing company. But before that he was a tech industry banker for JPM and MS, and now he’s going to be an MD focused on AI and software company coverage. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-21/citigroup-hires-tech-executive-govind-for-investment-banking?embedded-checkout=true>)
A little bit of care is needed in reading the headline this story – Ben Frost of Goldman Sachs is a “retail banker” in the sense of being an investment banker covering the consumer and retail sector, not a “retail banker” in the sense of ever having been involved with the Marcus or credit card ventures. (Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/goldman-sachs-promotes-consumer-retail-bankers-ben-frost-named-chairman-2026-01-21/>)
The Financial Conduct Authority now wants its regulators to spend 50% of their time regulating in the office, rather than regulating from home. (Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/fca-ups-office-attendance-to-50-7ea9b9a4?mod=topic_news>)
“The Narrative” is a quite unusual sounding documentary, premiering at a Swiss film festival this week and featuring Kweku Adoboli, the former UBS trader who was responsible for over $2bn of undisclosed losses. The film doesn’t give much context for what happened, but allows Adoboli to give his side of the story, and shows his new life in Ghana, after being deported from London at the end of his jail sentence. (BlueWin <https://www.bluewin.ch/en/entertainment/the-narrative-documentary-on-the-inner-turmoil-of-ex-ubs-trader-adoboli-3060494.html>)
