item.title: First UBS's head of technology left. Now tech people are being cut
item.description:
It's not just Citi. </news/citi-job-cuts-2026-bonuses>UBS's intention to cut jobs in early 2026 has also been well-flagged </news/ubs-layoffs-credit-suisse>. And those cuts are also approaching.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-13/ermotti-flags-job-cuts-as-ubs-nears-credit-suisse-integration?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260113&utm_campaign=author_21003048> reports that UBS will start a new round of job cuts "soon" and implies that they may afflict technology staff more than others. UBS says it's still running two separate IT systems in Switzerland (UBS's and Credit Suisse's) and that it intends to shut one and create "synergies".
Up to 3,000 jobs will go as a result. The timeline for their disappearance is between now and early 2027.
Coincidentally or not, the cuts follow the disappearance of Mike Dargan, UBS's former group COO and chief technology officer, who left at the end of December for digital bank N26.
Dargan, who spent nine years at UBS after joining from Standard Chartered, was assigned one of the Swiss bank's most stressful jobs </news/mike-dargan-ubs> after the Credit Suisse acquisition. It included moving 1.3m Credit Suisse customers with 110 petabytes of data are involved onto the UBS platform while also closing 3,000 Credit Suisse applications and 40,000 Credit Suisse servers.
With the Credit Suisse system seemingly being shut down, it appears that neither Dargan nor some members of his team are now required. This should be no surprise: even in 2023, UBS said it planned to close 90% of Credit Suisse's IT applications. </news/2023/08/credit-suisse-tech-jobs-ubs>
IT people may not be the only ones cut, though. UBS declined to comment on the cuts when we inquired last week, but sources at the bank have suggested the cuts may be cross department and impact 15% of some teams.
UBS announces bonuses in mid-February </news/investment-banking-bonus-schedule-calendar>, so anyone let go soon will go without a bonus. It's thought that this year's bonus pool at the bank may not be the best.

item.title: HFT firm Flow Traders brought in a new equities chief, courtesy of DRW
item.description:
The world’s electronic trading firms might seem similar on the outside, but they have some very different specialities </news/difference-between-electronic-trading-firms>. Despite that, or maybe because of it, they love hiring from each other.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Lawrence Hume joined Dutch HFT firm Flow Traders this week as global head of its cash equities & tokenized trading team, based in London. He joined the firm from Chicago-based rival DRW, where he spent four years, and where he was head of European equity volatility trading.
Hume spent years bouncing around London’s banks before switching to market makers. He moved from Merrill Lynch to Goldman Sachs </news/2014/08/goldman-sachs-jobs-suddenly-filled-outsiders-bank-america> after just two years at the former, and nine months at the latter before quitting for Morgan Stanley </news/2015/03/7-interesting-people-hired-by-goldman-sachs-baml-and-morgan-stanley-in-march-and-what-they-mean-for-you>, where he ended up staying for more than six years.
Flow Traders hasn’t released its Q4/FY results for 2025 yet, but it had a pretty bad Q3. “Variable employee expenses”, a proxy for bonuses, halved in Q3 of 2025 compared to the same period in 2024. They were still up for the year including the first two quarters, but it’s a bad sign.
DRW, meanwhile, is adding people with a prodigious appetite. Just in the last few months, it’s added BNP equities MD Deepak Sran <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/bnp-paribas-syndicate-banker-sran-exits-for-drw-7091c0c8>, crowd-sourced hedge fund Numerai’s CTO James Elford </news/the-cto-of-a-crowdsourced-hedge-fund-joined-trading-firm-drw>, and Jane Street’s tax UK expert Christopher Read </news/christopher-read-drw>.

item.title: Morgan Stanley's new VPs include a 25-year-old Scottish sheep farmer in New York
item.description:
Last week, Morgan Stanley promoted some new managing directors. </news/morgan-stanley-s-2026-md-list-ai-experts-ex-hedge-fund-traders>However, it also promoted some new vice presidents (VPs). In New York, they included a new young VP who not so long ago was working on a sheep farm in Scotland.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Aged 25, Scott Ritchie is working in financial control, planning and analysis for Morgan Stanley in NYC. Aged 22, he was working part-time for a sheep farm in Bishopston, a small village in Scotland, after completing a finance apprenticeship at Morgan Stanley in Glasgow.
Morgan Stanley declined to comment for this article and Ritchie didn't respond to a request to comment, but his success looks like an advertisement both for apprenticeships </news/2022/02/apprenticeships-banks> and for jobs in the middle office. </news/finance/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking>
It's understood that Ritchie left his local Scottish high school aged 16. Writing on LinkedIn, he says spent nine years working part-time on beef and sheep farms between the ages of 13 and 22 and that this shaped his work ethic. At Morgan Stanley, he was an apprentice for three years before completing the ACCA exams and becoming an analyst in Glasgow. He was promoted to associate aged 21 and then moved to New York aged 23.
There are no sheep or cows in New York, but Ritchie is now working with bigger beasts in the form of Morgan Stanley's US CFO and US Comptroller. His career is thought to have been accelerated by the fact that he was designated a rising star within Morgan Stanley and by the support of Morgan Stanley's former US CFO.
Ritchie's success is a reminder that there is more to banking than M&A </news/what-are-ma-jobs> and sales and trading. </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank>It's also a reminder that you don't need direct financial services experience to work your way up in banking, and that sheep farming as well as McDonald's </news/2022/05/100-hour-weeks> can bolster a CV </news/the-absolutely-perfect-investment-banking-cv> if deployed correctly.

item.title: Another Eisler PM has left for hedge fund Balyasny
item.description:
Multiple multistrategy hedge funds </news/best-paying-hedge-funds> are quite fond of traders working at Eisler Capital. Brevan Howard </news/eisler-brevan-howard> is one of them, Balyasny </news/where-do-portfolio-managers-work-balyasny> is another.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Balyasny hired Nikoloaos Rapanos, a portfolio manager at Eisler Capital, for its macro trading team. According to his LinkedIn, he joined the fund last year and is based in London.
Rapanos spent 18 months at Eisler in what was his first fully-fledged PM role. Prior to that, he spent six years at macro hedge fund Caxton Associates as a sub-PM in its global macro team. Rapanos has a PhD in finance and previously worked as an associate at Goldman Sachs.
He's one of many Eisler alums to join Balyasny, which has a thing for Eisler's quant strats. </news/strats-jobs-investment-banks> Last week, we reported on Tibor Kucs </news/eisler-capital-strats-to-balyasny> who joined to lead a team of equities quant </news/quant-jobs-finance>researchers.
Other strats have joined as portfolio managers; Alexander Alekseev </news/eisler-capital>, a top systematic equities PM, joined in October to build out a team and took five other Eisler people with him. Rapanos may not have been a strat at Eisler but spent much of his time at Caxton working in quant research.

item.title: Morning Coffee: Citi announces job cuts days before bonuses. Sergio Ermotti wants out at UBS
item.description:
If you have a keen memory for news involving Citi, you could deploy it to remember that before Christmas we said </news/citi-job-cuts-2026>that Citi would be cutting jobs in the New Year. This is now happening, albeit at a small scale.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-12/citi-to-cut-about-1-000-jobs-this-week-as-fraser-trims-costs> reports that Citi is planning 1,000 job cuts this week, less than 1% of its 227,000 employees. The bank is saying that: "These changes reflect adjustments we’re making to ensure our staffing levels, locations and expertise align with current business needs; efficiencies we have gained through technology; and progress against our transformation work.”
While this suggests that the cuts might be about Citi's enthusiasm for AI agents <https://www.wsj.com/articles/ai-agents-arrive-at-citi-60a3559d?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqfAXBXM2t-IJmWclHwXocgXIQx8HzcdHwhtCu9I3M28QR-Wda70jWGIZ5PNZHA%3D&gaa_ts=6966050a&gaa_sig=ZTs5HbxTNBAeT8Mns1OAcPTCn9_6TxgPV_o2bc4ZJZZayzVtgo36m3aL8wzYRHEnyG2PhRbid3r--0brB-6ldw%3D%3D>or offshoring, </news/ill-conceived-offshoring-destroyed-this-bank>our pre-Christmas sources said the bank's post-Christmas cuts would be more about eliminating underperforming managing directors and saving money on their bonuses.
Given that Citi is expected to announce bonuses </news/banker-bonuses> on Thursday </news/goldman-sachs-bonuses-are-announced-thursday-jp-morgan-people-must-wait> this week, the cuts do indeed seem timed to swap severance packages for performance pay. Citi insiders who fell foul of the bank's notorious forced ranking system during annual reviews tell us they're apprehensive about what comes next. "I've never been ranked this low before," says one. "I think they're planning to push me out."
Separately, after being persuaded back from the beach by Colm Kelleher to run the combined UBS and Credit Suisse in 2023, Sergio Ermotti will soon return to whence he came.
The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/0b6e4687-0804-448c-a7c4-155bc6005136> reports that Ermotti plans to step down as CEO of UBS for a second time in April 2027 and that Colm Kelleher is looking for his replacement.
This should come as no surprise. When Kelleher persuaded Ermotti to come back, Ermotti always said he wouldn't stay forever. “There is a lot of life in him, but he is not as young as some people,” observed Kelleher keenly at the time. <https://www.ft.com/content/b63a2e33-bc11-4059-ab7f-8784daa19674>
Ermotti, who is 65, does not need the money. When he first retired from UBS </news/2023/11/sergio-ermotti-ubs-124> in 2020, he said </news/2023/03/sergio-ermotti-ubs> he no longer needed to work for cash and was following his passion and holidaying in the Maldives. Last year alone, he earned another $17m.
UBS has long said it would like an internal successor to occupy Ermotti's seat and was said by the FT <https://www.ft.com/content/844cd731-ad33-4556-9bdd-c3a28f95d4ed> in 2024 to be planning a shortlist of three candidates. The FT says the favourite is Aleksandar Ivanovic, the head of asset management, or maybe Iqbal Khan and Robert Karofsky, who co-head wealth. COO Bea Martin is a fourth possibility.
Meanwhile...
Morgan Stanley increased bonuses in Asia by 20%. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-13/morgan-stanley-lifts-asia-bonuses-20-after-record-revenue-haul>
Conor Hillery, head of investment banking for EMEA at JPMorgan, says he's making "selective hires" for his European dealmaking team but is preparing a "big expansion in the Middle East" and "growing in some emerging markets like Turkey and sub-Saharan Africa.” This will happen irrespective of market conditions. (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/amp/articles/jpmorgan-emea-dealmaking-boss-looks-to-middle-east-emerging-markets-for-growth-5e5d31a4>
Now China is looking at the trades of Jane Street, and others. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-13/china-examines-foreign-etf-trades-after-jane-street-india-probe>
Hedge fund Diameter Partners made money shorting First Brands' senior debt when it was trading in the 90 cent range because it thought it "smelled of fraud." Then it decided it wasn't so smelly and bought the debt for 30 cents on the dollar in the expectation that it would recover. It now trades at 20 cents on the dollar and Diameter has lost $100m. “A mere three months later, and the letters F-B haunt us every time we close our eyes.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-13/diameter-s-winning-bet-on-first-brands-turns-horribly-wrong>
Standard Chartered wants to set up crypto prime broking. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-12/stanchart-said-to-prepare-crypto-expansion-with-prime-brokerage>
When the cap on unfair dismissal payments is removed </news/unlimited-compensation-for-unfair-dismissal-bankers-uk>, banks might stop hiring or fire before it becomes applicable. “We would expect employers to be a lot more ruthless in operating probationary periods and terminating employment before employees reach the six-month mark." (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/amp/articles/city-could-lose-more-jobs-to-eu-after-unfair-dismissal-cap-change-c81040f4>
Puneet Sethi, a commodities and a rates trader, left Eisler and joined Millennium. (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/millennium-hires-eisler-capital-money-manager-701944b1?mod=newswires>
The problem with private equity is the rigidity of commitments made under uncertainty about future public market returns. If an investor wants one third in private equity, one third in stocks, one third in bonds, and private equity is committed last, the amount committed to PE will vary according to the value of the other investments. (Substack) <https://ludovicphalippou.substack.com/p/private-equity-illiquidity-is-not?utm_source=substack&publication_id=7474535&post_id=184022601&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share&triggerShare=true&isFreemail=true&r=qrn8&triedRedirect=true>
London bankers are no longer making money on their houses. 14.8% of London sellers sold for less in 2025 than they originally paid and the problem was particularly acute in the City of London, Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster, and Hammersmith and Fulham. (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/dbefd2d9-149d-45b0-88d5-886bd1952c02>
A Lazard banker is accused of making $41m in insider trading profits through illicit activities like hijacking user accounts on breast cancer forums and discussing how great the drugs they'd invested in were. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-12/ex-lazard-banker-s-insider-tips-reaped-41-million-haul-us-says?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260112&utm_campaign=author_16830521>

item.title: Jefferies hires top Hong Kong industrials banker from HSBC
item.description:
Last year, Jefferies was vocal about its desire to promote more managing directors (MDs) from within and hire less externally. </news/jefferies-md-hiring> Nonetheless, exceptions are made when necessary, as is the case with the bank's latest hire in Hong Kong. </news/best-university-for-banking-jobs-hong-kong-singapore>
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Misi Tang announced via LinkedIn late last week that she is joining Jefferies as its Asia head of diversified industrials, </news/bankers-say-it-s-not-just-baird-most-industrials-teams-are-a-nightmare> based in Hong Kong. Her most recent role appears to be at HSBC; Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-11-05/hsbc-is-said-to-hire-misi-tang-from-barclays-to-boost-asia-deals>reported in 2019 that she joined the bank as its APAC head of capital goods and auto coverage.
Prior to that, Tang spent a decade at Barclays, where she was an MD and China head of Industrials.
New senior arrivals at Jefferies are becoming increasingly rare after years of being very common. The bank said in its October 2025 investor day <https://ir.jefferies.com/overview/> that it expected to hire just five external MDs across 2025. Tang's arrival means the bank is now 20% of the way towards last year's total.
